"url": "http://www.actionnewsjax.com/news/world/the-latest-submarine-owner-held-in-missing-womans-death/588678819", "body": "Copenhagen police say the owner of an amateur built submarine that sank in Denmark's water has been arrested on suspicion of murder in the disappearance of a Swedish journalist who had been a passenger on his vessel.\n\nPolice said in a statement Friday night that the man has denied killing the missing woman and said he dropped her off on an island on Thursday night.\n\nThe statement did not identify the owner, Peter Madsen, but he appeared on Danish television Friday to discuss the submarine's sinking.\n\nDeputy Police Inspector Jens Moller Jensen says investigators are looking for witnesses who may have seen the woman after the time Madsen reported she disembarked. She also was not identified by name.\n\nThe police statement says the submarine is lying in seven feet of water but divers have not been able to enter it safely yet.\n\nSwedish police are investigating the whereabouts of a missing woman who had been on a privately built submarine that sank off Denmark.\n\nSwedish and Danish media reported that the woman was a journalist who had been writing about the UC3 Nautilus' owner and builder, Peter Madsen.\n\nThe Danish navy rescued Madsen after launching a search for the submarine early Friday. He told authorities he had been alone on the vessel.\n\nNavy spokesman Anders Damgaard says Madsen \"told us that the journalist who also had been on board had been dropped off Thursday evening.\"\n\nIt was the woman's boyfriend who alerted authorities the submarine was missing early Friday.\n\nThe owner of a large, privately built submarine that sank south of Copenhagen says the vessel went down after a minor problem with a ballast tank turned into a major issue.\n\nPeter Madsen built the UC3 Nautilus and launched it in 2008. It was considered the largest privately submarine of its kind in the world.\n\nAfter being rescued by the Danish navy on Friday, the 46-year-old Madsen told Denmark's TV2 channel \"I am fine, but sad because Nautilus went down.\"\n\nThe ballast tank is a compartment that holds water, which is used as ballast to provide stability for a vessel.\n\nMadsen said that once the problem with the ballast tank started, \"It took about 30 seconds for Nautilus to sink and I couldn't close any hatches or anything.\"\n\nHe added: \"I guess that was pretty good because I otherwise still would have been down there.\"\n\nThe Danish navy says a crowdfunded, amateur-built submarine that was missing in Danish waters has sunk south of Copenhagen, but the owner and builder who was alone onboard is safe.\n\nThe navy initially said the 40-ton, nearly 18-meter-long (60-foot-long) UC3 Nautilus was \"found sailing\" south of Copenhagen on Friday. However, navy press spokesman Anders Damgaard later said it had sunk and owner Peter Madsen \"taken over to one of our ships.\"\n\nDamgaard declined to give details.\n\nFootage aired on Denmark's TV2 channel showed the 46-year-old Madsen, 46, getting off what looked to be a private boat and making a thumbs up sign as he walked away. It was not clear why the submarine sank.\n\nA privately built submarine that was feared missing in Danish waters has been found and the crew is safe, the Danish navy said Friday.\n\nThe 40-ton, nearly 18-meter-long (60-foot-long) submarine with at least two people on board was \"found sailing\" south of Copenhagen, the navy tweeted. It called off the search for the UC3 Nautilus submarine in the area from Copenhagen to the Baltic Sea island of Bornholm with two helicopters and three ships.\n\nNavy spokesman Christer Haven earlier had said members of the public with boats and sonar equipment were urged to take part in the search.\n\nIt wasn't immediately clear why the submarine crew failed to respond to radio contact.\n\nThe Danish navy says it is searching for a 40-ton, nearly 18-meter (60-foot) -long, privately built submarine in the waters off Copenhagen with at least two people on board.\n\nNavy spokesman Christer Haven says two helicopters and three ships are taking part in the search for the UC3 Nautilus submarine in the area from Copenhagen to the Baltic Sea island of Bornholm.\n\nHaven says members of the public with boats and sonar equipment have also been urged to take part in the search.\n\nHe said the search started after authorities got a call early Friday that the submarine had not returned to Copenhagen as planned. Owner Peter Madsen, who built the vessel that was launched in 2008, is believed to be on board along with a reporter.\n\nAn amateur-built submarine financed through crowdfunding sunk in Denmark's waters on Friday and the owner was found safe onboard, the Danish navy said. However, a Swedish journalist who had been on the vessel is reported missing.\n\nPeter Madsen, who built the UC3 Nautilus submarine that first was launched in 2008, was taken aboard a military ship, navy spokesman Anders Damgaard said. He declined to give further details.\n\nFootage aired on Denmark's TV2 channel showed the 46-year-old Madsen getting off what appeared to be a private boat and making a thumbs-up sign as he walked away.\n\n\"I am fine, but sad because Nautilus went down,\" he told Denmark's TV2 channel. Madsen said \"a minor problem with a ballast tank ... turned into a major issue\" that ultimately caused the vessel - considered the largest privately built submarine of its kind - to sink.\n\nSwedish police said they are investigating the whereabouts of a missing woman who had been on the submarine at some point.\n\n\"Whether the woman was on board the submarine at the time of her disappearance is unclear,\" police said in a statement.\n\nThe woman was a journalist writing about Madsen and his submarine, Swedish and Danish media reported.\n\n\"He told us that the journalist who also had been on board had been dropped off Thursday evening,\" Damgaard told The Associated Press. \"They were the only two on board yesterday.\"\n\nIt was the woman's boyfriend who alerted authorities the submarine was missing early Friday. Two helicopters and three ships combed the sea from Copenhagen to the Baltic Sea island of Bornholm.\n\nThe navy also encouraged members of the public with boats and sonar to search, too.\n\n\"It took about 30 seconds for Nautilus to sink, and I couldn't close any hatches or anything,\" Madsen said. \"But I guess that was pretty good because I otherwise still would have been down there.\"\n\nThe ballast tank is a compartment that holds water, which is used as ballast to provide stability for a vessel.\n\nThe navy initially said the sub was \"found sailing\" south of Copenhagen. But Damgaard later said the 40-ton, nearly 18-meter-long (60-foot-long) submarine had sunk.\n\nMadsen \"told us he had technical problems\" to explain why the submarine failed to respond to radio contact, Damgaard said.\n\nDanish media reported police sent divers down to the submarine. There were no official comments.", "time": "19:48:00"}

"http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_islands_in_the_Baltic_Sea", "label": {"eng": "List of islands in the Baltic Sea"}, "score": 3, "type": "wiki", "id": "1238823"}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/UC3_Nautilus", "label": {"eng": "UC3 Nautilus"}, "score": 5, "type": "wiki", "id": "1438666"}], "url": "http://nationalpost.com/pmn/news-pmn/the-latest-submarine-owner-held-in-missing-womans-death/wcm/d95bce6b-f11f-4d41-b36f-cfc5ed6b6520", "body": "COPENHAGEN -- The Latest on a private submarine that sank off Denmark: (all times local):\n\n8:10 p.m.\n\nCopenhagen police say the owner of an amateur built submarine that sank in Denmark's water has been arrested on suspicion of murder in the disappearance of a Swedish journalist who had been a passenger on his vessel.\n\nPolice said in a statement Friday night that the man has denied killing the missing woman and said he dropped her off on an island on Thursday night.\n\nThe statement did not identify the owner, Peter Madsen, but he appeared on Danish television Friday to discuss the submarine's sinking.\n\nDeputy Police Inspector Jens Moller Jensen says investigators are looking for witnesses who may have seen the woman after the time Madsen reported she disembarked. She also was not identified by name.\n\nThe police statement says the submarine is lying in seven feet of water but divers have not been able to enter it safely yet.\n\n-- --\n\n3:10 p.m.\n\nSwedish police are investigating the whereabouts of a missing woman who had been on a privately built submarine that sank off Denmark.\n\nSwedish and Danish media reported that the woman was a journalist who had been writing about the UC3 Nautilus' owner and builder, Peter Madsen.\n\nThe Danish navy rescued Madsen after launching a search for the submarine early Friday. He told authorities he had been alone on the vessel.\n\nNavy spokesman Anders Damgaard says Madsen \"told us that the journalist who also had been on board had been dropped off Thursday evening.\"\n\nIt was the woman's boyfriend who alerted authorities the submarine was missing early Friday.\n\n-- --\n\n1:35 p.m.\n\nThe owner of a large, privately built submarine that sank south of Copenhagen says the vessel went down after a minor problem with a ballast tank turned into a major issue.\n\nPeter Madsen built the UC3 Nautilus and launched it in 2008. It was considered the largest privately submarine of its kind in the world.\n\nAfter being rescued by the Danish navy on Friday, the 46-year-old Madsen told Denmark's TV2 channel \"I am fine, but sad because Nautilus went down.\"\n\nThe ballast tank is a compartment that holds water, which is used as ballast to provide stability for a vessel.\n\nMadsen said that once the problem with the ballast tank started, \"It took about 30 seconds for Nautilus to sink and I couldn't close any hatches or anything.\"\n\nHe added: \"I guess that was pretty good because I otherwise still would have been down there.\"\n\n-- --\n\n12:25 p.m.\n\nThe Danish navy says a crowdfunded, amateur-built submarine that was missing in Danish waters has sunk south of Copenhagen, but the owner and builder who was alone onboard is safe.\n\nThe navy initially said the 40-ton, nearly 18-meter-long (60-foot-long) UC3 Nautilus was \"found sailing\" south of Copenhagen on Friday. However, navy press spokesman Anders Damgaard later said it had sunk and owner Peter Madsen \"taken over to one of our ships.\"\n\nDamgaard declined to give details.\n\nFootage aired on Denmark's TV2 channel showed the 46-year-old Madsen, 46, getting off what looked to be a private boat and making a thumbs up sign as he walked away. It was not clear why the submarine sank.\n\n-- --\n\n11:15 a.m.\n\nA privately built submarine that was feared missing in Danish waters has been found and the crew is safe, the Danish navy said Friday.\n\nThe 40-ton, nearly 18-meter-long (60-foot-long) submarine with at least two people on board was \"found sailing\" south of Copenhagen, the navy tweeted. It called off the search for the UC3 Nautilus submarine in the area from Copenhagen to the Baltic Sea island of Bornholm with two helicopters and three ships.\n\nNavy spokesman Christer Haven earlier had said members of the public with boats and sonar equipment were urged to take part in the search.\n\nIt wasn't immediately clear why the submarine crew failed to respond to radio contact.\n\n-- --\n\n9:50 a.m.\n\nThe Danish navy says it is searching for a 40-ton, nearly 18-meter (60-foot) -long, privately built submarine in the waters off Copenhagen with at least two people on board.\n\nNavy spokesman Christer Haven says two helicopters and three ships are taking part in the search for the UC3 Nautilus submarine in the area from Copenhagen to the Baltic Sea island of Bornholm.\n\nHaven says members of the public with boats and sonar equipment have also been urged to take part in the search.\n\nHe said the search started after authorities got a call early Friday that the submarine had not returned to Copenhagen as planned. Owner Peter Madsen, who built the vessel that was launched in 2008, is believed to be on board along with a reporter.\n\nAn amateur-built submarine financed through crowdfunding sunk in Denmark's waters on Friday and the owner was found safe onboard, the Danish navy said. However, a Swedish journalist who had been on the vessel is reported missing.\n\nPeter Madsen, who built the UC3 Nautilus submarine that first was launched in 2008, was taken aboard a military ship, navy spokesman Anders Damgaard said. He declined to give further details.\n\nFootage aired on Denmark's TV2 channel showed the 46-year-old Madsen getting off what appeared to be a private boat and making a thumbs-up sign as he walked away.\n\n\"I am fine, but sad because Nautilus went down,\" he told Denmark's TV2 channel. Madsen said \"a minor problem with a ballast tank ... turned into a major issue\" that ultimately caused the vessel -- considered the largest privately built submarine of its kind -- to sink.\n\nSwedish police said they are investigating the whereabouts of a missing woman who had been on the submarine at some point.\n\n\"Whether the woman was on board the submarine at the time of her disappearance is unclear,\" police said in a statement.\n\nThe woman was a journalist writing about Madsen and his submarine, Swedish and Danish media reported.\n\n\"He told us that the journalist who also had been on board had been dropped off Thursday evening,\" Damgaard told The Associated Press. \"They were the only two on board yesterday.\"\n\nIt was the woman's boyfriend who alerted authorities the submarine was missing early Friday. Two helicopters and three ships combed the sea from Copenhagen to the Baltic Sea island of Bornholm.\n\nThe navy also encouraged members of the public with boats and sonar to search, too.\n\n\"It took about 30 seconds for Nautilus to sink, and I couldn't close any hatches or anything,\" Madsen said. \"But I guess that was pretty good because I otherwise still would have been down there.\"\n\nThe ballast tank is a compartment that holds water, which is used as ballast to provide stability for a vessel.\n\nThe navy initially said the sub was \"found sailing\" south of Copenhagen. But Damgaard later said the 40-ton, nearly 18-meter-long (60-foot-long) submarine had sunk.\n\nMadsen \"told us he had technical problems\" to explain why the submarine failed to respond to radio contact, Damgaard said.\n\nDanish media reported police sent divers down to the submarine. There were no official comments.", "time": "18:20:00"}

"http://www.wmcactionnews5.com/story/36117244/the-latest-submarine-owner-held-in-missing-womans-death", "body": "COPENHAGEN, Denmark (AP) - The Latest on a private submarine that sank off Denmark: (all times local):\n\n8:10 p.m.\n\nCopenhagen police say the owner of an amateur built submarine that sank in Denmark's water has been arrested on suspicion of murder in the disappearance of a Swedish journalist who had been a passenger on his vessel.\n\nPolice said in a statement Friday night that the man has denied killing the missing woman and said he dropped her off on an island on Thursday night.\n\nThe statement did not identify the owner, Peter Madsen, but he appeared on Danish television Friday to discuss the submarine's sinking.\n\nDeputy Police Inspector Jens Moller Jensen says investigators are looking for witnesses who may have seen the woman after the time Madsen reported she disembarked. She also was not identified by name.\n\nThe police statement says the submarine is lying in seven feet of water but divers have not been able to enter it safely yet.\n\nSwedish police are investigating the whereabouts of a missing woman who had been on a privately built submarine that sank off Denmark.\n\nSwedish and Danish media reported that the woman was a journalist who had been writing about the UC3 Nautilus' owner and builder, Peter Madsen.\n\nThe Danish navy rescued Madsen after launching a search for the submarine early Friday. He told authorities he had been alone on the vessel.\n\nNavy spokesman Anders Damgaard says Madsen \"told us that the journalist who also had been on board had been dropped off Thursday evening.\"\n\nIt was the woman's boyfriend who alerted authorities the submarine was missing early Friday.\n\nThe owner of a large, privately built submarine that sank south of Copenhagen says the vessel went down after a minor problem with a ballast tank turned into a major issue.\n\nPeter Madsen built the UC3 Nautilus and launched it in 2008. It was considered the largest privately submarine of its kind in the world.\n\nAfter being rescued by the Danish navy on Friday, the 46-year-old Madsen told Denmark's TV2 channel \"I am fine, but sad because Nautilus went down.\"\n\nThe ballast tank is a compartment that holds water, which is used as ballast to provide stability for a vessel.\n\nMadsen said that once the problem with the ballast tank started, \"It took about 30 seconds for Nautilus to sink and I couldn't close any hatches or anything.\"\n\nHe added: \"I guess that was pretty good because I otherwise still would have been down there.\"\n\nThe Danish navy says a crowdfunded, amateur-built submarine that was missing in Danish waters has sunk south of Copenhagen, but the owner and builder who was alone onboard is safe.\n\nThe navy initially said the 40-ton, nearly 18-meter-long (60-foot-long) UC3 Nautilus was \"found sailing\" south of Copenhagen on Friday. However, navy press spokesman Anders Damgaard later said it had sunk and owner Peter Madsen \"taken over to one of our ships.\"\n\nDamgaard declined to give details.\n\nFootage aired on Denmark's TV2 channel showed the 46-year-old Madsen, 46, getting off what looked to be a private boat and making a thumbs up sign as he walked away. It was not clear why the submarine sank.\n\nA privately built submarine that was feared missing in Danish waters has been found and the crew is safe, the Danish navy said Friday.\n\nThe 40-ton, nearly 18-meter-long (60-foot-long) submarine with at least two people on board was \"found sailing\" south of Copenhagen, the navy tweeted. It called off the search for the UC3 Nautilus submarine in the area from Copenhagen to the Baltic Sea island of Bornholm with two helicopters and three ships.\n\nNavy spokesman Christer Haven earlier had said members of the public with boats and sonar equipment were urged to take part in the search.\n\nIt wasn't immediately clear why the submarine crew failed to respond to radio contact.\n\nThe Danish navy says it is searching for a 40-ton, nearly 18-meter (60-foot) -long, privately built submarine in the waters off Copenhagen with at least two people on board.\n\nNavy spokesman Christer Haven says two helicopters and three ships are taking part in the search for the UC3 Nautilus submarine in the area from Copenhagen to the Baltic Sea island of Bornholm.\n\nHaven says members of the public with boats and sonar equipment have also been urged to take part in the search.\n\nHe said the search started after authorities got a call early Friday that the submarine had not returned to Copenhagen as planned. Owner Peter Madsen, who built the vessel that was launched in 2008, is believed to be on board along with a reporter.\n\nAn amateur-built submarine financed through crowdfunding sunk in Denmark's waters on Friday and the owner was found safe onboard, the Danish navy said. However, a Swedish journalist who had been on the vessel is reported missing.\n\nPeter Madsen, who built the UC3 Nautilus submarine that first was launched in 2008, was taken aboard a military ship, navy spokesman Anders Damgaard said. He declined to give further details.\n\nFootage aired on Denmark's TV2 channel showed the 46-year-old Madsen getting off what appeared to be a private boat and making a thumbs-up sign as he walked away.\n\n\"I am fine, but sad because Nautilus went down,\" he told Denmark's TV2 channel. Madsen said \"a minor problem with a ballast tank ... turned into a major issue\" that ultimately caused the vessel - considered the largest privately built submarine of its kind - to sink.\n\nSwedish police said they are investigating the whereabouts of a missing woman who had been on the submarine at some point.\n\n\"Whether the woman was on board the submarine at the time of her disappearance is unclear,\" police said in a statement.\n\nThe woman was a journalist writing about Madsen and his submarine, Swedish and Danish media reported.\n\n\"He told us that the journalist who also had been on board had been dropped off Thursday evening,\" Damgaard told The Associated Press. \"They were the only two on board yesterday.\"\n\nIt was the woman's boyfriend who alerted authorities the submarine was missing early Friday. Two helicopters and three ships combed the sea from Copenhagen to the Baltic Sea island of Bornholm.\n\nThe navy also encouraged members of the public with boats and sonar to search, too.\n\n\"It took about 30 seconds for Nautilus to sink, and I couldn't close any hatches or anything,\" Madsen said. \"But I guess that was pretty good because I otherwise still would have been down there.\"\n\nThe ballast tank is a compartment that holds water, which is used as ballast to provide stability for a vessel.\n\nThe navy initially said the sub was \"found sailing\" south of Copenhagen. But Damgaard later said the 40-ton, nearly 18-meter-long (60-foot-long) submarine had sunk.\n\nMadsen \"told us he had technical problems\" to explain why the submarine failed to respond to radio contact, Damgaard said.\n\nDanish media reported police sent divers down to the submarine. There were no official comments.\n\nCopyright 2017 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. This material may not be published, broadcast, rewritten or redistributed.", "time": "18:36:00"}

-- The Latest on a private submarine that sank off Denmark: (all times local):\n\n8:10 p.m.\n\nCopenhagen police say the owner of an amateur built submarine that sank in Denmark's water has been arrested on suspicion of murder in the disappearance of a Swedish journalist who had been a passenger on his vessel.\n\nPolice said in a statement Friday night that the man has denied killing the missing woman and said he dropped her off on an island on Thursday night.\n\nThe statement did not identify the owner, Peter Madsen, but he appeared on Danish television Friday to discuss the submarine's sinking.\n\nDeputy Police Inspector Jens Moller Jensen says investigators are looking for witnesses who may have seen the woman after the time Madsen reported she disembarked. She also was not identified by name.\n\nThe police statement says the submarine is lying in seven feet of water but divers have not been able to enter it safely yet.\n\nSwedish police are investigating the whereabouts of a missing woman who had been on a privately built submarine that sank off Denmark.\n\nSwedish and Danish media reported that the woman was a journalist who had been writing about the UC3 Nautilus' owner and builder, Peter Madsen.\n\nThe Danish navy rescued Madsen after launching a search for the submarine early Friday. He told authorities he had been alone on the vessel.\n\nNavy spokesman Anders Damgaard says Madsen \"told us that the journalist who also had been on board had been dropped off Thursday evening.\"\n\nIt was the woman's boyfriend who alerted authorities the submarine was missing early Friday.\n\nThe owner of a large, privately built submarine that sank south of Copenhagen says the vessel went down after a minor problem with a ballast tank turned into a major issue.\n\nPeter Madsen built the UC3 Nautilus and launched it in 2008. It was considered the largest privately submarine of its kind in the world.\n\nAfter being rescued by the Danish navy on Friday, the 46-year-old Madsen told Denmark's TV2 channel \"I am fine, but sad because Nautilus went down.\"\n\nThe ballast tank is a compartment that holds water, which is used as ballast to provide stability for a vessel.\n\nMadsen said that once the problem with the ballast tank started, \"It took about 30 seconds for Nautilus to sink and I couldn't close any hatches or anything.\"\n\nHe added: \"I guess that was pretty good because I otherwise still would have been down there.\"\n\nThe Danish navy says a crowdfunded, amateur-built submarine that was missing in Danish waters has sunk south of Copenhagen, but the owner and builder who was alone onboard is safe.\n\nThe navy initially said the 40-ton, nearly 18-meter-long (60-foot-long) UC3 Nautilus was \"found sailing\" south of Copenhagen on Friday. However, navy press spokesman Anders Damgaard later said it had sunk and owner Peter Madsen \"taken over to one of our ships.\"\n\nDamgaard declined to give details.\n\nFootage aired on Denmark's TV2 channel showed the 46-year-old Madsen, 46, getting off what looked to be a private boat and making a thumbs up sign as he walked away. It was not clear why the submarine sank.\n\nA privately built submarine that was feared missing in Danish waters has been found and the crew is safe, the Danish navy said Friday.\n\nThe 40-ton, nearly 18-meter-long (60-foot-long) submarine with at least two people on board was \"found sailing\" south of Copenhagen, the navy tweeted. It called off the search for the UC3 Nautilus submarine in the area from Copenhagen to the Baltic Sea island of Bornholm with two helicopters and three ships.\n\nNavy spokesman Christer Haven earlier had said members of the public with boats and sonar equipment were urged to take part in the search.\n\nIt wasn't immediately clear why the submarine crew failed to respond to radio contact.\n\nThe Danish navy says it is searching for a 40-ton, nearly 18-meter (60-foot) -long, privately built submarine in the waters off Copenhagen with at least two people on board.\n\nNavy spokesman Christer Haven says two helicopters and three ships are taking part in the search for the UC3 Nautilus submarine in the area from Copenhagen to the Baltic Sea island of Bornholm.\n\nHaven says members of the public with boats and sonar equipment have also been urged to take part in the search.\n\nHe said the search started after authorities got a call early Friday that the submarine had not returned to Copenhagen as planned. Owner Peter Madsen, who built the vessel that was launched in 2008, is believed to be on board along with a reporter.\n\nAn amateur-built submarine financed through crowdfunding sunk in Denmark's waters on Friday and the owner was found safe onboard, the Danish navy said. However, a Swedish journalist who had been on the vessel is reported missing.\n\nPeter Madsen, who built the UC3 Nautilus submarine that first was launched in 2008, was taken aboard a military ship, navy spokesman Anders Damgaard said. He declined to give further details.\n\nFootage aired on Denmark's TV2 channel showed the 46-year-old Madsen getting off what appeared to be a private boat and making a thumbs-up sign as he walked away.\n\n\"I am fine, but sad because Nautilus went down,\" he told Denmark's TV2 channel. Madsen said \"a minor problem with a ballast tank ... turned into a major issue\" that ultimately caused the vessel - considered the largest privately built submarine of its kind - to sink.\n\nSwedish police said they are investigating the whereabouts of a missing woman who had been on the submarine at some point.\n\n\"Whether the woman was on board the submarine at the time of her disappearance is unclear,\" police said in a statement.\n\nThe woman was a journalist writing about Madsen and his submarine, Swedish and Danish media reported.\n\n\"He told us that the journalist who also had been on board had been dropped off Thursday evening,\" Damgaard told The Associated Press. \"They were the only two on board yesterday.\"\n\nIt was the woman's boyfriend who alerted authorities the submarine was missing early Friday. Two helicopters and three ships combed the sea from Copenhagen to the Baltic Sea island of Bornholm.\n\nThe navy also encouraged members of the public with boats and sonar to search, too.\n\n\"It took about 30 seconds for Nautilus to sink, and I couldn't close any hatches or anything,\" Madsen said. \"But I guess that was pretty good because I otherwise still would have been down there.\"\n\nThe ballast tank is a compartment that holds water, which is used as ballast to provide stability for a vessel.\n\nThe navy initially said the sub was \"found sailing\" south of Copenhagen. But Damgaard later said the 40-ton, nearly 18-meter-long (60-foot-long) submarine had sunk.\n\nMadsen \"told us he had technical problems\" to explain why the submarine failed to respond to radio contact, Damgaard said.\n\nDanish media reported police sent divers down to the submarine. There were no official comments.", "time": "18:18:00"}

"type": "wiki", "id": "1438666"}], "url": "http://www.dailymail.co.uk/~/article-4782874/index.html", "body": "COPENHAGEN, Denmark (AP) - The Latest on a private submarine that sank off Denmark: (all times local):\n\n8:10 p.m.\n\nCopenhagen police say the owner of an amateur built submarine that sank in Denmark's water has been arrested on suspicion of murder in the disappearance of a Swedish journalist who had been a passenger on his vessel.\n\nFILE - This is a April 30 2008 file photo of submarine owner Peter Madsen . Denmark's navy says that Madsen's privately built submarine that had been feared missing in Danish waters has been found and the crew is safe. The navy says that the 40-ton, nearly 18-meter-long (60-foot-long) submarine with at least two people on board had been \"found sailing\" south of Copenhagen. (Niels Hougaard /Ritzau. File via AP)\n\nPolice said in a statement Friday night that the man has denied killing the missing woman and said he dropped her off on an island on Thursday night.\n\nThe statement did not identify the owner, Peter Madsen, but he appeared on Danish television Friday to discuss the submarine's sinking.\n\nDeputy Police Inspector Jens Moller Jensen says investigators are looking for witnesses who may have seen the woman after the time Madsen reported she disembarked. She also was not identified by name.\n\nThe police statement says the submarine is lying in seven feet of water but divers have not been able to enter it safely yet.\n\n___\n\n3:10 p.m.\n\nSwedish police are investigating the whereabouts of a missing woman who had been on a privately built submarine that sank off Denmark.\n\nSwedish and Danish media reported that the woman was a journalist who had been writing about the UC3 Nautilus' owner and builder, Peter Madsen.\n\nThe Danish navy rescued Madsen after launching a search for the submarine early Friday. He told authorities he had been alone on the vessel.\n\nNavy spokesman Anders Damgaard says Madsen \"told us that the journalist who also had been on board had been dropped off Thursday evening.\"\n\nIt was the woman's boyfriend who alerted authorities the submarine was missing early Friday.\n\n___\n\n1:35 p.m.\n\nThe owner of a large, privately built submarine that sank south of Copenhagen says the vessel went down after a minor problem with a ballast tank turned into a major issue.\n\nPeter Madsen built the UC3 Nautilus and launched it in 2008. It was considered the largest privately submarine of its kind in the world.\n\nAfter being rescued by the Danish navy on Friday, the 46-year-old Madsen told Denmark's TV2 channel \"I am fine, but sad because Nautilus went down.\"\n\nThe ballast tank is a compartment that holds water, which is used as ballast to provide stability for a vessel.\n\nMadsen said that once the problem with the ballast tank started, \"It took about 30 seconds for Nautilus to sink and I couldn't close any hatches or anything.\"\n\nHe added: \"I guess that was pretty good because I otherwise still would have been down there.\"\n\n___\n\n12:25 p.m.\n\nThe Danish navy says a crowdfunded, amateur-built submarine that was missing in Danish waters has sunk south of Copenhagen, but the owner and builder who was alone onboard is safe.\n\nThe navy initially said the 40-ton, nearly 18-meter-long (60-foot-long) UC3 Nautilus was \"found sailing\" south of Copenhagen on Friday. However, navy press spokesman Anders Damgaard later said it had sunk and owner Peter Madsen \"taken over to one of our ships.\"\n\nDamgaard declined to give details.\n\nFootage aired on Denmark's TV2 channel showed the 46-year-old Madsen, 46, getting off what looked to be a private boat and making a thumbs up sign as he walked away. It was not clear why the submarine sank.\n\n___\n\n11:15 a.m.\n\nA privately built submarine that was feared missing in Danish waters has been found and the crew is safe, the Danish navy said Friday.\n\nThe 40-ton, nearly 18-meter-long (60-foot-long) submarine with at least two people on board was \"found sailing\" south of Copenhagen, the navy tweeted. It called off the search for the UC3 Nautilus submarine in the area from Copenhagen to the Baltic Sea island of Bornholm with two helicopters and three ships.\n\nNavy spokesman Christer Haven earlier had said members of the public with boats and sonar equipment were urged to take part in the search.\n\nIt wasn't immediately clear why the submarine crew failed to respond to radio contact.\n\n___\n\n9:50 a.m.\n\nThe Danish navy says it is searching for a 40-ton, nearly 18-meter (60-foot) -long, privately built submarine in the waters off Copenhagen with at least two people on board.\n\nNavy spokesman Christer Haven says two helicopters and three ships are taking part in the search for the UC3 Nautilus submarine in the area from Copenhagen to the Baltic Sea island of Bornholm.\n\nHaven says members of the public with boats and sonar equipment have also been urged to take part in the search.\n\nHe said the search started after authorities got a call early Friday that the submarine had not returned to Copenhagen as planned. Owner Peter Madsen, who built the vessel that was launched in 2008, is believed to be on board along with a reporter.\n\nAn amateur-built submarine financed through crowdfunding sunk in Denmark's waters on Friday and the owner was found safe onboard, the Danish navy said. However, a Swedish journalist who had been on the vessel is reported missing.\n\nPeter Madsen, who built the UC3 Nautilus submarine that first was launched in 2008, was taken aboard a military ship, navy spokesman Anders Damgaard said. He declined to give further details.\n\nFootage aired on Denmark's TV2 channel showed the 46-year-old Madsen getting off what appeared to be a private boat and making a thumbs-up sign as he walked away.\n\n\"I am fine, but sad because Nautilus went down,\" he told Denmark's TV2 channel. Madsen said \"a minor problem with a ballast tank ... turned into a major issue\" that ultimately caused the vessel - considered the largest privately built submarine of its kind - to sink.\n\nSwedish police said they are investigating the whereabouts of a missing woman who had been on the submarine at some point.\n\n\"Whether the woman was on board the submarine at the time of her disappearance is unclear,\" police said in a statement.\n\nThe woman was a journalist writing about Madsen and his submarine, Swedish and Danish media reported.\n\n\"He told us that the journalist who also had been on board had been dropped off Thursday evening,\" Damgaard told The Associated Press. \"They were the only two on board yesterday.\"\n\nIt was the woman's boyfriend who alerted authorities the submarine was missing early Friday. Two helicopters and three ships combed the sea from Copenhagen to the Baltic Sea island of Bornholm.\n\nThe navy also encouraged members of the public with boats and sonar to search, too.\n\n\"It took about 30 seconds for Nautilus to sink, and I couldn't close any hatches or anything,\" Madsen said. \"But I guess that was pretty good because I otherwise still would have been down there.\"\n\nThe ballast tank is a compartment that holds water, which is used as ballast to provide stability for a vessel.\n\nThe navy initially said the sub was \"found sailing\" south of Copenhagen. But Damgaard later said the 40-ton, nearly 18-meter-long (60-foot-long) submarine had sunk.\n\nMadsen \"told us he had technical problems\" to explain why the submarine failed to respond to radio contact, Damgaard said.\n\nDanish media reported police sent divers down to the submarine. There were no official comments.\n\nFILE - This is a April 30 2008 file photo of submarine owner Peter Madsenstands inside the vessel . Denmark's navy says that Madsen's privately built submarine that had been feared missing in Danish waters has been found and the crew is safe. The navy says that the 40-ton, nearly 18-meter-long (60-foot-long) submarine with at least two people on board had been \"found sailing\" south of Copenhagen. (Niels Hougaard /Ritzau. It was considered the largest privately submarine of its kind in the world.\n\nAfter being rescued by the Danish navy on Friday, the 46-year-old Madsen told Denmark's TV2 channel \"I am fine, but sad because Nautilus went down.\"\n\nThe ballast tank is a compartment that holds water, which is used as ballast to provide stability for a vessel.\n\nMadsen said that once the problem with the ballast tank started, \"It took about 30 seconds for Nautilus to sink and I couldn't close any hatches or anything.\"\n\nHe added: \"I guess that was pretty good because I otherwise still would have been down there.\"\n\nThe Danish navy says a crowdfunded, amateur-built submarine that was missing in Danish waters has sunk south of Copenhagen, but the owner and builder who was alone onboard is safe.\n\nThe navy initially said the 40-ton, nearly 18-meter-long (60-foot-long) UC3 Nautilus was \"found sailing\" south of Copenhagen on Friday. "http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2017/08/11/sunken-submarine-owner-held-copenhagen-police-suspicion-murdering/", "body": "The owner of an amateur-built submarine was arrested on suspicion of murder Friday after his vessel sank in Denmark's waters and a journalist who had joined him for what was supposed to be a short voyage was reported missing, Copenhagen police said.\n\nPolice said in a statement Friday night that the man denied killing the missing woman and said he dropped her off on an island about 3 \u00bdhours into their Thursday night trip.\n\nThe statement did not identify the submarine's owner, Peter Madsen, 46, but his success financing his submarine project through crowdfunding and completing the UC3 Nautilus in 2008 made headlines.\n\nMadsen appeared on Danish television Friday to discuss the submarine's sinking and his rescue.\n\nFootage aired on Denmark's TV2 channel showed him getting off what appeared to be a private boat and making a thumbs-up sign as he walked away.\n\n\"I am fine, but sad because Nautilus went down,\" he told TV2.\n\nMadsen said \"a minor problem with a ballast tank ... turned into a major issue\" that ultimately caused the vessel - considered the largest privately built submarine of its kind - to sink.\n\nThe ballast tank is a compartment that holds water, which is used as ballast to provide stability for a vessel.\n\n\"It took about 30 seconds for Nautilus to sink, and I couldn't close any hatches or anything,\" Madsen said. \"But I guess that was pretty good because I otherwise still would have been down there.\"\n\nHowever, Swedish police said later in the day they were investigating the whereabouts of a missing woman who had been on the submarine at some point.\n\n\"Whether the woman was on board the submarine at the time of her disappearance is unclear,\" police said in a statement.\n\nThe woman was a journalist writing about Madsen and his submarine, Swedish and Danish media reported.\n\n\"He told us that the journalist who also had been on board had been dropped off Thursday evening,\" navy spokesman Anders Damgaard told The Associated Press. \"They were the only two on board yesterday.\"\n\nIt was the woman's boyfriend who alerted authorities the submarine was missing early Friday. Two helicopters and three ships combed the sea from Copenhagen to the Baltic Sea island of Bornholm.\n\nThe navy initially said the sub was \"found sailing\" south of Copenhagen. But Damgaard later said the 40-ton, nearly 18-meter-long (60-foot-long) submarine had sunk.\n\nMadsen \"told us he had technical problems\" to explain why the submarine failed to respond to radio contact, Damgaard said.", "time": "21:10:00"}

"http://www.staradvertiser.com/2017/08/11/breaking-news/private-submarine-sinks-danish-owner-held-on-suspicion-of-murder/", "body": "Submarine owner Peter Madsen, as seen in April 2008. Denmark's navy said that Madsen's privately-built submarine, which had been feared missing in Danish waters, has been found.\n\nCOPENHAGEN, Denmark >> The owner of an amateur-built submarine was arrested on suspicion of murder today after his vessel sank in Denmark's waters and a journalist who had joined him for what was supposed to be a short voyage was reported missing, Copenhagen police said.\n\nPolice said in a statement tonight that the man denied killing the missing woman and said he dropped her off on an island about 3 \u00bd hours into their Thursday night trip.\n\nThe statement did not identify the submarine's owner, Peter Madsen, 46, but his success financing his submarine project through crowdfunding and completing the UC3 Nautilus in 2008 made headlines.\n\nMadsen appeared on Danish television today to discuss the submarine's sinking and his rescue.\n\nFootage aired on Denmark's TV2 channel showed him getting off what appeared to be a private boat and making a thumbs-up sign as he walked away.\n\n\"I am fine, but sad because Nautilus went down,\" he told TV2.\n\nMadsen said \"a minor problem with a ballast tank ... turned into a major issue\" that ultimately caused the vessel -- considered the largest privately built submarine of its kind -- to sink.\n\nThe ballast tank is a compartment that holds water, which is used as ballast to provide stability for a vessel.\n\n\"It took about 30 seconds for Nautilus to sink, and I couldn't close any hatches or anything,\" Madsen said. \"But I guess that was pretty good because I otherwise still would have been down there.\"\n\nHowever, Swedish police said later in the day they were investigating the whereabouts of a missing woman who had been on the submarine at some point.\n\n\"Whether the woman was on board the submarine at the time of her disappearance is unclear,\" police said in a statement.\n\nThe woman was a journalist writing about Madsen and his submarine, Swedish and Danish media reported.\n\n\"He told us that the journalist who also had been on board had been dropped off Thursday evening,\" navy spokesman Anders Damgaard told The Associated Press. \"They were the only two on board yesterday.\"\n\nIt was the woman's boyfriend who alerted authorities the submarine was missing early today. Two helicopters and three ships combed the sea from Copenhagen to the Baltic Sea island of Bornholm.\n\nThe navy initially said the sub was \"found sailing\" south of Copenhagen. But Damgaard later said the 40-ton, nearly 60-foot-long submarine had sunk.\n\nMadsen \"told us he had technical problems\" to explain why the submarine failed to respond to radio contact, Damgaard said.", "time": "20:53:00"}

he walked away.\n\n\"I am fine, but sad because Nautilus went down,\" he told TV2.\n\nMadsen said \"a minor problem with a ballast tank ... turned into a major issue\" that ultimately caused the vessel -- considered the largest privately built submarine of its kind -- to sink.\n\nThe ballast tank is a compartment that holds water, which is used as ballast to provide stability for a vessel.\n\n\"It took about 30 seconds for Nautilus to sink, and I couldn't close any hatches or anything,\" Madsen said. \"But I guess that was pretty good because I otherwise still would have been down there.\"\n\nHowever, Swedish police said later in the day they were investigating the whereabouts of a missing woman who had been on the submarine at some point.\n\n\"Whether the woman was on board the submarine at the time of her disappearance is unclear,\" police said in a statement.\n\nThe woman was a journalist writing about Madsen and his submarine, Swedish and Danish media reported.\n\n\"He told us that the journalist who also had been on board had been dropped off Thursday evening,\" navy spokesman Anders Damgaard told The Associated Press. \"They were the only two on board yesterday.\"\n\nIt was the woman's boyfriend who alerted authorities the submarine was missing early Friday. Two helicopters and three ships combed the sea from Copenhagen to the Baltic Sea island of Bornholm.\n\nThe navy initially said the sub was \"found sailing\" south of Copenhagen. But Damgaard later said the 40-ton, nearly 18-meter-long (60-foot-long) submarine had sunk.\n\nMadsen \"told us he had technical problems\" to explain why the submarine failed to respond to radio contact, Damgaard said.", "time": "19:39:00"}

"https://www.iol.co.za/news/world/owner-held-on-suspicion-of-murder-after-submarine-sinks-10748824", "body": "Copenhagen, Denmark - The owner of an amateur-built submarine was arrested on suspicion of murder Friday after his vessel sank in Denmark's waters and a journalist who had joined him for what was supposed to be a short voyage was reported missing, Copenhagen police said.\n\nPolice said in a statement Friday night that the man denied killing the missing woman and said he dropped her off on an island about 3 \u00bd hours into their Thursday night trip.\n\nThe statement did not identify the submarine's owner, Peter Madsen, 46, but his success financing his submarine project through crowdfunding and completing the UC3 Nautilus in 2008 made headlines.\n\nMadsen appeared on Danish television Friday to discuss the submarine's sinking and his rescue.\n\nFootage aired on Denmark's TV2 channel showed him getting off what appeared to be a private boat and making a thumbs-up sign as he walked away.\n\n\"I am fine, but sad because Nautilus went down,\" he told TV2.\n\nMadsen said \"a minor problem with a ballast tank ... turned into a major issue\" that ultimately caused the vessel - considered the largest privately built submarine of its kind - to sink.\n\nThe ballast tank is a compartment that holds water, which is used as ballast to provide stability for a vessel.\n\n\"It took about 30 seconds for Nautilus to sink, and I couldn't close any hatches or anything,\" Madsen said. \"But I guess that was pretty good because I otherwise still would have been down there.\"\n\nHowever, Swedish police said later in the day they were investigating the whereabouts of a missing woman who had been on the submarine at some point.\n\n\"Whether the woman was on board the submarine at the time of her disappearance is unclear,\" police said in a statement.\n\nThe woman was a journalist writing about Madsen and his submarine, Swedish and Danish media reported.\n\n\"He told us that the journalist who also had been on board had been dropped off Thursday evening,\" navy spokesman Anders Damgaard told The Associated Press. \"They were the only two on board yesterday.\"\n\nIt was the woman's boyfriend who alerted authorities the submarine was missing early Friday. Two helicopters and three ships combed the sea from Copenhagen to the Baltic Sea island of Bornholm.\n\nThe navy initially said the sub was \"found sailing\" south of Copenhagen. But Damgaard later said the 40-ton, nearly 18-meter-long (60-foot-long) submarine had sunk.\n\nMadsen \"told us he had technical problems\" to explain why the submarine failed to respond to radio contact, Damgaard said.\n\nAssociated Press", "time": "19:25:00"}

"http://www.philstar.com/world/2017/08/12/1728147/private-sub-sinks-denmark-pilot-safe-passenger-missing", "body": "COPENHAGEN -- An amateur-built submarine financed through crowdfunding sunk in Denmark's waters on yesterday and the owner was found safe onboard, the Danish navy said. However, a Swedish journalist who had been on the vessel is reported missing.\n\nPeter Madsen, who built the UC3 Nautilus submarine that first was launched in 2008, was taken aboard a military ship, navy spokesman Anders Damgaard said. He declined to give further details.\n\nFootage aired on Denmark's TV2 channel showed the 46-year-old Madsen getting off what appeared to be a private boat and making a thumbs-up sign as he walked away.\n\n\"I am fine, but sad because Nautilus went down,\" he told Denmark's TV2 channel. Madsen said \"a minor problem with a ballast tank ... turned into a major issue\" that ultimately caused the vessel -- considered the largest privately built submarine of its kind -- to sink.\n\nSwedish police said they are investigating the whereabouts of a missing woman who had been on the submarine at some point.\n\n\"Whether the woman was on board the submarine at the time of her disappearance is unclear,\" police said in a statement.\n\nThe woman was a journalist writing about Madsen and his submarine, Swedish and Danish media reported.\n\n\"He told us that the journalist who also had been on board had been dropped off Thursday evening,\" Damgaard told The Associated Press. \"They were the only two on board yesterday.\"\n\nIt was the woman's boyfriend who alerted authorities the submarine was missing early yesterday. Two helicopters and three ships combed the sea from Copenhagen to the Baltic Sea island of Bornholm.\n\nThe navy also encouraged members of the public with boats and sonar to search, too.\n\n\"It took about 30 seconds for Nautilus to sink, and I couldn't close any hatches or anything,\" Madsen said. \"But I guess that was pretty good because I otherwise still would have been down there.\"\n\nThe ballast tank is a compartment that holds water, which is used as ballast to provide stability for a vessel.\n\nThe navy initially said the sub was \"found sailing\" south of Copenhagen. But Damgaard later said the 40-ton, nearly 18-meter-long (60-foot-long) submarine had sunk.\n\nMadsen \"told us he had technical problems\" to explain why the submarine failed to respond to radio contact, Damgaard said.\n\nDanish media reported police sent divers down to the submarine. There were no official comments.", "time": "23:20:00"}

was reported missing, Copenhagen police said.\n\nPolice said in a statement Friday night that the man denied killing the missing woman and said he dropped her off on an island about 3 \u00bd hours into their Thursday night trip.\n\nThe statement did not identify the submarine's owner, Peter Madsen, 46, but his success financing his submarine project through crowdfunding and completing the UC3 Nautilus in 2008 made headlines.\n\nMadsen appeared on Danish television Friday to discuss the submarine's sinking and his rescue.\n\nFootage aired on Denmark's TV2 channel showed him getting off what appeared to be a private boat and making a thumbs-up sign as he walked away.\n\n\"I am fine, but sad because Nautilus went down,\" he told TV2.\n\nMadsen said \"a minor problem with a ballast tank ... turned into a major issue\" that ultimately caused the vessel -- considered the largest privately built submarine of its kind -- to sink.\n\nThe ballast tank is a compartment that holds water, which is used as ballast to provide stability for a vessel.\n\n\"It took about 30 seconds for Nautilus to sink, and I couldn't close any hatches or anything,\" Madsen said. \"But I guess that was pretty good because I otherwise still would have been down there.\"\n\nHowever, Swedish police said later in the day they were investigating the whereabouts of a missing woman who had been on the submarine at some point.\n\n\"Whether the woman was on board the submarine at the time of her disappearance is unclear,\" police said in a statement.\n\nThe woman was a journalist writing about Madsen and his submarine, Swedish and Danish media reported.\n\n\"He told us that the journalist who also had been on board had been dropped off Thursday evening,\" navy spokesman Anders Damgaard told The Associated Press. \"They were the only two on board yesterday.\"\n\nIt was the woman's boyfriend who alerted authorities the submarine was missing early Friday. Two helicopters and three ships combed the sea from Copenhagen to the Baltic Sea island of Bornholm.\n\nThe navy initially said the sub was \"found sailing\" south of Copenhagen. But Damgaard later said the 40-ton, nearly 18-meter-long (60-foot-long) submarine had sunk.\n\nMadsen \"told us he had technical problems\" to explain why the submarine failed to respond to radio contact, Damgaard said.\n\n-- -- --\n\nLisa Leff contributed from London.\n\nSubscribe", "time": "19:08:00"}

"COPENHAGEN, Denmark (AP) - The owner of an amateur-built submarine was arrested on suspicion of murder Friday after his vessel sank in Denmark's waters and a journalist who had joined him for what was supposed to be a short voyage was reported missing, Copenhagen police said.\n\nPolice said in a statement Friday night that the man denied killing the missing woman and said he dropped her off on an island about 3 \u00bd hours into their Thursday night trip.\n\nThe statement did not identify the submarine's owner, Peter Madsen, 46, but his success financing his submarine project through crowdfunding and completing the UC3 Nautilus in 2008 made headlines.\n\nFILE - This is a April 30 2008 file photo of submarine owner Peter Madsen . Denmark's navy says that Madsen's privately built submarine that had been feared missing in Danish waters has been found and the crew is safe. The navy says that the 40-ton, nearly 18-meter-long (60-foot-long) submarine with at least two people on board had been \"found sailing\" south of Copenhagen. (Niels Hougaard /Ritzau. File via AP)\n\nMadsen appeared on Danish television Friday to discuss the submarine's sinking and his rescue.\n\nFootage aired on Denmark's TV2 channel showed him getting off what appeared to be a private boat and making a thumbs-up sign as he walked away.\n\n\"I am fine, but sad because Nautilus went down,\" he told TV2.\n\nMadsen said \"a minor problem with a ballast tank ... turned into a major issue\" that ultimately caused the vessel - considered the largest privately built submarine of its kind - to sink.\n\nThe ballast tank is a compartment that holds water, which is used as ballast to provide stability for a vessel.\n\n\"It took about 30 seconds for Nautilus to sink, and I couldn't close any hatches or anything,\" Madsen said. \"But I guess that was pretty good because I otherwise still would have been down there.\"\n\nHowever, Swedish police said later in the day they were investigating the whereabouts of a missing woman who had been on the submarine at some point.\n\n\"Whether the woman was on board the submarine at the time of her disappearance is unclear,\" police said in a statement.\n\nThe woman was a journalist writing about Madsen and his submarine, Swedish and Danish media reported.\n\n\"He told us that the journalist who also had been on board had been dropped off Thursday evening,\" navy spokesman Anders Damgaard told The Associated Press. \"They were the only two on board yesterday.\"\n\nIt was the woman's boyfriend who alerted authorities the submarine was missing early Friday. Two helicopters and three ships combed the sea from Copenhagen to the Baltic Sea island of Bornholm.\n\nThe navy initially said the sub was \"found sailing\" south of Copenhagen. But Damgaard later said the 40-ton, nearly 18-meter-long (60-foot-long) submarine had sunk.\n\nMadsen \"told us he had technical problems\" to explain why the submarine failed to respond to radio contact, Damgaard said.\n\n___\n\nLisa Leff contributed from London.\n\nFILE - This is a April 30 2008 file photo of submarine owner Peter Madsenstands inside the vessel . "http://www.wboc.com/story/36113491/private-submarine-sinks-owner-held-on-suspicion-of-murder", "body": "COPENHAGEN, Denmark (AP) - The owner of an amateur-built submarine was arrested on suspicion of murder Friday after his vessel sank in Denmark's waters and a journalist who had joined him for what was supposed to be a short voyage was reported missing, Copenhagen police said.\n\nPolice said in a statement Friday night that the man denied killing the missing woman and said he dropped her off on an island about 3 \u00bd hours into their Thursday night trip.\n\nThe statement did not identify the submarine's owner, Peter Madsen, 46, but his success financing his submarine project through crowdfunding and completing the UC3 Nautilus in 2008 made headlines.\n\nMadsen appeared on Danish television Friday to discuss the submarine's sinking and his rescue.\n\nFootage aired on Denmark's TV2 channel showed him getting off what appeared to be a private boat and making a thumbs-up sign as he walked away.\n\n\"I am fine, but sad because Nautilus went down,\" he told TV2.\n\nMadsen said \"a minor problem with a ballast tank ... turned into a major issue\" that ultimately caused the vessel - considered the largest privately built submarine of its kind - to sink.\n\nThe ballast tank is a compartment that holds water, which is used as ballast to provide stability for a vessel.\n\n\"It took about 30 seconds for Nautilus to sink, and I couldn't close any hatches or anything,\" Madsen said. \"But I guess that was pretty good because I otherwise still would have been down there.\"\n\nHowever, Swedish police said later in the day they were investigating the whereabouts of a missing woman who had been on the submarine at some point.\n\n\"Whether the woman was on board the submarine at the time of her disappearance is unclear,\" police said in a statement.\n\nThe woman was a journalist writing about Madsen and his submarine, Swedish and Danish media reported.\n\n\"He told us that the journalist who also had been on board had been dropped off Thursday evening,\" navy spokesman Anders Damgaard told The Associated Press. \"They were the only two on board yesterday.\"\n\nIt was the woman's boyfriend who alerted authorities the submarine was missing early Friday. Two helicopters and three ships combed the sea from Copenhagen to the Baltic Sea island of Bornholm.\n\nThe navy initially said the sub was \"found sailing\" south of Copenhagen. But Damgaard later said the 40-ton, nearly 18-meter-long (60-foot-long) submarine had sunk.\n\nMadsen \"told us he had technical problems\" to explain why the submarine failed to respond to radio contact, Damgaard said.\n\nCopyright 2017 The Associated Press. "http://hosted2.ap.org/CARIE/0260ea4c3e85456b80715585ba3c7b5b/Article_2017-08-11-EU--Denmark-Missing%20Submarine/id-e75f409eda4a41c281d3badaf39a1c01", "body": "COPENHAGEN, Denmark (AP) -- An amateur-built submarine financed through crowdfunding sunk in Denmark's waters on Friday and the owner was found safe onboard, the Danish navy said. However, a Swedish journalist who had been on the vessel is reported missing.\n\nPeter Madsen, who built the UC3 Nautilus submarine that first was launched in 2008, was taken aboard a military ship, navy spokesman Anders Damgaard said. He declined to give further details.\n\nFootage aired on Denmark's TV2 channel showed the 46-year-old Madsen getting off what appeared to be a private boat and making a thumbs-up sign as he walked away.\n\n\"I am fine, but sad because Nautilus went down,\" he told Denmark's TV2 channel. Madsen said \"a minor problem with a ballast tank ... turned into a major issue\" that ultimately caused the vessel -- considered the largest privately built submarine of its kind -- to sink.\n\nSwedish police said they are investigating the whereabouts of a missing woman who had been on the submarine at some point.\n\n\"Whether the woman was on board the submarine at the time of her disappearance is unclear,\" police said in a statement.\n\nThe woman was a journalist writing about Madsen and his submarine, Swedish and Danish media reported.\n\n\"He told us that the journalist who also had been on board had been dropped off Thursday evening,\" Damgaard told The Associated Press. \"They were the only two on board yesterday.\"\n\nIt was the woman's boyfriend who alerted authorities the submarine was missing early Friday. Two helicopters and three ships combed the sea from Copenhagen to the Baltic Sea island of Bornholm.\n\nThe navy also encouraged members of the public with boats and sonar to search, too.\n\n\"It took about 30 seconds for Nautilus to sink, and I couldn't close any hatches or anything,\" Madsen said. \"But I guess that was pretty good because I otherwise still would have been down there.\"\n\nThe ballast tank is a compartment that holds water, which is used as ballast to provide stability for a vessel.\n\nThe navy initially said the sub was \"found sailing\" south of Copenhagen. But Damgaard later said the 40-ton, nearly 18-meter-long (60-foot-long) submarine had sunk.\n\nMadsen \"told us he had technical problems\" to explain why the submarine failed to respond to radio contact, Damgaard said.\n\nDanish media reported police sent divers down to the submarine. There were no official comments.", "time": "13:11:00"}

"http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/UC3_Nautilus", "label": {"eng": "UC3 Nautilus"}, "score": 3, "type": "wiki", "id": "1438666"}], "url": "http://www.wboc.com/story/36113491/private-sub-sinks-in-denmark-pilot-safe-passenger-missing", "body": "COPENHAGEN, Denmark (AP) - An amateur-built submarine financed through crowdfunding sunk in Denmark's waters on Friday and the owner was found safe onboard, the Danish navy said. However, a Swedish journalist who had been on the vessel is reported missing.\n\nPeter Madsen, who built the UC3 Nautilus submarine that first was launched in 2008, was taken aboard a military ship, navy spokesman Anders Damgaard said. He declined to give further details.\n\nFootage aired on Denmark's TV2 channel showed the 46-year-old Madsen getting off what appeared to be a private boat and making a thumbs-up sign as he walked away.\n\n\"I am fine, but sad because Nautilus went down,\" he told Denmark's TV2 channel. Madsen said \"a minor problem with a ballast tank ... turned into a major issue\" that ultimately caused the vessel - considered the largest privately built submarine of its kind - to sink.\n\nSwedish police said they are investigating the whereabouts of a missing woman who had been on the submarine at some point.\n\n\"Whether the woman was on board the submarine at the time of her disappearance is unclear,\" police said in a statement.\n\nThe woman was a journalist writing about Madsen and his submarine, Swedish and Danish media reported.\n\n\"He told us that the journalist who also had been on board had been dropped off Thursday evening,\" Damgaard told The Associated Press. \"They were the only two on board yesterday.\"\n\nIt was the woman's boyfriend who alerted authorities the submarine was missing early Friday. Two helicopters and three ships combed the sea from Copenhagen to the Baltic Sea island of Bornholm.\n\nThe navy also encouraged members of the public with boats and sonar to search, too.\n\n\"It took about 30 seconds for Nautilus to sink, and I couldn't close any hatches or anything,\" Madsen said. \"But I guess that was pretty good because I otherwise still would have been down there.\"\n\nThe ballast tank is a compartment that holds water, which is used as ballast to provide stability for a vessel.\n\nThe navy initially said the sub was \"found sailing\" south of Copenhagen. But Damgaard later said the 40-ton, nearly 18-meter-long (60-foot-long) submarine had sunk.\n\nMadsen \"told us he had technical problems\" to explain why the submarine failed to respond to radio contact, Damgaard said.\n\nDanish media reported police sent divers down to the submarine. There were no official comments.\n\nCopyright 2017 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. This material may not be published, broadcast, rewritten or redistributed.", "time": "13:31:00"}

"http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Television_in_Denmark", "label": {"eng": "Television in Denmark"}, "score": 3, "type": "wiki", "id": "1009474"}], "url": "http://www.japantimes.co.jp/news/2017/08/12/world/danish-woman-missing-amateur-inventors-submarine-sinks/", "body": "COPENHAGEN - The owner of an amateur-built submarine was arrested on suspicion of murder Friday after his vessel sank off Denmark's coast and a journalist who had joined him for what was supposed to be a short voyage was reported missing, Copenhagen police said.\n\nPolice said in a statement Friday night that the man denied killing the missing woman and reported dropping her off on a redeveloped island in Copenhagen's harbor about 3\u00bd hours into their Thursday night trip.\n\nThe statement did not identify the submarine's owner, Peter Madsen, 46, but the Danish inventor's financing of the project through crowdfunding and first launch of the UC3 Nautilus in 2008 made headlines.\n\nThe 40-ton, nearly 18-meter-long (60-foot-long) vessel has been described as the largest privately built submarine of its kind.\n\nBefore his arrest, Madsen appeared on Danish television to discuss the submarine's sinking and his rescue. It was the journalist's boyfriend who alerted authorities early Friday that the sub had not returned from a test run, police said.\n\n\"I am fine, but sad because Nautilus went down,\" Madsen told Denmark's TV2 channel, which aired footage of him getting off what appeared to be a private boat and giving a thumbs-up sign.\n\nMadsen said \"a minor problem with a ballast tank\" -- a compartment that holds water to provide stability -- \"turned into a major issue\" that ultimately caused the submarine to sink.\n\n\"It took about 30 seconds for Nautilus to sink, and I couldn't close any hatches or anything,\" he said. \"But I guess that was pretty good, because I otherwise still would have been down there.\"\n\nSwedish police said later in the day they were investigating the whereabouts of a missing woman who had been on the submarine at some point.\n\n\"Whether the woman was on board the submarine at the time of her disappearance is unclear,\" police said in a statement.\n\nThe woman was a journalist writing about Madsen and his submarine, Swedish and Danish media reported.\n\n\"He told us that the journalist who also had been on board had been dropped off Thursday evening,\" Danish Navy spokesman Anders Damgaard said. \"They were the only two on board yesterday.\"\n\nCopenhagen Deputy Police Inspector Jens Moller Jensen says investigators are looking for witnesses who may have seen the woman after the time Madsen reported she disembarked. She also was not identified by name.\n\nThe police statement said the submerged submarine was lying in seven feet (about two meters) of water, but divers had not been able to enter it safely as of Friday night. They were hoping to tow it to port on Saturday and open it then, the statement said.\n\nMadsen describes himself as an \"inventrepaneur\" on the website for his Copenhagen-based company. RML Spacelab is seeking to send people into space and is developing a rocket, floating launch pad and astronaut testing machine among other projects, the site says.\n\n\"My passion is finding ways to travel to worlds beyond the well-known,\" Madsen wrote on the site. \"I design and manufacture non-commercial extreme machines, employing teams of volunteering engineers and technicians to challenge the ordinary. . . .\"\n\n\"The undersea world is close, it's beautiful, always just around the corner in Denmark. Diving, no matter the method, is very challenging and it's technically difficult to go to beyond where rubber suits and scuba gear can take us.\"\n\nThe Nautilus set out from Refshale Island, a former shipyard redeveloped as an entertainment and activity spot, at about 7 p.m. Thursday, according to a police timeline.\n\nTwo helicopters and three ships combed the sea from Copenhagen to the Baltic Sea island of Bornholm after police received a report it had not gotten back to land just after 3:30 a.m. It was spotted by a lighthouse in Koge Bay, a seaport south of the city, at 10:30 a.m.\n\n\"Radio contact was established for the boat, which, according to the owner, was heading toward the harbor,\" the police statement said. Half an hour later \"the submarine suddenly sank and the owner was subsequently rescued on a private motorboat sailing him in port.\"\n\nMadsen \"told us he had technical problems\" when asked to explain why the submarine failed to respond to radio contact earlier in the day, Damgaard said.", "time": "09:57:00"}

"http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ballast_tank", "label": {"eng": "Ballast tank"}, "score": 3, "type": "wiki", "id": "616014"}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Royal_Danish_Navy", "label": {"eng": "Royal Danish Navy"}, "score": 2, "type": "wiki", "id": "783667"}], "url": "http://www.scmp.com/news/world/europe/article/2106529/danish-inventor-held-murder-charge-after-home-made-sub-sinks-and", "body": "The owner of an amateur-built submarine was arrested on suspicion of murder on Friday after his vessel sank off Denmark's coast and a journalist who had joined him for what was supposed to be a short voyage was reported missing, Copenhagen police said.\n\nIn a statement on Friday night, police said the man denied killing the missing woman and reported dropping her off on a redeveloped island in Copenhagen's harbour about three and a half hours into their Thursday night trip.\n\nThe statement did not identify the submarine's owner, Peter Madsen, 46, but the Danish inventor's financing of the project through crowdfunding and first launch of the UC3 Nautilus in 2008 made headlines.\n\nThe 40-tonne, nearly 18-metre-long vessel has been described as the largest privately built submarine of its kind.\n\nBefore his arrest, Madsen appeared on Danish television to discuss the submarine's sinking and his rescue. It was the journalist's boyfriend who alerted authorities early on Friday that the sub had not returned from a test run, police said.\n\n\"I am fine, but sad because Nautilus went down,\" Madsen told Denmark's TV2 channel, which aired footage of him getting off what appeared to be a private boat and giving a thumbs-up sign.\n\nMadsen said \"a minor problem with a ballast tank\" - a compartment that holds water to provide stability - \"turned into a major issue\" that ultimately caused the submarine to sink.\n\n\"It took about 30 seconds for Nautilus to sink, and I couldn't close any hatches or anything,\" he said. \"But I guess that was pretty good, because I otherwise still would have been down there.\"\n\nSwedish police said later in the day they were investigating the whereabouts of a missing woman who had been on the submarine at some point.\n\n\"Whether the woman was on board the submarine at the time of her disappearance is unclear,\" police said in a statement.\n\nThe woman was a journalist writing about Madsen and his submarine, Swedish and Danish media reported.\n\n\"He told us that the journalist who also had been on board had been dropped off Thursday evening,\" Danish navy spokesman Anders Damgaard said. \"They were the only two on board yesterday.\"\n\nCopenhagen Deputy Police Inspector Jens Moller Jensen says investigators are looking for witnesses who may have seen the woman after the time Madsen said she disembarked. She was also not identified by name.\n\nThe police statement said the submerged submarine was lying in two metres of water, but divers had not been able to enter it safely on Friday night. They were hoping to tow it to port on Saturday and open it then, the statement said.\n\nMadsen describes himself as an \"inventrepaneur\" on the website for his Copenhagen-based company. RML Spacelab is seeking to send people into space and is developing a rocket, floating launch pad and astronaut testing machine among other projects, the site says.\n\n\"My passion is finding ways to travel to worlds beyond the well-known,\" Madsen wrote on the site. \"I design and manufacture non-commercial extreme machines, employing teams of volunteering engineers and technicians to challenge the ordinary ... The undersea world is close, it's beautiful, always just around the corner in Denmark. Diving, no matter the method, is very challenging and it*s technically difficult to go to beyond where rubber suits and scuba gear can take us.\"\n\nThe Nautilus set out from Refshale Island, a former shipyard redeveloped as an entertainment and activity spot, at about 7pm local time on Thursday, according to a police timeline.\n\nTwo helicopters and three ships combed the sea from Copenhagen to the Baltic Sea island of Bornholm after police received a report that it had not returned to land just after 3.30am. It was spotted by a lighthouse in Koge Bay, a seaport south of the city, at 10.30am.\n\n\"A radio contact was established for the boat, which, according to the owner, was heading towards the harbour,\" the police statement said. Half an hour later \"the submarine suddenly sank and the owner was subsequently rescued on a private motorboat sailing him in port\".\n\nMadsen \"told us he had technical problems\" when asked to explain why the submarine failed to respond to radio contact earlier in the day, Damgaard said.", "time": "04:43:00"}

It was not clear why the submarine sank.\n\n\"He told us that the journalist who also had been on board had been dropped off Thursday evening,\" Damgaard told The Associated Press. "score": 2, "type": "wiki", "id": "977034"}], "url": "http://www.sacbee.com/news/nation-world/world/article166643712.html", "body": "The owner of an amateur-built submarine was arrested on suspicion of murder Friday after his vessel sank off Denmark's coast and a journalist who had joined him for what was supposed to be a short voyage was reported missing, Copenhagen police said.\n\nPolice said in a statement Friday night that the man denied killing the missing woman and reported dropping her off on a redeveloped island in Copenhagen's harbor about 3 \u00bd hours into their Thursday night trip.\n\nThe statement did not identify the submarine's owner, Peter Madsen, 46, but the Danish inventor's financing of the project through crowdfunding and first launch of the UC3 Nautilus in 2008 made headlines.\n\nThe 40-ton, nearly 18-meter-long (60-foot-long) vessel has been described as the largest privately built submarine of its kind.\n\nBefore his arrest, Madsen appeared on Danish television to discuss the submarine's sinking and his rescue. It was the journalist's boyfriend who alerted authorities early Friday that the sub had not returned from a test run, police said.\n\n\"I am fine, but sad because Nautilus went down,\" Madsen told Denmark's TV2 channel, which aired footage of him getting off what appeared to be a private boat and giving a thumbs-up sign.\n\nMadsen said \"a minor problem with a ballast tank\" -- a compartment that holds water to provide stability -- \"turned into a major issue\" that ultimately caused the submarine to sink.\n\n\"It took about 30 seconds for Nautilus to sink, and I couldn't close any hatches or anything,\" he said. \"But I guess that was pretty good, because I otherwise still would have been down there.\"\n\nSwedish police said later in the day they were investigating the whereabouts of a missing woman who had been on the submarine at some point.\n\n\"Whether the woman was on board the submarine at the time of her disappearance is unclear,\" police said in a statement.\n\nThe woman was a journalist writing about Madsen and his submarine, Swedish and Danish media reported.\n\n\"He told us that the journalist who also had been on board had been dropped off Thursday evening,\" Danish navy spokesman Anders Damgaard told The Associated Press. \"They were the only two on board yesterday.\"\n\nCopenhagen Deputy Police Inspector Jens Moller Jensen says investigators are looking for witnesses who may have seen the woman after the time Madsen reported she disembarked. She also was not identified by name.\n\nThe police statement said the submerged submarine was lying in seven feet of water, but divers had not been able to enter it safely as of Friday night. They were hoping to tow it to port on Saturday and open it then, the statement said.\n\nMadsen describes himself as an \"inventrepaneur\" on the website for his Copenhagen-based company. RML Spacelab is seeking to send people into space and is developing a rocket, floating launch pad and astronaut testing machine among other projects, the site says.\n\n\"My passion is finding ways to travel to worlds beyond the well-known,\" Madsen wrote on the site. \"I design and manufacture non-commercial extreme machines, employing teams of volunteering engineers and technicians to challenge the ordinary....\"\n\n\"The undersea world is close, it's beautiful, always just around the corner in Denmark. Diving, no matter the method, is very challenging and it*s technically difficult to go to beyond where rubber suits and scuba gear can take us.\"\n\nThe Nautilus set out from Refshale Island, a former shipyard redeveloped as an entertainment and activity spot, at about 7 p.m. local time on Thursday, according to a police timeline.\n\nTwo helicopters and three ships combed the sea from Copenhagen to the Baltic Sea island of Bornholm after police received the report it had not gotten back to land just after 3:30 a.m. It was spotted by a lighthouse in Koge Bay, a seaport south of the city, at 10:30 a.m.\n\n\"A radio contact was established for the boat, which, according to the owner, was heading towards the harbor,\" the police statement said. Half an hour later \"the submarine suddenly sank and the owner was subsequently rescued on a private motorboat sailing him in port.\"\n\nMadsen \"told us he had technical problems\" when asked to explain why the submarine failed to respond to radio contact earlier in the day, Damgaard said.", "time": "23:44:00"}
