"http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kim_Wall_(British_actor)", "label": {"eng": "Kim Wall (British actor)"}, "score": 5, "type": "wiki", "id": "1438956"}], "url": "http://www.theguardian.com/global/2017/aug/13/submarine-maker-held-as-search-for-kim-wall-continues", "body": "Inventor Peter Madsen is alleged to have deliberately sunk vessel missing Kim Wall had been aboard off coast of Denmark\n\nAn amateur submarine maker is in custody in Copenhagen as police investigate the disappearance of a Swedish journalist who had been onboard his vessel before he is alleged to have deliberately sunk it off Denmark's east coast.\n\nPeter Madsen, a Danish inventor whose crowdfunded submarine Nautilus sank near Copenhagen on Friday, was arrested on preliminary manslaughter charges but has denied responsibility for the fate of 30-year-old Kim Wall.\n\nHe claims she disembarked on an island about three-and-a-half hours into their trip on Thursday night, according to Copenhagen police.\n\nPolice spokesman Jens M\u00f8ller Jensen said on Sunday that the submarine had been raised from the sea bed and searched but no body had been discovered. The search for Wall in the water, from the air and on land, continues.\n\nM\u00f8ller Jensen added that there were indications that Madsen deliberately sank his submarine.\n\nOn Saturday, after a two-hour custody hearing held in private, Judge Kari S\u00f8rensen ordered that Madsen be held in pre-trial detention for 24 days while the investigation into Wall's disappearance continued.\n\nProsecutor Louise Pedersen said Madsen faced a preliminary manslaughter charge \"for having killed in an unknown way and in an unknown place Kim Isabell Frerika Wall of Sweden sometime after Thursday 5pm\".\n\nMadsen's defence lawyer, Betina Hald Engmark, said her client maintains his innocence. He is \"willing to cooperate\" and hasn't decided whether to appeal the detention ruling, Hald Engmark said.\n\nWall, a freelance journalist, had been writing about Madsen and his submarine at the time of disappearing, according to Swedish and Danish reports.\n\n\"It is with great dismay that we received the news that Kim went missing during an assignment in Denmark,\" her family said.\n\nShe lives between New York and Beijing, the family said, and has written for titles including the Guardian, New York Times, South China Morning Post and Vice. Her LinkedIn page says she writes about \"identity, gender, pop-culture, social justice, foreign policy and the undercurrents of rebellion\".\n\nMadsen made headlines when he successfully financed the building of the 40-tonne, 18-metre Nautilus through crowdfunding, completing it in 2008.\n\nHe appeared on Danish television on Friday to discuss the submarine's sinking and his rescue. Footage aired on Denmark's TV2 channel showed him getting off what appeared to be a private boat and making a thumbs-up sign as he walked away. \"I am fine, but sad because Nautilus went down,\" he told TV2.\n\nMadsen said \"a minor problem with a ballast tank ... turned into a major issue\" that ultimately caused the sinking of the vessel, considered to be the largest privately-built submarine of its kind. The ballast tank is a compartment that holds water to provide stability.\n\n\"It took about 30 seconds for Nautilus to sink, and I couldn't close any hatches or anything,\" Madsen said. \"But I guess that was pretty good because I otherwise still would have been down there.\"\n\nSwedish police said later in the day that they were investigating the whereabouts of Wall, who they said had been on the submarine at some point. \"Whether the woman was on board the submarine at the time of her disappearance is unclear,\" police said.\n\nA navy spokesman, Anders Damgaard, said: \"He told us that the journalist who also had been on board had been dropped off on Thursday evening. They were the only two on board yesterday.\"\n\nAuthorities were alerted to issues with the voyage when Wall's boyfriend reported her missing early on Friday. Two helicopters and three ships searched the sea from Copenhagen to the Baltic Sea island of Bornholm.\n\nThe navy initially said the craft was \"found sailing\" south of Copenhagen. But Damgaard later said the 40 tonne submarine had sunk.\n\nKristian Isbak, who had responded to the navy's call to help locate the ship, sailed out immediately Friday and saw Madsen standing wearing his trademark military fatigues in the submarine's tower while it was still afloat.\n\n\"He then climbed down inside the submarine and there was then some kind of air flow coming up and the submarine started to sink,\" Isbak said. \"[He] came up again and stayed in the tower until water came into it\", before swimming to a nearby boat as the submarine sank, he added.\n\nMadsen \"told us he had technical problems\" to explain why the submarine failed to respond to radio contact, Damgaard said.", "time": "12:53:00"}

"814158"}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Refshale\u00f8en,_Copenhagen", "label": {"eng": "Refshale\u00f8en, Copenhagen"}, "score": 2, "type": "wiki", "id": "977034"}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Television_in_Denmark", "label": {"eng": "Television in Denmark"}, "score": 3, "type": "wiki", "id": "1009474"}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_islands_in_the_Baltic_Sea", "label": {"eng": "List of islands in the Baltic Sea"}, "score": 1, "type": "wiki", "id": "1238823"}], "url": "http://thegardenisland.com/news/world/amateur-danish-sub-sinks-inventor-held-on-murder-charge/article_acf45c8a-323d-5eae-b312-395462ff9f01.html", "body": "The statement did not identify the submarine's owner, Peter Madsen, 46, but the Danish inventor's financing of the project through crowdfunding and first launch of the UC3 Nautilus in 2008 made headlines.\n\nThe 40-ton, nearly 18-meter-long (60-foot-long) vessel has been described as the largest privately built submarine of its kind.\n\nBefore his arrest, Madsen appeared on Danish television to discuss the submarine's sinking and his rescue. It was the journalist's boyfriend who alerted authorities early Friday that the sub had not returned from a test run, police said.\n\n\"I am fine, but sad because Nautilus went down,\" Madsen told Denmark's TV2 channel, which aired footage of him getting off what appeared to be a private boat and giving a thumbs-up sign.\n\nMadsen said \"a minor problem with a ballast tank\" -- a compartment that holds water to provide stability -- \"turned into a major issue\" that ultimately caused the submarine to sink.\n\n\"It took about 30 seconds for Nautilus to sink, and I couldn't close any hatches or anything,\" he said. \"But I guess that was pretty good, because I otherwise still would have been down there.\"\n\nSwedish police said later in the day they were investigating the whereabouts of a missing woman who had been on the submarine at some point.\n\n\"Whether the woman was on board the submarine at the time of her disappearance is unclear,\" police said in a statement.\n\nThe woman was a journalist writing about Madsen and his submarine, Swedish and Danish media reported.\n\n\"He told us that the journalist who also had been on board had been dropped off Thursday evening,\" Danish navy spokesman Anders Damgaard told The Associated Press. \"They were the only two on board yesterday.\"\n\nCopenhagen Deputy Police Inspector Jens Moller Jensen says investigators are looking for witnesses who may have seen the woman after the time Madsen reported she disembarked. She also was not identified by name.\n\nThe police statement said the submerged submarine was lying in seven feet of water, but divers had not been able to enter it safely as of Friday night. They were hoping to tow it to port on Saturday and open it then, the statement said.\n\nMadsen describes himself as an \"inventrepaneur\" on the website for his Copenhagen-based company. RML Spacelab is seeking to send people into space and is developing a rocket, floating launch pad and astronaut testing machine among other projects, the site says.\n\n\"My passion is finding ways to travel to worlds beyond the well-known,\" Madsen wrote on the site. \"I design and manufacture non-commercial extreme machines, employing teams of volunteering engineers and technicians to challenge the ordinary....\"\n\n\"The undersea world is close, it's beautiful, always just around the corner in Denmark. Diving, no matter the method, is very challenging and it*s technically difficult to go to beyond where rubber suits and scuba gear can take us.\"\n\nThe Nautilus set out from Refshale Island, a former shipyard redeveloped as an entertainment and activity spot, at about 7 p.m. local time on Thursday, according to a police timeline.\n\nTwo helicopters and three ships combed the sea from Copenhagen to the Baltic Sea island of Bornholm after police received the report it had not gotten back to land just after 3:30 a.m. It was spotted by a lighthouse in Koge Bay, a seaport south of the city, at 10:30 a.m.\n\n\"A radio contact was established for the boat, which, according to the owner, was heading towards the harbor,\" the police statement said. Half an hour later \"the submarine suddenly sank and the owner was subsequently rescued on a private motorboat sailing him in port.\"\n\nMadsen \"told us he had technical problems\" when asked to explain why the submarine failed to respond to radio contact earlier in the day, Damgaard said.", "time": "06:55:00"}

"http://www.wmcactionnews5.com/story/36113491/private-submarine-sinks-in-denmark-crew-safe", "body": "COPENHAGEN, Denmark (AP) - A crowdfunded, amateur-built submarine that was missing in Danish waters has sunk south of Copenhagen, but the owner and builder who was alone onboard is safe, the Danish navy said Friday.\n\nInitially the navy said the 40-ton, nearly 18-meter-long (60-foot-long) UC3 Nautilus was \"found sailing\" south of Copenhagen. However, navy press spokesman Anders Damgaard later said it had sunk and Peter Madsen, who built the vessel that was launched in 2008, had \"been taken over to one of our ships.\" He declined to give details.\n\nFootage aired on Denmark's TV2 channel showed Madsen, 46, getting off what seemed to be a private boat and making a thumbs up sign as he walked away. It was not clear why the submarine sank.\n\n\"He told us that the journalist who also had been on board had been dropped off Thursday evening,\" Damgaard told The Associated Press. Swedish media said the reporter was Swedish. \"They were the only two on board yesterday.\"\n\nAfter the submarine was reported missing early Friday, the navy had launched a search from Copenhagen to the Baltic Sea island of Bornholm with two helicopters and three ships, and encouraged members of the public with boats and sonar to search, too\n\n\"He told us he had technical problems\" to explain why the submarine failed to respond to radio contact, Damgaard said.\n\nCopyright 2017 The Associated Press. "http://www.mcall.com/news/nationworld/ct-denmark-submarine-murder-charge-20170811-story.html", "body": "The owner of an amateur-built submarine was arrested on suspicion of murder Friday after his vessel sank off Denmark's coast and a journalist who had joined him for what was supposed to be a short voyage was reported missing, Copenhagen police said.\n\nPolice said in a statement Friday night that the man denied killing the missing woman and reported dropping her off on a redeveloped island in Copenhagen's harbor about 3 \u00bd hours into their Thursday night trip.\n\nThe statement did not identify the submarine's owner, Peter Madsen, 46, but the Danish inventor's financing of the project through crowdfunding and first launch of the UC3 Nautilus in 2008 made headlines.\n\nThe 40-ton, nearly 18-meter-long (60-foot-long) vessel has been described as the largest privately built submarine of its kind.\n\nBefore his arrest, Madsen appeared on Danish television to discuss the submarine's sinking and his rescue. It was the journalist's boyfriend who alerted authorities early Friday that the sub had not returned from a test run, police said.\n\n\"I am fine, but sad because Nautilus went down,\" Madsen told Denmark's TV2 channel, which aired footage of him getting off what appeared to be a private boat and giving a thumbs-up sign.\n\nMadsen said \"a minor problem with a ballast tank\" -- a compartment that holds water to provide stability -- \"turned into a major issue\" that ultimately caused the submarine to sink.\n\n\"It took about 30 seconds for Nautilus to sink, and I couldn't close any hatches or anything,\" he said. \"But I guess that was pretty good, because I otherwise still would have been down there.\"\n\nSwedish police said later in the day they were investigating the whereabouts of a missing woman who had been on the submarine at some point.\n\n\"Whether the woman was on board the submarine at the time of her disappearance is unclear,\" police said in a statement.\n\nThe woman was a journalist writing about Madsen and his submarine, Swedish and Danish media reported.\n\n\"He told us that the journalist who also had been on board had been dropped off Thursday evening,\" Danish navy spokesman Anders Damgaard told The Associated Press. \"They were the only two on board yesterday.\"\n\nCopenhagen Deputy Police Inspector Jens Moller Jensen says investigators are looking for witnesses who may have seen the woman after the time Madsen reported she disembarked. She also was not identified by name.\n\nThe police statement said the submerged submarine was lying in seven feet of water, but divers had not been able to enter it safely as of Friday night. They were hoping to tow it to port on Saturday and open it then, the statement said.\n\nMadsen describes himself as an \"inventrepaneur\" on the website for his Copenhagen-based company. RML Spacelab is seeking to send people into space and is developing a rocket, floating launch pad and astronaut testing machine among other projects, the site says.\n\n\"My passion is finding ways to travel to worlds beyond the well-known,\" Madsen wrote on the site. \"I design and manufacture non-commercial extreme machines, employing teams of volunteering engineers and technicians to challenge the ordinary....\"\n\n\"The undersea world is close, it's beautiful, always just around the corner in Denmark. Diving, no matter the method, is very challenging and it's technically difficult to go to beyond where rubber suits and scuba gear can take us.\"\n\nThe Nautilus set out from Refshale Island, a former shipyard redeveloped as an entertainment and activity spot, at about 7 p.m. local time on Thursday, according to a police timeline.\n\nTwo helicopters and three ships combed the sea from Copenhagen to the Baltic Sea island of Bornholm after police received the report it had not gotten back to land just after 3:30 a.m. It was spotted by a lighthouse in Koge Bay, a seaport south of the city, at 10:30 a.m.\n\n\"A radio contact was established for the boat, which, according to the owner, was heading towards the harbor,\" the police statement said. Half an hour later \"the submarine suddenly sank and the owner was subsequently rescued on a private motorboat sailing him in port.\"\n\nMadsen \"told us he had technical problems\" when asked to explain why the submarine failed to respond to radio contact earlier in the day, Damgaard said.\n\nLisa Leff contributed from London.", "time": "23:28:00"}

tank"}, "score": 3, "type": "wiki", "id": "616014"}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Royal_Danish_Navy", "label": {"eng": "Royal Danish Navy"}, "score": 2, "type": "wiki", "id": "783667"}, "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Refshale\u00f8en,_Copenhagen", "label": {"eng": "Refshale\u00f8en, Copenhagen"}, "score": 2, "type": "wiki", "id": "977034"}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Television_in_Denmark", "label": {"eng": "Television in Denmark"}, "score": 3, "type": "wiki", "id": "1009474"}], "url": "http://www.dothaneagle.com/news/ap/world/amateur-danish-sub-sinks-inventor-held-on-murder-charge/article_0885cdfb-7640-5125-9076-bb2c5af267ab.html", "body": "COPENHAGEN, Denmark (AP) -- The owner of an amateur-built submarine was arrested on suspicion of murder Friday after his vessel sank off Denmark's coast and a journalist who had joined him for what was supposed to be a short voyage was reported missing, Copenhagen police said.\n\nPolice said in a statement Friday night that the man denied killing the missing woman and reported dropping her off on a redeveloped island in Copenhagen's harbor about 3 \u00bd hours into their Thursday night trip.\n\nThe statement did not identify the submarine's owner, Peter Madsen, 46, but the Danish inventor's financing of the project through crowdfunding and first launch of the UC3 Nautilus in 2008 made headlines.\n\nThe 40-ton, nearly 18-meter-long (60-foot-long) vessel has been described as the largest privately built submarine of its kind.\n\nBefore his arrest, Madsen appeared on Danish television to discuss the submarine's sinking and his rescue. It was the journalist's boyfriend who alerted authorities early Friday that the sub had not returned from a test run, police said.\n\n\"I am fine, but sad because Nautilus went down,\" Madsen told Denmark's TV2 channel, which aired footage of him getting off what appeared to be a private boat and giving a thumbs-up sign.\n\nMadsen said \"a minor problem with a ballast tank\" -- a compartment that holds water to provide stability -- \"turned into a major issue\" that ultimately caused the submarine to sink.\n\n\"It took about 30 seconds for Nautilus to sink, and I couldn't close any hatches or anything,\" he said. \"But I guess that was pretty good, because I otherwise still would have been down there.\"\n\nSwedish police said later in the day they were investigating the whereabouts of a missing woman who had been on the submarine at some point.\n\n\"Whether the woman was on board the submarine at the time of her disappearance is unclear,\" police said in a statement.\n\nThe woman was a journalist writing about Madsen and his submarine, Swedish and Danish media reported.\n\n\"He told us that the journalist who also had been on board had been dropped off Thursday evening,\" Danish navy spokesman Anders Damgaard told The Associated Press. \"They were the only two on board yesterday.\"\n\nCopenhagen Deputy Police Inspector Jens Moller Jensen says investigators are looking for witnesses who may have seen the woman after the time Madsen reported she disembarked. She also was not identified by name.\n\nThe police statement said the submerged submarine was lying in seven feet of water, but divers had not been able to enter it safely as of Friday night. They were hoping to tow it to port on Saturday and open it then, the statement said.\n\nMadsen describes himself as an \"inventrepaneur\" on the website for his Copenhagen-based company. RML Spacelab is seeking to send people into space and is developing a rocket, floating launch pad and astronaut testing machine among other projects, the site says.\n\n\"My passion is finding ways to travel to worlds beyond the well-known,\" Madsen wrote on the site. \"I design and manufacture non-commercial extreme machines, employing teams of volunteering engineers and technicians to challenge the ordinary....\"\n\n\"The undersea world is close, it's beautiful, always just around the corner in Denmark. Diving, no matter the method, is very challenging and it*s technically difficult to go to beyond where rubber suits and scuba gear can take us.\"\n\nThe Nautilus set out from Refshale Island, a former shipyard redeveloped as an entertainment and activity spot, at about 7 p.m. local time on Thursday, according to a police timeline.\n\nTwo helicopters and three ships combed the sea from Copenhagen to the Baltic Sea island of Bornholm after police received the report it had not gotten back to land just after 3:30 a.m. It was spotted by a lighthouse in Koge Bay, a seaport south of the city, at 10:30 a.m.\n\n\"A radio contact was established for the boat, which, according to the owner, was heading towards the harbor,\" the police statement said. Half an hour later \"the submarine suddenly sank and the owner was subsequently rescued on a private motorboat sailing him in port.\"\n\nMadsen \"told us he had technical problems\" when asked to explain why the submarine failed to respond to radio contact earlier in the day, Damgaard said.\n\n-- -- --\n\nLisa Leff contributed from London.", "time": "22:39:00"}

"http://www.rep-am.com/news/world/2017/08/11/danish-police-suspect-woman-on-sunken-sub/", "body": "COPENHAGEN, Denmark - The owner of an amateur-built submarine was arrested on suspicion of murder Friday after his vessel sank off Denmark's coast and a journalist who had joined him for what was supposed to be a short voyage was reported missing, Copenhagen police said.\n\nPolice said in a statement Friday night that the man denied killing the missing woman and reported dropping her off on a redeveloped island in Copenhagen's harbor about 3 \u00bd hours into their Thursday night trip.\n\nThe statement did not identify the submarine's owner, Peter Madsen, 46, but the Danish inventor's financing of the project through crowdfunding and first launch of the UC3 Nautilus in 2008 made headlines.\n\nThe 40-ton, nearly 60-foot-long vessel has been described as the largest privately built submarine of its kind.\n\nBefore his arrest, Madsen appeared on Danish television to discuss the submarine's sinking and his rescue. It was the journalist's boyfriend who alerted authorities early Friday that the sub had not returned from a test run, police said.\n\n\"I am fine, but sad because Nautilus went down,\" Madsen told Denmark's TV2 channel, which aired footage of him getting off what appeared to be a private boat and giving a thumbs-up sign.\n\nSwedish police said later in the day they were investigating the whereabouts of a missing woman who had been on the submarine at some point.\n\n\"Whether the woman was on board the submarine at the time of her disappearance is unclear,\" police said in a statement.\n\nThe woman was a journalist writing about Madsen and his submarine, Swedish and Danish media reported.\n\n\"He told us that the journalist who also had been on board had been dropped off Thursday evening,\" Danish navy spokesman Anders Damgaard saids. \"They were the only two on board yesterday.\"\n\nCopenhagen Deputy Police Inspector Jens Moller Jensen says investigators are looking for witnesses who may have seen the woman after the time Madsen reported she disembarked. She also was not identified by name.\n\nThe police statement said the submerged submarine was lying in seven feet of water, but divers had not been able to enter it safely as of Friday night. They were hoping to tow it to port on Saturday and open it then, the statement said.\n\nMadsen describes himself as an \"inventrepaneur\" on the website for his Copenhagen-based company. RML Spacelab is seeking to send people into space and is developing a rocket, floating launch pad and astronaut testing machine among other projects, the site says.\n\n\"My passion is finding ways to travel to worlds beyond the well-known,\" Madsen wrote on the site. \"I design and manufacture non-commercial extreme machines, employing teams of volunteering engineers and technicians to challenge the ordinary....\"\n\n\"The undersea world is close, it's beautiful, always just around the corner in Denmark. Diving, no matter the method, is very challenging and it s technically difficult to go to beyond where rubber suits and scuba gear can take us.\"\n\nThe Nautilus set out from Refshale Island, a former shipyard redeveloped as an entertainment and activity spot, at about 7 p.m. local time on Thursday, according to a police timeline.\n\nTwo helicopters and three ships combed the sea from Copenhagen to the Baltic Sea island of Bornholm after police received the report it had not gotten back to land just after 3:30 a.m. It was spotted by a lighthouse in Koge Bay, a seaport south of the city, at 10:30 a.m.\n\n\"A radio contact was established for the boat, which, according to the owner, was heading towards the harbor,\" the police statement said. Half an hour later \"the submarine suddenly sank and the owner was subsequently rescued on a private motorboat sailing him in port.\"\n\nMadsen \"told us he had technical problems\" when asked to explain why the submarine failed to respond to radio contact earlier in the day, Damgaard said.", "time": "02:49:00"}

"http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_islands_in_the_Baltic_Sea", "label": {"eng": "List of islands in the Baltic Sea"}, "score": 2, "type": "wiki", "id": "1238823"}], "url": "http://www.nzherald.co.nz/world/news/article.cfm?c_id=2&objectid=11903013", "body": "The owner of an amateur-built submarine was arrested on suspicion of murder yesterday after his vessel sank off Denmark's coast and a journalist who had joined him for a short voyage was reported missing.\n\nCopenhagen police said the man denied killing the missing woman and reported dropping her off on a redeveloped island in Copenhagen's harbour about 3 hours into their night trip.\n\nThe statement did not identify the submarine's owner, Peter Madsen, 46, but the Danish inventor's financing of the project through crowdfunding and first launch of the UC3 Nautilus in 2008 made headlines.\n\nThe 40-tonne, nearly 18m long vessel has been described as the largest privately-built submarine of its kind.\n\nBefore his arrest, Madsen appeared on Danish television to discuss the submarine's sinking and his rescue. The journalist's boyfriend alerted authorities on Friday that the sub had not returned from a test run, police said.\n\n\"I am fine, but sad because Nautilus went down,\" Madsen told Denmark's TV2 channel.\n\nMadsen said \"a minor problem with a ballast tank turned into a major issue\" that ultimately caused the submarine to sink.\n\n\"It took about 30 seconds for Nautilus to sink, and I couldn't close any hatches or anything,\" he said. \"But I guess that was pretty good, because I otherwise still would have been down there.\"\n\nThe woman was a journalist writing about Madsen and his submarine, Swedish and Danish media reported.\n\nDanish Navy spokesman Anders Damgaard. said Madsen the and journalist were the only two on board.\n\nCopenhagen's Deputy Police Inspector Jens Moller Jensen says investigators are looking for witnesses who may have seen the woman after the time Madsen reported she disembarked.\n\nPolice said the submerged submarine was lying in just over 2m of water, but divers had not been able to enter it safely. They were hoping to tow it to port and open it then.\n\nMadsen's company RML Spacelab is seeking to send people into space and is developing a rocket, floating launch pad and astronaut testing machine, its website says.\n\nTwo helicopters and three ships combed the sea from Copenhagen to the Baltic Sea island of Bornholm after police received the report it had not got back to land just after 3.30am. It was spotted by a lighthouse in Koge Bay, south of the city, at 10.30am.\n\n\"A radio contact was established for the boat, which, according to the owner, was heading towards the harbour,\" police said.\n\nHalf an hour later \"the submarine suddenly sank and the owner was subsequently rescued on a private motorboat\".\n\nMadsen \"told us he had technical problems\" when asked to explain why the submarine failed to respond to radio contact earlier in the day, Damgaard said.", "time": "17:27:00"}

"score": 2, "type": "wiki", "id": "557657"}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ballast_tank", "label": {"eng": "Ballast tank"}, "score": 3, "type": "wiki", "id": "616014"}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Royal_Danish_Navy", "label": {"eng": "Royal Danish Navy"}, "score": 2, "type": "wiki", "id": "783667"}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nautilus_(Verne)", "label": {"eng": "Nautilus (Verne)"}, "score": 2, "type": "wiki", "id": "814158"}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Refshale\u00f8en,_Copenhagen", "label": {"eng": "Refshale\u00f8en, Copenhagen"}, "score": 2, "type": "wiki", "id": "977034"}], "url": "http://www.timesdaily.com/news/nation/amateur-danish-sub-sinks-inventor-held-on-murder-charge/article_ed620977-b764-5626-a1e8-0ffeb7cdcd56.html", "body": "COPENHAGEN, Denmark (AP) -- The owner of an amateur-built submarine was arrested on suspicion of murder Friday after his vessel sank off Denmark's coast and a journalist who had joined him for what was supposed to be a short voyage was reported missing, Copenhagen police said.\n\nPolice said in a statement Friday night that the man denied killing the missing woman and reported dropped her off on a redeveloped island in Copenhagen's harbor about 3 \u00bd hours into their Thursday night trip.\n\nThe statement did not identify the submarine's owner, Peter Madsen, 46, but the Danish inventor's financing of the project through crowdfunding and first launch of the UC3 Nautilus in 2008 made headlines.\n\nThe 40-ton, nearly 18-meter-long (60-foot-long) has been described as the largest privately built submarine of its kind.\n\nBefore his arrest, Madsen appeared on Danish television to discuss the submarine's sinking and his rescue. It was the journalist's boyfriend who alerted authorities early Friday that the sub had not returned from a test run, police said.\n\n\"I am fine, but sad because Nautilus went down,\" Madsen told Denmark's TV2 channel, which aired footage of him getting off what appeared to be a private boat and making a thumbs-up sign.\n\nMadsen said \"a minor problem with a ballast tank\" -- a compartment that holds water to provide stability -- \"turned into a major issue\" that ultimately caused the vessel to sink.\n\n\"It took about 30 seconds for Nautilus to sink, and I couldn't close any hatches or anything,\" he said. \"But I guess that was pretty good, because I otherwise still would have been down there.\"\n\nSwedish police said later in the day they were investigating the whereabouts of a missing woman who had been on the submarine at some point.\n\n\"Whether the woman was on board the submarine at the time of her disappearance is unclear,\" police said in a statement.\n\nThe woman was a journalist writing about Madsen and his submarine, Swedish and Danish media reported.\n\n\"He told us that the journalist who also had been on board had been dropped off Thursday evening,\" Danish navy spokesman Anders Damgaard told The Associated Press. \"They were the only two on board yesterday.\"\n\nCopenhagen Deputy Police Inspector Jens Moller Jensen says investigators are looking for witnesses who may have seen the woman after the time Madsen reported she disembarked. She also was not identified by name.\n\nThe police statement said the submerged submarine was lying in seven feet of water, but divers had not been able to enter it safely as of Friday night. They were hoping to tow it to port on Saturday and open it then, the statement said.\n\nMadsen describes himself as an \"inventrepaneur\" on the website for his Copenhagen-based company. RML Spacelab is seeking to send people into space and is developing a rocket, floating launch pad and astronaut testing machine among other projects, the site says.\n\n\"My passion is finding ways to travel to worlds beyond the well-known,\" Madsen wrote on the site. \"I design and manufacture non-commercial extreme machines, employing teams of volunteering engineers and technicians to challenge the ordinary....\"\n\n\"The undersea world is close, it's beautiful, always just around the corner in Denmark. Diving, no matter the method, is very challenging and it*s technically difficult to go to beyond where rubber suits and scuba gear can take us.\"\n\nThe Nautilus set out from Refshale Island, a former shipyard redeveloped as an purposed as an entertainment and activity spot, at about 7 p.m. local time on Thursday, according to a police timeline.\n\nTwo helicopters and three ships combed the sea from Copenhagen to the Baltic Sea island of Bornholm after police learned just after 3:30 a.m. It was spotted by a lighthouse in Koge Bay, a seaport south of the city, at 10:30 a.m.\n\n\"A radio contact was established for the boat, which, according to the owner, was heading towards the harbor,\" the police statement said. Half an hour later \"the submarine suddenly sank and the owner was subsequently rescued on a private motorboat sailing him in port.\"\n\nMadsen \"told us he had technical problems\" when asked to explain why the submarine failed to respond to radio contact earlier in the day, Damgaard said.\n\n-- -- --\n\nLisa Leff contributed from London.\n\nSubscribe", "time": "21:45:00"}

of Copenhagen. But I guess that was pretty good because I otherwise still would have been down there.\"\n\nThe ballast tank is a compartment that holds water, which is used as ballast to provide stability for a vessel.\n\n\"He told us that the journalist who also had been on board had been dropped off Thursday evening,\" Damgaard told The Associated Press. "http://www.pressherald.com/2017/08/11/danish-sub-sinks-police-hold-inventor/", "body": "COPENHAGEN, Denmark -- The owner of an amateur-built submarine was arrested on suspicion of murder Friday after his vessel sank off Denmark's coast and a journalist who had joined him for what was supposed to be a short voyage was reported missing, Copenhagen police said.\n\nPolice said Friday night that the man denied killing the missing woman and reported dropping her off on a redeveloped island in Copenhagen's harbor about 3 1/2 hours into their Thursday night trip.\n\nDanish submarine owner Peter Madsen stands inside his privately built 60-foot-long vessel in 2008. Search photos available for purchase: Photo Store \u2192\n\nPolice did not identify the submarine's owner, Peter Madsen, 46, but the Danish inventor's financing of the project through crowdfunding and first launch of the UC3 Nautilus in 2008 made headlines.\n\nThe 40-ton, nearly 60-foot-long vessel has been described as the largest privately built submarine of its kind.\n\nBefore his arrest, Madsen appeared on Danish television to discuss the submarine's sinking and his rescue.\n\nIt was the journalist's boyfriend who alerted authorities early Friday that the sub had not returned from a test run, police said.\n\n\"I am fine, but sad because Nautilus went down,\" Madsen told Denmark's TV2 channel, which aired footage of him getting off what appeared to be a private boat and giving a thumbs-up sign.\n\nMadsen said \"a minor problem with a ballast tank\" - a compartment that holds water to provide stability - \"turned into a major issue\" that ultimately caused the submarine to sink.\n\n\"It took about 30 seconds for Nautilus to sink, and I couldn't close any hatches or anything,\" he said.\n\n\"But I guess that was pretty good, because I otherwise still would have been down there,\" he said.\n\nSwedish police said later in the day they were investigating the whereabouts of a missing woman who had been on the submarine at some point.\n\n\"Whether the woman was on board the submarine at the time of her disappearance is unclear,\" police said in a statement.\n\nThe woman was a journalist writing about Madsen and his submarine, Swedish and Danish media reported.\n\n\"He told us that the journalist who also had been on board had been dropped off Thursday evening,\" Danish navy spokesman Anders Damgaard said. \"They were the only two on board yesterday.\"\n\nCopenhagen Deputy Police Inspector Jens Moller Jensen said investigators are looking for witnesses who may have seen the woman after the time Madsen reported she disembarked. She also was not identified by name.\n\nPolice said the submerged submarine was lying in seven feet of water, but divers had not been able to enter it safely as of Friday night.\n\nThey were hoping to tow it to port Saturday and open it then, police said.\n\nShare\n\nSend questions/comments to the editors.\n\nWant the news vital to Maine? "http://www.dw.com/en/sunken-danish-submarine-owner-peter-madsen-denies-manslaughter-charge-for-missing-reporter/a-40064090", "body": "Danish inventor Peter Madsen has fronted court charged with manslaughter after his giant homemade submarine sunk with a passenger inexplicably missing. The submarine only sunk after it was found by searching authorities.\n\nA Danish court was to decide Saturday if the owner of a sunken amateur-built submarine should remain in pre-trial detention.\n\nPeter Madsen faces manslaughter charges over the disappearance of a female journalist.\n\nThirty-year-old freelance journalist Kim Wall was doing a story on the submarine. The inventor told authorities Friday that he dropped Wall off on an island in Copenhagen's harbor before the vessel sank.\n\nThe submarine was located Friday at a depth of seven meters (22-feet), south of Copenhagen. Divers were initially unable to safely enter it.\n\nA salvage vessel was working Saturday to raise the submarine.\n\nCrowdfunding project\n\nMadsen built the world's largest homemade submarine in 2008 after crowdfunding the cost. The 40-ton, 18-meter-long craft named UC3 Nautilus was his third submarine project.\n\nAccording to a timeline compiled by police, on Thursday at about 7 p.m. local time (1700 UTC), the sub departed Refshale Island, a former industrial shipyard transformed into a creative hub, for what was supposed to be a short trip.\n\nWhen it failed to return, the journalist's boyfriend alerted authorities at about 2:30 a.m., prompting a wide search.\n\nCraft sinks after being spotted\n\nTwo helicopters and three ships scoured the Baltic Sea waters between Copenhagen and the island of Bornholm. Eventually a lighthouse in Koge Bay, about 30 kilometers (19 miles) south of Copenhagen, spotted the craft at 10:30 a.m. on Friday.\n\n\"A radio contact was established for the boat, which, according to the owner, was heading towards the harbor,\" the police statement said. But 30 minutes later \"the submarine suddenly sank and the owner was subsequently rescued on a private motorboat sailing him in port.\"\n\nRead more: Captain of shipwrecked Costa Concordia cruise liner jailed\n\nLocal broadcaster TV2 aired footage of Madsen getting off the private boat and giving a thumbs-up sign, but the journalist was nowhere to be seen.\n\nMadsen told authorities he had dropped her off back at their departure point at about 10:30 p.m..\n\n\"Whether the woman was on board the submarine at the time of her disappearance is unclear,\" Danish police said without naming her.\n\nIgnored radio contact\n\nWhen asked why he did not respond to radio contact earlier in the day, Madsen told them he had had technical problems, Danish navy spokesman Anders Damgaard told The Associated Press news agency.\n\nBefore his arrest, Madsen told TV2 that the submarine sank when a minor ballast problem rapidly escalated and sunk the boat.\n\n\"It took about 30 seconds for Nautilus to sink, and I couldn't close any hatches or anything,\" he said. \"But I guess that was pretty good, because I otherwise still would have been down there.\"\n\n\"I am fine, but sad because Nautilus went down.\"\n\nCopenhagen Deputy Police Inspector Jens Moller Jensen said investigators were looking for witnesses who may have seen the woman after the time Madsen reported she disembarked.", "time": "05:02:00"}

suspicion of murder Friday after his vessel sank off Denmark's coast and a journalist who had joined him for what was supposed to be a short voyage was reported missing, Copenhagen police said.\n\nPolice said in a statement Friday night that the man denied killing the missing woman and reported dropped her off on a redeveloped island in Copenhagen's harbour about 3 1/2 hours into their Thursday night trip.\n\nThe statement did not identify the submarine's owner, Peter Madsen, 46, but the Danish inventor's financing of the project through crowdfunding and first launch of the UC3 Nautilus in 2008 made headlines.\n\nThe 40-ton, nearly 18-meter-long (60-foot-long) has been described as the largest privately built submarine of its kind.\n\nBefore his arrest, Madsen appeared on Danish television to discuss the submarine's sinking and his rescue. It was the journalist's boyfriend who alerted authorities early Friday that the sub had not returned from a test run, police said.\n\n\"I am fine, but sad because Nautilus went down,\" Madsen told Denmark's TV2 channel, which aired footage of him getting off what appeared to be a private boat and making a thumbs-up sign.\n\nMadsen said \"a minor problem with a ballast tank\" - a compartment that holds water to provide stability - \"turned into a major issue\" that ultimately caused the vessel to sink.\n\n\"It took about 30 seconds for Nautilus to sink, and I couldn't close any hatches or anything,\" he said. \"But I guess that was pretty good, because I otherwise still would have been down there.\"\n\nSwedish police said later in the day they were investigating the whereabouts of a missing woman who had been on the submarine at some point.\n\n\"Whether the woman was on board the submarine at the time of her disappearance is unclear,\" police said in a statement.\n\nThe woman was a journalist writing about Madsen and his submarine, Swedish and Danish media reported.\n\n\"He told us that the journalist who also had been on board had been dropped off Thursday evening,\" Danish navy spokesman Anders Damgaard told The Associated Press. \"They were the only two on board yesterday.\"\n\nCopenhagen Deputy Police Inspector Jens Moller Jensen says investigators are looking for witnesses who may have seen the woman after the time Madsen reported she disembarked. She also was not identified by name.\n\nThe police statement said the submerged submarine was lying in seven feet of water, but divers had not been able to enter it safely as of Friday night. They were hoping to tow it to port on Saturday and open it then, the statement said.\n\nMadsen describes himself as an \"inventrepaneur\" on the website for his Copenhagen-based company. RML Spacelab is seeking to send people into space and is developing a rocket, floating launch pad and astronaut testing machine among other projects, the site says.\n\n\"My passion is finding ways to travel to worlds beyond the well-known,\" Madsen wrote on the site. \"I design and manufacture non-commercial extreme machines, employing teams of volunteering engineers and technicians to challenge the ordinary....\"\n\n\"The undersea world is close, it's beautiful, always just around the corner in Denmark. Diving, no matter the method, is very challenging and it*s technically difficult to go to beyond where rubber suits and scuba gear can take us.\"\n\nThe Nautilus set out from Refshale Island, a former shipyard redeveloped as an purposed as an entertainment and activity spot, at about 7 p.m. local time on Thursday, according to a police timeline.\n\nTwo helicopters and three ships combed the sea from Copenhagen to the Baltic Sea island of Bornholm after police learned just after 3:30 a.m. It was spotted by a lighthouse in Koge Bay, a seaport south of the city, at 10:30 a.m.\n\n\"A radio contact was established for the boat, which, according to the owner, was heading towards the harbour,\" the police statement said. Half an hour later \"the submarine suddenly sank and the owner was subsequently rescued on a private motorboat sailing him in port.\"\n\nMadsen \"told us he had technical problems\" when asked to explain why the submarine failed to respond to radio contact earlier in the day, Damgaard said.", "time": "21:27:00"}

"http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/UC3_Nautilus", "label": {"eng": "UC3 Nautilus"}, "score": 3, "type": "wiki", "id": "1438666"}], "url": "http://www.dw.com/en/sunken-danish-submarine-owner-peter-madsen-denies-manslaughter-reporter-missing/a-40064090", "body": "Danish inventor Peter Madsen has fronted court charged with manslaughter after his giant homemade submarine sunk with a passenger inexplicably missing. The submarine only sunk after it was found by searching authorities.\n\nA Danish court was to decide Saturday if the owner of a sunken amateur-built submarine should remain in pre-trial detention.\n\nPeter Madsen faces manslaughter charges over the disappearance of a female journalist.\n\nThirty-year-old freelance journalist Kim Wall was doing a story on the submarine. The inventor told authorities Friday that he dropped Wall off on an island in Copenhagen's harbor before the vessel sank.\n\nThe submarine was located Friday at a depth of seven meters (22-feet), south of Copenhagen. Divers were initially unable to safely enter it.\n\nA salvage vessel was working Saturday to raise the submarine.\n\nCrowdfunding project\n\nMadsen built the world's largest homemade submarine in 2008 after crowdfunding the cost. The 40-ton, 18-meter-long craft named UC3 Nautilus was his third submarine project.\n\nAccording to a timeline compiled by police, on Thursday at about 7 p.m. local time (1700 UTC), the sub departed Refshale Island, a former industrial shipyard transformed into a creative hub, for what was supposed to be a short trip.\n\nWhen it failed to return, the journalist's boyfriend alerted authorities at about 2:30 a.m., prompting a wide search.\n\nCraft sinks after being spotted\n\nTwo helicopters and three ships scoured the Baltic Sea waters between Copenhagen and the island of Bornholm. Eventually a lighthouse in Koge Bay, about 30 kilometers (19 miles) south of Copenhagen, spotted the craft at 10:30 a.m. on Friday.\n\n\"A radio contact was established for the boat, which, according to the owner, was heading towards the harbor,\" the police statement said. But 30 minutes later \"the submarine suddenly sank and the owner was subsequently rescued on a private motorboat sailing him in port.\"\n\nRead more: Captain of shipwrecked Costa Concordia cruise liner jailed\n\nLocal broadcaster TV2 aired footage of Madsen getting off the private boat and giving a thumbs-up sign, but the journalist was nowhere to be seen.\n\nMadsen told authorities he had dropped her off back at their departure point at about 10:30 p.m..\n\n\"Whether the woman was on board the submarine at the time of her disappearance is unclear,\" Danish police said without naming her.\n\nIgnored radio contact\n\nWhen asked why he did not respond to radio contact earlier in the day, Madsen told them he had had technical problems, Danish navy spokesman Anders Damgaard told The Associated Press news agency.\n\nBefore his arrest, Madsen told TV2 that the submarine sank when a minor ballast problem rapidly escalated and sunk the boat.\n\n\"It took about 30 seconds for Nautilus to sink, and I couldn't close any hatches or anything,\" he said. \"But I guess that was pretty good, because I otherwise still would have been down there.\"\n\n\"I am fine, but sad because Nautilus went down.\"\n\nCopenhagen Deputy Police Inspector Jens Moller Jensen said investigators were looking for witnesses who may have seen the woman after the time Madsen reported she disembarked.", "time": "05:02:00"}

"814158"}], "url": "http://www.hawaiinewsnow.com/story/36113492/amateur-danish-sub-sinks-inventor-held-on-murder-charge", "body": "COPENHAGEN, Denmark (AP) - The owner of an amateur-built submarine was arrested on suspicion of murder Friday after his vessel sank off Denmark's coast and a journalist who had joined him for what was supposed to be a short voyage was reported missing, Copenhagen police said.\n\nPolice said in a statement Friday night that the man denied killing the missing woman and reported dropped her off on a redeveloped island in Copenhagen's harbor about 3 \u00bd hours into their Thursday night trip.\n\nThe statement did not identify the submarine's owner, Peter Madsen, 46, but the Danish inventor's financing of the project through crowdfunding and first launch of the UC3 Nautilus in 2008 made headlines.\n\nThe 40-ton, nearly 18-meter-long (60-foot-long) has been described as the largest privately built submarine of its kind.\n\nBefore his arrest, Madsen appeared on Danish television to discuss the submarine's sinking and his rescue. It was the journalist's boyfriend who alerted authorities early Friday that the sub had not returned from a test run, police said.\n\n\"I am fine, but sad because Nautilus went down,\" Madsen told Denmark's TV2 channel, which aired footage of him getting off what appeared to be a private boat and making a thumbs-up sign.\n\nMadsen said \"a minor problem with a ballast tank\" - a compartment that holds water to provide stability - \"turned into a major issue\" that ultimately caused the vessel to sink.\n\n\"It took about 30 seconds for Nautilus to sink, and I couldn't close any hatches or anything,\" he said. \"But I guess that was pretty good, because I otherwise still would have been down there.\"\n\nSwedish police said later in the day they were investigating the whereabouts of a missing woman who had been on the submarine at some point.\n\n\"Whether the woman was on board the submarine at the time of her disappearance is unclear,\" police said in a statement.\n\nThe woman was a journalist writing about Madsen and his submarine, Swedish and Danish media reported.\n\n\"He told us that the journalist who also had been on board had been dropped off Thursday evening,\" Danish navy spokesman Anders Damgaard told The Associated Press. \"They were the only two on board yesterday.\"\n\nCopenhagen Deputy Police Inspector Jens Moller Jensen says investigators are looking for witnesses who may have seen the woman after the time Madsen reported she disembarked. She also was not identified by name.\n\nThe police statement said the submerged submarine was lying in seven feet of water, but divers had not been able to enter it safely as of Friday night. They were hoping to tow it to port on Saturday and open it then, the statement said.\n\nMadsen describes himself as an \"inventrepaneur\" on the website for his Copenhagen-based company. RML Spacelab is seeking to send people into space and is developing a rocket, floating launch pad and astronaut testing machine among other projects, the site says.\n\n\"My passion is finding ways to travel to worlds beyond the well-known,\" Madsen wrote on the site. \"I design and manufacture non-commercial extreme machines, employing teams of volunteering engineers and technicians to challenge the ordinary....\"\n\n\"The undersea world is close, it's beautiful, always just around the corner in Denmark. Diving, no matter the method, is very challenging and it*s technically difficult to go to beyond where rubber suits and scuba gear can take us.\"\n\nThe Nautilus set out from Refshale Island, a former shipyard redeveloped as an purposed as an entertainment and activity spot, at about 7 p.m. local time on Thursday, according to a police timeline.\n\nTwo helicopters and three ships combed the sea from Copenhagen to the Baltic Sea island of Bornholm after police learned just after 3:30 a.m. It was spotted by a lighthouse in Koge Bay, a seaport south of the city, at 10:30 a.m.\n\n\"A radio contact was established for the boat, which, according to the owner, was heading towards the harbor,\" the police statement said. Half an hour later \"the submarine suddenly sank and the owner was subsequently rescued on a private motorboat sailing him in port.\"\n\nMadsen \"told us he had technical problems\" when asked to explain why the submarine failed to respond to radio contact earlier in the day, Damgaard said.\n\nCopyright 2017 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. This material may not be published, broadcast, rewritten or redistributed.", "time": "21:24:00"}

Thursday night trip.\n\nThe statement did not identify the submarine's owner, Peter Madsen, 46, but the Danish inventor's financing of the project through crowdfunding and first launch of the UC3 Danish television to discuss the submarine's sinking and his rescue. It was the journalist's boyfriend who alerted authorities early Friday that the sub had not returned from a test run, police said.\n\n\"I am fine, but sad because Nautilus went down,\" Madsen told Denmark's TV2 channel, which aired footage of him getting off what appeared to be a private boat and making a thumbs-up sign.\n\nMadsen said \"a minor problem with a ballast tank\" - a compartment that holds water to provide stability - \"turned into a major issue\" that ultimately caused the vessel to sink.\n\n\"It took about 30 seconds for Nautilus to sink, and I couldn't close any hatches or anything,\" he said. \"But I guess that was pretty good, because I otherwise still would have been down there.\"\n\nSwedish police said later in the day they were investigating the whereabouts of a missing woman who had been on the submarine at some point.\n\n\"Whether the woman was on board the submarine at the time of her disappearance is unclear,\" police said in a statement.\n\nThe woman was a journalist writing about Madsen and his submarine, Swedish and Danish media reported.\n\n\"He told us that the journalist who also had been on board had been dropped off Thursday evening,\" Danish navy spokesman Anders Damgaard told The Associated Press. \"They were the only two on board yesterday.\"\n\nCopenhagen Deputy Police Inspector Jens Moller Jensen says investigators are looking for witnesses who may have seen the woman after the time Madsen reported she disembarked. She also was not identified by name.\n\nThe police statement said the submerged submarine was lying in seven feet of water, but divers had not been able to enter it safely as of Friday night. They were hoping to tow it to port on Saturday and open it then, the statement said.\n\nMadsen describes himself as an \"inventrepaneur\" on the website for his Copenhagen-based company. RML Spacelab is seeking to send people into space and is developing a rocket, floating launch pad and astronaut testing machine among other projects, the site says.\n\n\"My passion is finding ways to travel to worlds beyond the well-known,\" Madsen wrote on the site. \"I design and manufacture non-commercial extreme machines, employing teams of volunteering engineers and technicians to challenge the ordinary....\"\n\n\"The undersea world is close, it's beautiful, always just around the corner in Denmark. Diving, no matter the method, is very challenging and it*s technically difficult to go to beyond where rubber suits and scuba gear can take us.\"\n\nThe Nautilus set out from Refshale Island, a former shipyard redeveloped as an purposed as an entertainment and activity spot, at about 7 p.m. local time on Thursday, according to a police timeline.\n\nTwo helicopters and three ships combed the sea from Copenhagen to the Baltic Sea island of Bornholm after police learned just after 3:30 a.m. It was spotted by a lighthouse in Koge Bay, a seaport south of the city, at 10:30 a.m.\n\n\"A radio contact was established for the boat, which, according to the owner, was heading towards the harbour,\" the police statement said. Half an hour later \"the submarine suddenly sank and the owner was subsequently rescued on a private motorboat sailing him in port.\"\n\nMadsen \"told us he had technical problems\" when asked to explain why the submarine failed to respond to radio contact earlier in the day, Damgaard said.", "time": "21:24:00"}

"http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/UC3_Nautilus", "label": {"eng": "UC3 Nautilus"}, "score": 3, "type": "wiki", "id": "1438666"}], "url": "http://www.dw.com/en/danish-diy-submarines-sinks-inventor-peter-madsen-arrested-on-suspicion-of-manslaughter/a-40064090", "body": "Danish inventor Peter Madsen has been arrested after his giant homemade submarine sunk with a passenger inexplicably missing. The submarine ignored radio contact and only sunk after it was found by searching authorities.\n\nThe Danish owner of a huge DIY submarine was arrested on manslaughter charges after his craft sunk, and a journalist who was possibly on board disappeared, Copenhagen police announced on Friday.\n\nPeter Madsen built the world's largest homemade submarine in 2008 after crowdfunding the cost. The 40-ton, 18-meter-long (60 feet) craft named UC3 Nautilus was his third submarine project.\n\nThe 46-year-old was voyaging off the coast of Denmark with a Swedish journalist who local media said was doing a story on the sub, when they went missing.\n\nRead more: Former judge in French child murder mystery found dead\n\nAccording to the police timeline, on Thursday at about 7 p.m. local time, the sub departed Refshale Island, a former industrial shipyard transformed into a creative hub, for what was supposed to be a short trip.\n\nBut when they did not return, the journalist's boyfriend alerted authorities at about 2.30 a.m., prompting a wide search.\n\nCraft sinks after being spotted\n\nTwo helicopters and three ships scoured the Baltic Sea waters between Copenhagen and the island of Bornholm. Eventually a lighthouse in Koge Bay, about 30 kilometers (19 miles) south of Copenhagen, spotted the craft at 10.30 a.m. on Friday.\n\n\"A radio contact was established for the boat, which, according to the owner, was heading towards the harbor,\" the police statement said. But 30 minutes later \"the submarine suddenly sank and the owner was subsequently rescued on a private motorboat sailing him in port.\"\n\nRead more: Captain of shipwrecked Costa Concordia cruise liner jailed\n\nLocal broadcaster TV2 aired footage of Madsen getting off the private boat and giving a thumbs-up sign, but the journalist was nowhere to be seen.\n\nMadsen told authorities he had dropped her off back at their departure point at about 10.30 p.m.\n\n\"Whether the woman was on board the submarine at the time of her disappearance is unclear,\" Danish police said without naming her.\n\nIgnored radio contact\n\nWhen asked why he did not respond to radio contact earlier in the day, Madsen told them he had had technical problems, Danish navy spokesman Anders Damgaard told The Associated Press.\n\nBefore his arrest Madsen told TV2 that the submarine sank when a minor ballast problem rapidly escalated and sunk the boat.\n\n\"It took about 30 seconds for Nautilus to sink, and I couldn't close any hatches or anything,\" he said. \"But I guess that was pretty good, because I otherwise still would have been down there.\"\n\n\"I am fine, but sad because Nautilus went down.\"\n\nPolice located the wreck several meters below the surface but divers were unable to safely enter it. They were hoping to tow it to port on Saturday and then search inside.\n\nCopenhagen Deputy Police Inspector Jens Moller Jensen said investigators were looking for witnesses who may have seen the woman after the time Madsen reported she disembarked.", "time": "05:02:00"}

[which] turned into a major issue,\" he told Denmark's TV2 channel.\n\nHours later, the police said Madsen had been charged with the murder of a female journalist from Sweden, who had been aboard the submarine earlier.\n\nStory continues below\n\nIt was the woman's boyfriend who alerted authorities the submarine was missing early Friday. Two helicopters and three ships combed the sea from Copenhagen to the Baltic Sea island of Bornholm.\n\n\"Whether the woman was on board the submarine at the time of her disappearance is unclear,\" police said in a statement.\n\nMadsen denied the charges and said he had dropped the woman off in Copenhagen on Thursday night, according to the police.\n\nREAD MORE: U of A students create robotic submarine, now headed to international competition\n\nThe police in Sweden said they had tried without success to contact the woman by phone. Her family had not heard from her.\n\nThe woman was a journalist writing about Madsen and his submarine, Swedish and Danish media reported.\n\nPolice said the submarine was found on the seabed in Koge Bay, south of Copenhagen, at a depth of seven metres. Divers had not been able to enter the vessel.\n\nMadsen, an entrepreneur known as an artist, submarine builder and aerospace engineer, will go before a judge for preliminary questioning on Saturday.\n\nThe submarine, UC3 Nautilus, is nearly 18-metres long, and one of three constructed by Madsen and funded by crowdsourcing. It can carry eight people.\n\nRELATED: Mini-submarine launched in Lake Ontario to uncover the Avro Arrow", "time": "21:58:00"}

But navy spokesman Anders Damgaard later said the 40-ton, nearly 18-metrs-long submarine had sunk.\n\nPeter Madsen, who built the vessel that was launched in 2008, had \"been taken over to one of our ships\", Mr Damgaard said. He declined to give further details.\n\nFootage aired on Denmark's TV2 channel showed the 46-year-old getting off what seemed to be a private boat and making a thumbs-up sign as he walked away.\n\n\"I am fine but sad because Nautilus went down,\" he told Denmark's TV2 channel.\n\nMr Madsen said \"a minor problem with a ballast tank ... turned into a major issue\" that ultimately caused the vessel - considered the largest privately-built of its kind in the world - to sink.\n\n\"It took about 30 seconds for Nautilus to sink and I couldn't close any hatches or anything. But I guess that was pretty good because I otherwise still would have been down there.\"\n\nThe ballast tank is a compartment that holds water, which is used as ballast to provide stability for a vessel.\n\n\"He told us that the journalist who also had been on board had been dropped off on Thursday evening,\" Mr Damgaard said.\n\nSwedish media said the reporter was Swedish. \"They were the only two on board yesterday.\"\n\nAfter the submarine was reported missing early on Friday, the navy had launched a search from Copenhagen to the Baltic Sea island of Bornholm with two helicopters and three ships, and encouraged members of the public with boats and sonar to search, too\n\n\"He told us he had technical problems\" to explain why the submarine failed to respond to radio contact, Mr Damgaard said.", "time": "12:43:00"}

p.m.\n\nA Danish court has ordered the owner of an amateur-built submarine to be held in pre-trial detention for 24 days while police investigate the disappearance of a Swedish journalist who had been on the ship.\n\nDanish maritime authorities work on a salvage operation, taking place in connection with a criminal investigation, south of the island of Amager close to Copenhagen, Denmark, Saturday, Aug. 12, 2017. Danish prosecutors urged a judge on Saturday to hold in pre-trial detention the owner of an amateur-built submarine, suspected of being responsible for the disappearance of a Swedish woman who had been onboard the ship that later sank. The buoy marks where privately built and owned submarine UC3 Nautilus sank. (Brian Lindberg Jensen/Ritzau Foto via AP)\n\nPeter Madsen was arrested Friday on preliminary manslaughter charges after his 40-ton, nearly 18-meter-long (60-foot-long) submarine sank off Denmark's eastern coast. He has denied responsibility for the fate of 30-year-old Kim Wall, saying she had disembarked before his vessel went down.\n\nJudge Kari Soerensen announced the ruling Saturday after a two-hour custody hearing held behind closed doors.\n\nMadsen's defense lawyer, Bettina Hald Engmark, said her client maintains he is innocent.\n\nHald Engmark says Madsen is \"willing to cooperate\" and hasn't decided whether to appeal the detention ruling.\n\n___\n\n3 p.m.\n\nThe family of a journalist who has been missing since she joined the inventor of an amateur-built submarine on a voyage in Denmark says she freelanced for prestigious publications such as the New York Times, The Guardian and Vice Magazine.\n\nKim Wall's family said in statement emailed to The Associated Press on Saturday, \"It is with great dismay that we received the news that Kim went missing during an assignment in Denmark.\"\n\nHer family says the 30-year-old Sweden-born journalist lives in New York and Peking and had studied at the Sorbonne university in Paris and the London School of Economics.\n\nShe also received a master's degree in journalism from Columbia University in New York in 2013.\n\nThe submarine's Danish inventor, Peter Madsen, is being held on suspicion of manslaughter in Wall's disappearance.\n\nThe submarine sank on Friday, but Madsen says Wall disembarked on Thursday night.\n\n___\n\n11:15 a.m.\n\nA boater who helped search a private submarine that sank off Denmark says he saw inventor Peter Madsen Kristian standing in the vessel's tower while it was still afloat.\n\nKristian Isbak tells The Associated Press he had responded to the Navy's call to help locate the submarine on Friday when he spotted Madsen.\n\nIsbak says the inventor \"then climbed down inside the submarine and there was then some kind of air flow coming up and the submarine started to sink.\"\n\nWhile the UC3 Nautilus was going down, Isbak says \"came up again, stayed in the tower until water came into it as the submarine started sinking.\"\n\nIsbak says he then saw Madsen swim over to another private boat.\n\nMadsen's actions are being scrutinized because he is being detained in the disappearance of a Swedish journalist who had been onboard his submarine Thursday night.\n\nMadsen says he dropped her off before the sinking.\n\n___\n\n10:55 a.m.\n\nA judge is set to decide if the owner of an amateur-built submarine should be held in custody during an investigation into whether he is responsible for the disappearance of a Swedish woman who had been onboard his submarine that sank off Denmark's east coast.\n\nPeter Madsen was arrested Friday on preliminary manslaughter charges after his 40-ton, nearly 18-meter-long (60-foot-long) UC3 Nautilus sank. He has denied responsibility for the 30-year-old woman's fate, saying she disembarked earlier.\n\nThe woman's boyfriend alerted authorities that the sub had not returned, prompting a major maritime search. The Navy said it was spotted sailing but then sank.\n\nMadsen told authorities he dropped the woman off on an island in Copenhagen's harbor a few hours into their Thursday night trip.\n\nThe hearing starts at 1200 GMT.\n\nFILE - This is a April 30 2008 file photo of submarine owner Peter Madsen . Denmark's navy says that Madsen's privately built submarine that had been feared missing in Danish waters has been found and the crew is safe. The navy says that the 40-ton, nearly 18-meter-long (60-foot-long) submarine with at least two people on board had been \"found sailing\" south of Copenhagen. (Niels Hougaard /Ritzau. "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/UC3_Nautilus", "label": {"eng": "UC3 Nautilus"}, "score": 4, "type": "wiki", "id": "1438666"}], "url": "https://www.yahoo.com/tech/submarine-owner-suspected-murder-faces-085332552.html", "body": "1 / 6The turret of sunken privately built and owned submarine submarine UC3 Nautilus is seen by the side of a salvage vessel during an operation taking place in connection with a criminal investigation, in Oeresund strait near Copenhagen, Denmark, Saturday, Aug. 12, 2017. Danish prosecutors urged a judge on Saturday to hold in pre-trial detention the owner of an amateur-built submarine, suspected of being responsible for the disappearance of a Swedish woman who had been onboard the ship that later sank. (Jacob Ehrbahn/Ritzau Foto via AP)\n\nCOPENHAGEN, Denmark (AP) -- A Danish court ordered the owner of an amateur-built submarine Saturday held in pre-trial detention for 24 days while police investigate the disappearance of a Swedish journalist who had been on the ship before it sank.\n\nPeter Madsen was arrested Friday on preliminary manslaughter charges, hours after his 40-ton, nearly 18-meter-long (60-foot-long) submarine sank off Denmark's eastern coast.\n\nThe inventor, who is from Denmark, has denied responsibility for the fate of 30-year-old Kim Wall, saying the journalist disembarked before his vessel went down.\n\nJudge Kari Soerensen announced the ruling after a two-hour custody hearing held behind closed doors.\n\nMadsen's defense lawyer, Bettina Hald Engmark, said her client maintains his innocence. He is \"willing to cooperate\" and hasn't decided whether to appeal the detention ruling, Hald Engmark said.\n\nBefore the hearing was closed, the courtroom was packed with Danish and Swedish reporters and the 46-year-old Madsen's relatives. Madsen smiled and chatted with his lawyer.\n\n\"I would very much like to express myself,\" he said after the preliminary charges were read.\n\nProsecutor Louise Pedersen said Madsen faces the preliminary manslaughter charge \"for having killed in an unknown way and in an unknown place Kim Isabell Frerika Wall of Sweden sometime after Thursday 5 p.m.\"\n\nWall's boyfriend alerted authorities early Friday that the sub, , named the UC3 Nautilus, had not returned to Copenhagen as expected. The Danish Navy launched a major search involving two helicopters, three ships and several private boats. The Navy said the sub was seen sailing, but then sank shortly afterward.\n\nKristian Isbak, who had responded to the Navy's call to help locate the ship on Friday, told The Associated Press he first spotted Madsen standing wearing his trademark military fatigues in the submarine's tower while it was still afloat.\n\n\"He then climbed down inside the submarine and there was then some kind of air flow coming up and the submarine started to sink,\" Isbak said. \"(He) came up again and stayed in the tower until water came into it\" before swimming to a nearby boat as the submarine sank, he added.\n\nMadsen told authorities he had dropped Wall off on an island in Copenhagen's harbor a few hours into their Thursday night trip.\n\n\"It is with great dismay that we received the news that Kim went missing during an assignment in Denmark,\" her family said in statement emailed to The Associated Press.\n\nThe Sweden-born freelance journalist studied at the Sorbonne university in Paris, the London School of Economics and at Columbia University in New York, where she graduated with a master's degree in journalism in 2013.\n\nShe lived in New York and Peking, her family said, and had written for The New York Times, The Guardian, the South China Morning Post and Vice Magazine, among other publications.\n\nA salvage vessel on Saturday raised the submarine, which was seven meters (23 feet) under water off Copenhagen's south island of Dragoer. The submarine was brought up some 7 kilometers (4.3 miles) off the coast and is expected to be transported to land at some point.\n\nIn theory, the Nautilus can dive up to 470 meters (1,550 feet) but has rarely gone deeper than 40 meters (132 feet), according to Madsen's business web site.\n\nIf tried and found guilty, Madsen would face between five years and life in prison.", "time": "01:58:00"}

compartment that holds water, which is used as ballast to provide stability for a vessel. "body": "Ships and aircraft have been circling the site off the Danish coast where the UC3 Nautilus submarine sank on Friday August 11 to try to salvage the vessel.\n\nEntrepreneur Peter Madsen, from Denmark, made headlines when he successfully financed the building of the submarine through crowdfunding.\n\nHe designed and built the UC3 Nautilus along with fellow submarine enthusiasts in 2008.\n\nAfter being rescued, Madsen was arrested on suspicion of murder after a Swedish journalist who joined him for the voyage was reported missing.\n\nMadsen, 46, denies killing the missing woman and says he dropped her off on Refshale\u00f8en island about three and a half hours into their trip on Thursday night.\n\nThe only people on board were Madsen and the journalist, whose partner alerted authorities to her absence on Thursday evening.\n\nThe police in Sweden said they had tried without success to contact the woman by phone. Her family had not heard from her.\n\nMadsen, an entrepreneur known as an artist, submarine builder and aerospace engineer, is appearing before a judge for preliminary questioning.\n\nPolice said the submarine was on the seabed in Koge Bay, south of Copenhagen, at a depth of seven metres. Divers had not been able to enter the vessel.\n\nMadsen said \"a minor problem with a ballast tank ... turned into a major issue\" that caused the sinking of the vessel.\n\nThe ballast tank is a compartment that holds water to provide stability for a vessel.\n\nThe 18-metre Nautilus is one of three subs built by Madsen. It can carry eight people and is considered to be the largest privately built submarine of its kind.", "time": "19:19:00"}

{"eng": "UC3 Nautilus"}, "score": 3, "type": "wiki", "id": "1438666"}], "url": "http://www.mercurynews.com/2017/08/13/submarine-owner-suspected-of-murder-faces-custody-hearing/", "body": "HELSINKI (AP) -- Danish police say they have not found the body of a missing Swedish journalist inside an amateur-built submarine that sank off Denmark's eastern coast last week.\n\nCopenhagen police spokesman Jens Moller Jensen said Sunday that investigators uncovered no trace of 30-year-old freelance journalist Kim Wall in the UC3 Nautilus sub after it was raised and transported for investigation Saturday.\n\nPolice will continue to search for Wall in the waters near the island in Copenhagen's harbor where the sub's owner Peter Madsen said he dropped her off late Thursday.\n\nMadsen, 40, made a last-minute escape from the sinking sub and has denied any responsibility on the fate of Wall. He was arrested Friday on preliminary manslaughter charges.\n\nMoller Jensen said there are indications that the Danish inventor deliberately sank the 40-ton, 60-foot-long submarine.\n\nMadsen was ordered held in pre-trial detention for 24 days while police investigate Wall's disappearance. The inventor says the journalist disembarked before his vessel went down.\n\nMadsen's defense lawyer, Bettina Hald Engmark, said her client maintains his innocence. He is \"willing to cooperate\" and hasn't decided whether to appeal the detention ruling, Hald Engmark said.\n\nProsecutor Louise Pedersen said Madsen faces the preliminary manslaughter charge \"for having killed in an unknown way and in an unknown place Kim Isabell Frerika Wall of Sweden sometime after Thursday 5 p.m.\"\n\nWall's boyfriend alerted authorities early Friday that the sub had not returned to Copenhagen as expected. The Danish Navy launched a major search involving two helicopters, three ships and several private boats.\n\nKristian Isbak, who had responded to the Navy's call to help locate the ship on Friday, told The Associated Press he spotted Madsen standing in the submarine's tower while it was still afloat.\n\n\"He then climbed down inside the submarine and there was then some kind of air flow coming up and the submarine started to sink,\" Isbak said. \"(He) came up again and stayed in the tower until water came into it\" before swimming to a nearby boat as the submarine sank, he added.\n\nA salvage vessel on Saturday raised the submarine, which was 22 feet under water off Copenhagen's south island of Dragoer. The submarine was brought up four miles off the coast and is expected to be transported to land at some point.\n\nIn theory, the Nautilus can dive up to 1,550 feet but has rarely gone deeper than 132 feet, according to Madsen's business web site.\n\nMadsen told authorities he had dropped Wall off on an island in Copenhagen's harbor a few hours into their Thursday night trip.\n\nThe Sweden-born freelance journalist studied at the Sorbonne university in Paris, the London School of Economics and at Columbia University in New York, where she graduated with a master's degree in journalism in 2013.\n\nShe lived in New York and Peking, her family said, and had written for The New York Times, The Guardian, the South China Morning Post and Vice Magazine, among other publications.\n\nIf tried and found guilty, Madsen would face between five years and life in prison.", "time": "08:31:00"}

{"eng": "Kim Wall (British actor)"}, "score": 3, "type": "wiki", "id": "1438956"}], "url": "https://www.yahoo.com/news/submarine-owner-detained-over-journalist-164704245.html", "body": "(COPENHAGEN, Denmark) -- A Danish court ordered the owner of an amateur-built submarine Saturday to be held in pre-trial detention for 24 days while police investigate the disappearance of a Swedish journalist who had been on the ship before it sank.\n\nPeter Madsen was arrested Friday on preliminary manslaughter charges, hours after his 40-ton, nearly 18-meter-long (60-foot-long) submarine sank off Denmark's eastern coast.\n\nHe has denied responsibility for the fate of 30-year-old Kim Wall, saying the journalist disembarked before his vessel, named the UC3 Nautilus, went down.\n\nJudge Kari Soerensen announced the ruling after a two-hour custody hearing held behind closed doors.\n\nMadsen's defense lawyer, Bettina Hald Engmark, said her client maintains his innocence. He is \"willing to cooperate\" and hasn't decided whether to appeal the detention ruling, Hald Engmark said.\n\nBefore the hearing was closed, the courtroom was packed with Danish and Swedish reporters and the 46-year-old Madsen's relatives. Madsen smiled and chatted with his lawyer.\n\n\"I would very much like to express myself,\" he said after the preliminary charges were read.\n\nProsecutor Louise Pedersen said Madsen faces the preliminary manslaughter charge \"for having killed in an unknown way and in an unknown place Kim Isabell Frerika Wall of Sweden sometime after Thursday 5 p.m.\"\n\nWall's boyfriend alerted authorities early Friday that the sub had not returned to Copenhagen as expected, prompting a major search involving two helicopters, three ships and several private boats. The Navy said the sub was seen sailing, but then sank shortly afterward.\n\nKristian Isbak, who had responded to the Navy's call to help locate the ship on Friday, told The Associated Press he first spotted Madsen standing wearing his trademark military fatigues in the submarine's tower while it was still afloat.\n\n\"He then climbed down inside the submarine and there was then some kind of air flow coming up and the submarine started to sink,\" Isbak said. \"(He) came up again and stayed in the tower until water came into it\" before swimming to a nearby boat as the submarine sank, he added.\n\nMadsen told authorities he had dropped Wall off on an island in Copenhagen's harbor a few hours into their Thursday night trip.\n\n\"It is with great dismay that we received the news that Kim went missing during an assignment in Denmark,\" her family said in statement emailed to The Associated Press.\n\nThe Sweden-born freelance journalist studied at the Sorbonne university in Paris, the London School of Economics and at Columbia University in New York, where she graduated with a master's degree in journalism in 2013.\n\nShe lived in New York and Peking, her family said, and had written for The New York Times, The Guardian, the South China Morning Post and Vice Magazine, among other publications.\n\nA salvage vessel, the Vina, on Saturday raised the submarine, which was seven meters (23 feet) under water off Copenhagen's south island of Dragoer. The submarine was brought up some 7 kilometers (4.3 miles) off the coast and is expected to be transported to land at some point.\n\nIn theory, the Nautilus can dive up to 470 meters (1,550 feet) but has rarely gone deeper than 40 meters (132 feet), according to Madsen's business web site.\n\nIf tried and found guilty, Madsen would face between five years and life in prison.", "time": "13:58:00"}
