operation and taken ashore after his homemade 17-meter submarine went down.\n\nThe vessel was recovered on Saturday in Koge Bay, south of Copenhagen, at a depth of seven meters, and taken into harbor.\n\nIt will be partly drained of water and searched by the police late on Saturday and early Sunday.\n\nMadsen, an entrepreneur known as an artist, submarine builder, and aerospace engineer, went before a judge on Saturday behind closed doors for preliminary questioning. His defense lawyer, Betina Hald Engmark, told Reuters he denied the charges.\n\nThe police said on Friday the inventor had said he had dropped Wall off in Copenhagen on Thursday night.\n\nThe police in Sweden said they had tried without success to contact her by phone and that her family had not heard from her.\n\nThe submarine, the UC3 Nautilus, is one of three constructed by Madsen. "http://www.dailymail.co.uk/~/article-4786410/index.html", "body": "Police raised the submarine on Sunday and failed to find Miss Wall's body, but say there is evidence craft was scuttled deliberately\n\nThe body of a missing Swedish journalist is not on board a crowdfunded submarine that sank off the Danish coast on Friday, police have revealed.\n\nOfficers had been hoping to find the remains of 30-year-old Kim Wall on board the wreckage of the UC3 Nautilus submarine which was wrecked in Copenhagen harbour on Friday.\n\nMiss Wall was last seen on board the vessel with amateur builder Peter Madsen who is now being held on suspicion of negligent manslaughter.\n\nDanish investigators say they have found evidence the Nautilus was sunk deliberately as they continue land and sea searches for any sign of Miss Wall, Swedish newspaper Expressen reports.\n\nThe body of missing journalist Kim Wall, 30, is not on board a submarine that sank in Copenhagen harbour after she was last seen on board, police say\n\nPeter Madsen, who built the submarine himself before inviting Miss Wall along for the maiden voyage, is still under investigation for negligent manslaughter as investigators say there is evidence it was wrecked deliberately\n\nThe UC3 Nautilus was raised from the bottom of Copenhagen harbour on Saturday night where it had been under 8m (24ft) of water since sinking on Friday morning\n\nThe freelance reporter boarded the sub, which was built by Madsen, on Thursday night in order to write a story about it.\n\nOn Friday morning the Danish Navy were scrambled to help the stricken sub, before reporting it sunk at 10.45am.\n\nMadsen claims he was the only one on board at the time, and that he dropped Miss Wall off at the mouth of the harbour shortly after 10pm the previous night.\n\nBut Danish police on Sunday said he has given them several conflicting accounts of what had happened, without elaborating further.\n\nMiss Wall's family and boyfriend have not heard from her since she boarded the submarine and police have been unable to contact her.\n\nAround the time he claimed to have dropped Miss Wall off, Madsen sent a mysterious text to a friend saying she had left the vessel and cancelling a trip he was supposed to be taking on the submarine the following day, according to local reports.\n\nHe did not respond to questions from the friend about why he had dropped Miss Wall off or why the trip was being cancelled.\n\nMadsen was arrested on manslaughter charges on Saturday before a judge ordered that he be held in custody while investigations are carried out.\n\nDespite not finding Miss Wall's body, Danish investigators are continuing to search in water and on land for any sign of her\n\nMadsen claims he dropped Miss Wall off at the mouth of the harbour and was the only one on board when his craft (pictured right) sank\n\nMiss Wall's family have not heard from her and police say they have been unable to contact her since she boarded the submarine (pictured overnight Saturday) on Thursday\n\nSpeaking to reporters at court, Madsen said 'there is something I really want to tell you later', without elaborating any further.\n\nThe prosecutor asked for doors to the hearing to be closed as information likely to distress Miss Wall's family was about to be heard.\n\nThe 40-ton, 18-meter long Nautilus, one of three subs built by Madsen, was found by divers under 7m (24ft) of water, though they were unable to enter it safely.\n\nA salvage ship, the Vina, has now raised the sub from the sea bed close to Copenhagen's south island of Dragoer and brought it back to shore to be inspected.\n\nAuthorities were alerted that something had gone wrong with the submarine by Miss Wall's boyfriend after she failed to return home, prompting a major search operation involving two helicopters, three ships and several private boats.\n\nKristian Isbak, who had responded to the Navy's call to help locate the ship, sailed out immediately Friday and saw Madsen standing wearing his trademark military fatigues in the submarine's tower while it was still afloat.\n\nDivers had located the submarine underwater on Friday but were unable to enter it safely\n\nThe submarine was reported missing early on Friday by Miss Wall's boyfriend after she failed to return home, prompting a major search operation by the Danish Navy\n\n'He then climbed down inside the submarine and there was then some kind of air flow coming up and the submarine started to sink,' Isbak told The Associated Press.\n\n'(He) came up again and stayed in the tower until water came into it' before swimming to a nearby boat as the submarine sank, he added.\n\nMadsen said there was a valve error that became serious when he tried to repair it.\n\nFootage aired on Denmark's TV2 channel showed Madsen, 46, getting off what seemed to be a private boat and making a thumbs up sign as he walked away.\n\nUpon his rescue from K\u00f8ge Bay, Madsen said: 'I'm fine. But I'm sorry because 'Nautilus' has gone down.'\n\nMiss Wall is a freelance journalist who graduated with a masters from Columbia University before going on to write about identity, gender, pop-culture, social justice and foreign policy.\n\nMadsen, pictured above in 2008 in front of his submarine, was seen standing the tower of the still-floating submarine moments before it sank, according to a rescuer\n\nMadsen claimed his creation had suffered a valve failure that became much worse when he tried to fix it, leading to the sinking\n\nShe is from Sweden but spent time living in New York and Beijing. Her writing has appeared in Harpers, The Guardian, New York Times, Foreign Policy, Vice Magazine, Slate, South China Morning Post, The Atlantic, Roads & Kingdoms, and TIME.\n\nThe submarine was Madsen's third attempt at building such a structure and was the largest privately built submarine in the world at the time of its launch.\n\nThe Nautilus was a diesel-electric submarine. The diesel engine is uses when sailing or propelling just below the surface, while the electrical engine is used when the submarine is deep below the water's surface.\n\nIt was built like a post-World War II submarine, with a galley, crew bunks, officer's mass, bridge and engine room.\n\nIt's named after the famed submarine manned by Jules Verne's Captain Nemo character in Twenty Thousand Leagues Under the Sea.", "time": "12:54:00"}

"http://lethbridgeherald.com/news/world-news/2017/08/12/submarine-owner-detained-over-journalists-disappearance/", "body": "COPENHAGEN - A Danish court ordered the owner of an amateur-built submarine Saturday held in pre-trial detention for 24 days while police investigate the disappearance of a Swedish journalist who had been on the ship before it sank.\n\nPeter Madsen was arrested Friday on preliminary manslaughter charges, hours after his 40-ton, nearly 18-meter-long (60-foot-long) submarine sank off Denmark's eastern coast.\n\nThe inventor, who is from Denmark, has denied responsibility for the fate of 30-year-old Kim Wall, saying the journalist disembarked before his vessel went down.\n\nJudge Kari Soerensen announced the ruling after a two-hour custody hearing held behind closed doors.\n\nMadsen's defence lawyer, Bettina Hald Engmark, said her client maintains his innocence. He is \"willing to co-operate\" and hasn't decided whether to appeal the detention ruling, Hald Engmark said.\n\nBefore the hearing was closed, the courtroom was packed with Danish and Swedish reporters and the 46-year-old Madsen's relatives. Madsen smiled and chatted with his lawyer.\n\n\"I would very much like to express myself,\" he said after the preliminary charges were read.\n\nProsecutor Louise Pedersen said Madsen faces the preliminary manslaughter charge \"for having killed in an unknown way and in an unknown place Kim Isabell Frerika Wall of Sweden sometime after Thursday 5 p.m.\"\n\nWall's boyfriend alerted authorities early Friday that the sub, , named the UC3 Nautilus, had not returned to Copenhagen as expected. The Danish Navy launched a major search involving two helicopters, three ships and several private boats. The Navy said the sub was seen sailing, but then sank shortly afterward.\n\nKristian Isbak, who had responded to the Navy's call to help locate the ship on Friday, told The Associated Press he first spotted Madsen standing wearing his trademark military fatigues in the submarine's tower while it was still afloat.\n\n\"He then climbed down inside the submarine and there was then some kind of air flow coming up and the submarine started to sink,\" Isbak said. \"(He) came up again and stayed in the tower until water came into it\" before swimming to a nearby boat as the submarine sank, he added.\n\nMadsen told authorities he had dropped Wall off on an island in Copenhagen's harbour a few hours into their Thursday night trip.\n\n\"It is with great dismay that we received the news that Kim went missing during an assignment in Denmark,\" her family said in statement emailed to The Associated Press.\n\nThe Sweden-born freelance journalist studied at the Sorbonne university in Paris, the London School of Economics and at Columbia University in New York, where she graduated with a master's degree in journalism in 2013.\n\nShe lived in New York and Peking, her family said, and had written for The New York Times, The Guardian, the South China Morning Post and Vice Magazine, among other publications.\n\nA salvage vessel on Saturday raised the submarine, which was seven meters (23 feet) under water off Copenhagen's south island of Dragoer. The submarine was brought up some 7 kilometres (4.3 miles) off the coast and is expected to be transported to land at some point.\n\nIn theory, the Nautilus can dive up to 470 metres (1,550 feet) but has rarely gone deeper than 40 metres (132 feet), according to Madsen's business website.\n\nIf tried and found guilty, Madsen would face between five years and life in prison.", "time": "22:14:00"}

crowdfunded, amateur-built submarine that was missing in Danish waters has sunk south of Copenhagen, but the owner and builder who was alone onboard is safe, the Danish navy said Friday.\n\nInitially the navy said the 40-ton, nearly 18-meter-long (60-foot-long) UC3 Nautilus, which cost 1.5million DKK (\u00a3154,000, $200,000) to build, was 'found sailing' south of Copenhagen.\n\nHowever, navy press spokesman Anders Damgaard later said it had sunk and Peter Madsen, who built the vessel that was launched in 2008, had 'been taken over to one of our ships'. He declined to give details.\n\nMadsen later said there was a valve error that became serious when he tried to repair it.\n\nFootage aired on Denmark's TV2 channel showed Madsen, 46, getting off what seemed to be a private boat and making a thumbs up sign as he walked away.\n\nUpon his rescue from K\u00f8ge Bay, Madsen said: 'I'm fine. But I'm sorry because \"Nautilus\" has gone down.'\n\n'He told us that the journalist who also had been on board had been dropped off Thursday evening,' Damgaard told The Associated Press.\n\nSwedish media said the reporter was Swedish. 'They were the only two on board yesterday'.\n\nAfter the submarine was reported missing early Friday, the navy had launched a search from Copenhagen to the Baltic Sea island of Bornholm with two helicopters and three ships, and encouraged members of the public with boats and sonar to search, too\n\n'He told us he had technical problems' to explain why the submarine failed to respond to radio contact, Damgaard said.\n\nThe submarine was Madsen's third attempt at building such a structure and was the largest privately built submarine in the world at the time of its launch.\n\nThe Nautilus is a diesel-electric submarine. The diesel engine is uses when sailing or propelling just below the surface, while the electrical engine is used when the submarine is deep below the water's surface.\n\nIt was built like a post-World War II submarine, with a galley, crew bunks, officer's mass, bridge and engine room.\n\nIt's named after the famed submarine manned by Jules Verne's Captain Nemo character in Twenty Thousand Leagues Under the Sea.", "time": "07:13:00"}

2, "type": "wiki", "id": "1438969"}], "url": "http://www.dailymail.co.uk/~/article-4784310/index.html", "body": "A Danish inventor whose crowdfunded submarine sank near Copenhagen on Friday has now been arrested on suspicion of killing a journalist last seen on board.\n\nPeter Madsen is being investigated over the disappearance of journalist Kim Wall who was on the \u00a3154,000 UC3 Nautilus submarine shortly before it was wrecked.\n\nMiss Wall, 30, has not been seen since the ill-fated voyage, though Madsen claims he dropped her off on an island in Copenhagen's harbor not long into the voyage.\n\nPeter Madsen, 46, whose home-built submarine sank near Copenhagen on Friday, is now being investigated over the disappearance of journalist Kim Wall, 30, who was on board with him\n\nMadsen (pictured right after he was rescued from the sinking craft) claims he dropped Miss Wall off on an island in Copenhagen's harbour before his vessel sank\n\nThe UC3 Nautilus was built by Madsen who crowd-funded \u00a3154,000 to create the 40-ton, 18m vessel which he claimed could reach a depth of 1,150ft\n\nPolice in Sweden said they have tried without success to contact Miss Wall by phone. Her family has not heard from her.\n\nHe is currently being held on preliminary manslaughter charges with a judge set to rule on Saturday whether he must remain in detention while investigations are carried out.\n\nThe 40-ton, 18-meter long Nautilus, one of three subs built by Madsen, is currently sitting under 7m (24ft) of water with divers unable to enter it safely.\n\nA salvage ship, the Vina, is working to raise the vessel which came to rest on the sea bed close to Copenhagen's south island of Dragoer.\n\nAuthorities were alerted that something had gone wrong with the submarine by Miss Wall's boyfriend after she failed to return home, prompting a major search operation involving two helicopters, three ships and several private boats.\n\nKristian Isbak, who had responded to the Navy's call to help locate the ship, sailed out immediately Friday and saw Madsen standing wearing his trademark military fatigues in the submarine's tower while it was still afloat.\n\n'He then climbed down inside the submarine and there was then some kind of air flow coming up and the submarine started to sink,' Isbak told The Associated Press.\n\nThe submarine was reported missing early on Friday by Miss Wall's boyfriend after she failed to return home, prompting a major search operation by the Danish Navy\n\nMadsen, pictured above in 2008 in front of his submarine, was seen standing the tower of the still-floating submarine moments before it sank, according to a rescuer\n\nMadsen claimed his creation had suffered a valve failure that became much worse when he tried to fix it, leading to the sinking\n\n'(He) came up again and stayed in the tower until water came into it' before swimming to a nearby boat as the submarine sank, he added.\n\nMadsen said there was a valve error that became serious when he tried to repair it.\n\nFootage aired on Denmark's TV2 channel showed Madsen, 46, getting off what seemed to be a private boat and making a thumbs up sign as he walked away.\n\nUpon his rescue from K\u00f8ge Bay, Madsen said: 'I'm fine. But I'm sorry because 'Nautilus' has gone down.'\n\nMiss Wall is a freelance journalist who graduated with a masters from Columbia University before going on to write about identity, gender, pop-culture, social justice and foreign policy.\n\nShe is from Sweden but spent time living in New York and Beijing. Her writing has appeared in Harpers, The Guardian, New York Times, Foreign Policy, Vice Magazine, Slate, South China Morning Post, The Atlantic, Roads & Kingdoms, and TIME.\n\nThe submarine was Madsen's third attempt at building such a structure and was the largest privately built submarine in the world at the time of its launch.\n\nThe Nautilus was a diesel-electric submarine. The diesel engine is uses when sailing or propelling just below the surface, while the electrical engine is used when the submarine is deep below the water's surface.\n\nIt was built like a post-World War II submarine, with a galley, crew bunks, officer's mass, bridge and engine room.\n\nIt's named after the famed submarine manned by Jules Verne's Captain Nemo character in Twenty Thousand Leagues Under the Sea.", "time": "11:06:00"}

{"eng": "UC3 Nautilus"}, "score": 3, "type": "wiki", "id": "1438666"}], "url": "http://www.mymcmurray.com/2017/08/12/submarine-owner-detained-over-journalists-disappearance/", "body": "COPENHAGEN - A Danish court ordered the owner of an amateur-built submarine Saturday held in pre-trial detention for 24 days while police investigate the disappearance of a Swedish journalist who had been on the ship before it sank.\n\nPeter Madsen was arrested Friday on preliminary manslaughter charges, hours after his 40-ton, nearly 18-meter-long (60-foot-long) submarine sank off Denmark's eastern coast.\n\nThe inventor, who is from Denmark, has denied responsibility for the fate of 30-year-old Kim Wall, saying the journalist disembarked before his vessel went down.\n\nJudge Kari Soerensen announced the ruling after a two-hour custody hearing held behind closed doors.\n\nMadsen's defence lawyer, Bettina Hald Engmark, said her client maintains his innocence. He is \"willing to co-operate\" and hasn't decided whether to appeal the detention ruling, Hald Engmark said.\n\nBefore the hearing was closed, the courtroom was packed with Danish and Swedish reporters and the 46-year-old Madsen's relatives. Madsen smiled and chatted with his lawyer.\n\n\"I would very much like to express myself,\" he said after the preliminary charges were read.\n\nProsecutor Louise Pedersen said Madsen faces the preliminary manslaughter charge \"for having killed in an unknown way and in an unknown place Kim Isabell Frerika Wall of Sweden sometime after Thursday 5 p.m.\"\n\nWall's boyfriend alerted authorities early Friday that the sub, , named the UC3 Nautilus, had not returned to Copenhagen as expected. The Danish Navy launched a major search involving two helicopters, three ships and several private boats. The Navy said the sub was seen sailing, but then sank shortly afterward.\n\nKristian Isbak, who had responded to the Navy's call to help locate the ship on Friday, told The Associated Press he first spotted Madsen standing wearing his trademark military fatigues in the submarine's tower while it was still afloat.\n\n\"He then climbed down inside the submarine and there was then some kind of air flow coming up and the submarine started to sink,\" Isbak said. \"(He) came up again and stayed in the tower until water came into it\" before swimming to a nearby boat as the submarine sank, he added.\n\nMadsen told authorities he had dropped Wall off on an island in Copenhagen's harbour a few hours into their Thursday night trip.\n\n\"It is with great dismay that we received the news that Kim went missing during an assignment in Denmark,\" her family said in statement emailed to The Associated Press.\n\nThe Sweden-born freelance journalist studied at the Sorbonne university in Paris, the London School of Economics and at Columbia University in New York, where she graduated with a master's degree in journalism in 2013.\n\nShe lived in New York and Peking, her family said, and had written for The New York Times, The Guardian, the South China Morning Post and Vice Magazine, among other publications.\n\nA salvage vessel on Saturday raised the submarine, which was seven meters (23 feet) under water off Copenhagen's south island of Dragoer. The submarine was brought up some 7 kilometres (4.3 miles) off the coast and is expected to be transported to land at some point.\n\nIn theory, the Nautilus can dive up to 470 metres (1,550 feet) but has rarely gone deeper than 40 metres (132 feet), according to Madsen's business website.\n\nIf tried and found guilty, Madsen would face between five years and life in prison.", "time": "22:11:00"}

"body": "COPENHAGEN, Denmark (AP) -- The Latest on a private submarine that sank off Denmark: (all times local):\n\n5 p.m.\n\nA Danish court has ordered the owner of an amateur-built submarine to be held in pre-trial detention for 24 days while police investigate the disappearance of a Swedish journalist who had been on the ship.\n\nPeter Madsen was arrested Friday on preliminary manslaughter charges after his 40-ton, nearly 18-meter-long (60-foot-long) submarine sank off Denmark's eastern coast. He has denied responsibility for the fate of 30-year-old Kim Wall, saying she had disembarked before his vessel went down.\n\nJudge Kari Soerensen announced the ruling Saturday after a two-hour custody hearing held behind closed doors.\n\nMadsen's defense lawyer, Bettina Hald Engmark, said her client maintains he is innocent.\n\nHald Engmark says Madsen is \"willing to cooperate\" and hasn't decided whether to appeal the detention ruling.\n\nThe family of a journalist who has been missing since she joined the inventor of an amateur-built submarine on a voyage in Denmark says she freelanced for prestigious publications such as the New York Times, The Guardian and Vice Magazine.\n\nKim Wall's family said in statement emailed to The Associated Press on Saturday, \"It is with great dismay that we received the news that Kim went missing during an assignment in Denmark.\"\n\nHer family says the 30-year-old Sweden-born journalist lives in New York and Peking and had studied at the Sorbonne university in Paris and the London School of Economics.\n\nShe also received a master's degree in journalism from Columbia University in New York in 2013.\n\nThe submarine's Danish inventor, Peter Madsen, is being held on suspicion of manslaughter in Wall's disappearance.\n\nThe submarine sank on Friday, but Madsen says Wall disembarked on Thursday night.\n\nA boater who helped search a private submarine that sank off Denmark says he saw inventor Peter Madsen Kristian standing in the vessel's tower while it was still afloat.\n\nKristian Isbak tells The Associated Press he had responded to the Navy's call to help locate the submarine on Friday when he spotted Madsen.\n\nIsbak says the inventor \"then climbed down inside the submarine and there was then some kind of air flow coming up and the submarine started to sink.\"\n\nWhile the UC3 Nautilus was going down, Isbak says \"came up again, stayed in the tower until water came into it as the submarine started sinking.\"\n\nIsbak says he then saw Madsen swim over to another private boat.\n\nMadsen's actions are being scrutinized because he is being detained in the disappearance of a Swedish journalist who had been onboard his submarine Thursday night.\n\nMadsen says he dropped her off before the sinking.\n\nA judge is set to decide if the owner of an amateur-built submarine should be held in custody during an investigation into whether he is responsible for the disappearance of a Swedish woman who had been onboard his submarine that sank off Denmark's east coast.\n\nPeter Madsen was arrested Friday on preliminary manslaughter charges after his 40-ton, nearly 18-meter-long (60-foot-long) UC3 Nautilus sank. He has denied responsibility for the 30-year-old woman's fate, saying she disembarked earlier.\n\nThe woman's boyfriend alerted authorities that the sub had not returned, prompting a major maritime search. The Navy said it was spotted sailing but then sank.\n\nMadsen told authorities he dropped the woman off on an island in Copenhagen's harbor a few hours into their Thursday night trip.", "time": "15:10:00"}

Copenhagen\n\nDanish police said on Sunday they had found nobody in the wreck of a submarine owned by an inventor charged with the manslaughter of a woman who had been on board - but added the vessel seemed to have been deliberately sunk.\n\nPolice have said that Swedish journalist Kim Wall, 30, is missing after taking a ride on Peter Madsen's homemade 17-metre sub, which sank on Friday morning. Madsen was rescued by the navy.\n\nMadsen, 46, has been ordered to be held in custody for 24 days, accused of Wall's manslaughter.\n\nThe vessel was recovered on Saturday from Koge Bay, south of Copenhagen, where it had been lying at a depth of seven metres, and taken into harbour. Police searched it late on Saturday and early on Sunday.\n\n\"There are no persons in the submarine, dead or alive,\" Jens Moller, head of Copenhagen Police's homicide unit, said at a news conference on Sunday.\n\nHe said it appeared to have been deliberately scuttled, and was still being treated as a possible crime scene.\n\nMadsen, an entrepreneur, artist, submarine builder and aerospace engineer, went before a judge on Saturday behind closed doors for preliminary questioning. His defence lawyer, Betina Hald Engmark, told Reuters he denied the charges.\n\nPolice said on Friday the inventor had told them he dropped Wall off from his submarine in Copenhagen on Thursday night. On Sunday they said they had since been given another explanation by Madsen, but declined to elaborate.\n\nPolice in Sweden said they had tried without success to contact Wall by phone and that her family had not heard from her.\n\nThe submarine, UC3 Nautilus, is one of three constructed by Madsen. It can carry eight people.", "time": "13:19:00"}

"body": "COPENHAGEN - A Danish court ordered the owner of an amateur-built submarine Saturday held in pre-trial detention for 24 days while police investigate the disappearance of a Swedish journalist who had been on the ship before it sank.\n\nPeter Madsen was arrested Friday on preliminary manslaughter charges, hours after his 40-ton, nearly 18-meter-long (60-foot-long) submarine sank off Denmark's eastern coast.\n\nThe inventor, who is from Denmark, has denied responsibility for the fate of 30-year-old Kim Wall, saying the journalist disembarked before his vessel went down.\n\nJudge Kari Soerensen announced the ruling after a two-hour custody hearing held behind closed doors.\n\nMadsen's defence lawyer, Bettina Hald Engmark, said her client maintains his innocence. He is \"willing to co-operate\" and hasn't decided whether to appeal the detention ruling, Hald Engmark said.\n\nBefore the hearing was closed, the courtroom was packed with Danish and Swedish reporters and the 46-year-old Madsen's relatives. Madsen smiled and chatted with his lawyer.\n\n\"I would very much like to express myself,\" he said after the preliminary charges were read.\n\nProsecutor Louise Pedersen said Madsen faces the preliminary manslaughter charge \"for having killed in an unknown way and in an unknown place Kim Isabell Frerika Wall of Sweden sometime after Thursday 5 p.m.\"\n\nWall's boyfriend alerted authorities early Friday that the sub, , named the UC3 Nautilus, had not returned to Copenhagen as expected. The Danish Navy launched a major search involving two helicopters, three ships and several private boats. The Navy said the sub was seen sailing, but then sank shortly afterward.\n\nKristian Isbak, who had responded to the Navy's call to help locate the ship on Friday, told The Associated Press he first spotted Madsen standing wearing his trademark military fatigues in the submarine's tower while it was still afloat.\n\n\"He then climbed down inside the submarine and there was then some kind of air flow coming up and the submarine started to sink,\" Isbak said. \"(He) came up again and stayed in the tower until water came into it\" before swimming to a nearby boat as the submarine sank, he added.\n\nMadsen told authorities he had dropped Wall off on an island in Copenhagen's harbour a few hours into their Thursday night trip.\n\n\"It is with great dismay that we received the news that Kim went missing during an assignment in Denmark,\" her family said in statement emailed to The Associated Press.\n\nThe Sweden-born freelance journalist studied at the Sorbonne university in Paris, the London School of Economics and at Columbia University in New York, where she graduated with a master's degree in journalism in 2013.\n\nShe lived in New York and Peking, her family said, and had written for The New York Times, The Guardian, the South China Morning Post and Vice Magazine, among other publications.\n\nA salvage vessel on Saturday raised the submarine, which was seven meters (23 feet) under water off Copenhagen's south island of Dragoer. The submarine was brought up some 7 kilometres (4.3 miles) off the coast and is expected to be transported to land at some point.\n\nIn theory, the Nautilus can dive up to 470 metres (1,550 feet) but has rarely gone deeper than 40 metres (132 feet), according to Madsen's business website.\n\nIf tried and found guilty, Madsen would face between five years and life in prison.", "time": "21:47:00"}

"url": "https://www.rt.com/news/399431-madsen-wall-submarine-killing/", "body": "Danish inventor Peter Madsen, charged in court Saturday with the death of Swedish journalist Kim Wall, who disappeared on Thursday after boarding his private submarine, has denied any guilt. He previously said he dropped her off on one of Copenhagen's harbor islands.\n\nMedia frenzy surrounding the case forced the hearing to be moved to a larger courtroom in Copenhagen on Saturday.\n\n\"I would like to have my say,\" Madsen, 46, told reporters and the public at the courtroom after the prosecutor said he faced \"preliminary charges [of manslaughter] for having killed in an unknown way and in an unknown place Kim Isabell Frerika Wall of Sweden.\"\n\nThe judge insisted, however, that initial statements should be given behind closed doors. After the hearing, Madsen, who has been a suspect since Friday, was placed in detention for 24 days.\n\nFriends, relatives and colleagues of Wall, who had been educated at Columbia University, Sorbonne and the London School of Economics, and worked as a freelance journalist, have bombarded social media with requests for information about her. Her family has also released a statement saying they still hoped that she would be found \"safe and well.\" Wall has not been reachable by phone since shortly after boarding Madsen's UC3 Nautilus submarine as part of an assignment for \"Wired\" magazine on Thursday evening.\n\nOn Saturday, the rescue vessel Vina recovered the UC3 Nautilus submarine, which is being treated as a possible crime scene, from the bottom of the sea near the island of Dragoer south of Copenhagen. The 18-meter-long, 40-ton vessel, built in 2008 with help from crowdfunding, was at the time the biggest private submarine in the world, and made its designer and captain a national celebrity.\n\nThe disappearance of Wall, whose articles have been published by the New York Times, the Guardian and other high-profile publications, was first reported by her boyfriend, who called the police after she failed to return on Thursday night.\n\nUnable to contact the Nautilus, police began a rescue operation involving two helicopters, three ships, and multiple volunteer vessels.\n\nKristian Isbak, who runs a marine company, says that he saw the moment the Nautilus sank on Friday morning.\n\nIsbak responded to the Navy's call to help locate the missing submarine, noticed the vessel on the sonar, and then spotted its sail above the water.\n\n\"We realized that it was Peter Madsen's submarine. A man sat in the tower, he climbed down and then up into the tower again,\" he told Danish daily Ekstra Bladet. \"There was a powerful pressure wave around the submarine. It began to sink. Madsen stood quite calmly in the tower. When the submarine had sunk so much that he could swim, it only took 10-15 seconds, Madsen leaped into the water and paddled to a rescue boat.\"\n\nMadsen gave a thumbs-up to gathered reporters when he came ashore, though admitted to local broadcaster TV2 that he was \"sad\" to have lost the Nautilus.\n\nWhen asked about the whereabouts of Wall, he claimed that he dropped her off near a restaurant on Refshaleon Island in Copenhagen harbor on Thursday evening, and then gave his own account of the sinking.\n\n\"I was out on a rehearsal trip, tinkering with different things in the submarine. Then a defect happened with a ballast tank which wasn't that serious, until I tried to repair it. Then it suddenly became very serious,\" Madsen told TV2. \"After that, it took 30 seconds for Nautilus to sink. I couldn't close the catch or anything. But that might be OK, as I would still be down there then.\"\n\nDanish daily Ekstra Bladet reported police sources as claiming that Madsen was suspected of intentionally sinking the vessel to cover up his tracks.", "time": "18:21:00"}

"http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/UC3_Nautilus", "label": {"eng": "UC3 Nautilus"}, "score": 5, "type": "wiki", "id": "1438666"}], "url": "https://www.gizmodo.com.au/2017/08/man-charged-with-killing-missing-journalist-after-crowdfunded-sub-sinks/", "body": "On Friday, the UC3 Nautilus, a famous DIY submarine, sank off the coast of Denmark. Its owner, Peter Madsen, was later rescued and claimed he'd had technical difficulties. Copenhagen police now say that they have charged Madsen with killing a Swedish woman who was last seen with him on board the submarine.\n\nPhoto: Wikimedia Commons\n\nWhen the UC3 Nautilus was first launched in 2008, it was touted as the world's largest privately built submarine. It's had some trouble along the way but was back in action this year. On Friday, however, it sunk off the coast of Denmark.\n\nThe Associated Press reported yesterday that Peter Madsen, the owner of the vessel and co-founder of Copenhagen Suborbitals, was returned to shore by a private boat after a technical malfunction sank the sub. \"I am fine, but sad because Nautilus went down,\" Madsen told Denmark's TV2, \"a minor problem with a ballast tank... turned into a major issue.\"\n\nFurther details are sketchy. According to the report, \"The navy initially said the sub was 'found sailing' south of Copenhagen.\" But later corrected themselves and confirmed that it had sunk. Soon thereafter, Copenhagen police confirmed that an unidentified woman had been reported missing and her boyfriend told authorities that she had been on the submarine doing a story for Wired. A spokesperson for Wired's US division tells Gizmodo that the reporter was not working for them and they are trying to confirm if she was working for the UK division. The boyfriend is said to be the one who first alerted police that the submarine was missing when it didn't return on time.\n\nAccording to Danish outlet Berlingske, a spokesperson for the Danish police said that Madsen claims he dropped the woman off in Copenhagen the previous night. \"We know she was aboard the submarine last night, but we do not know if she was aboard the boat when she disappeared,\" the spokesperson said. \"All I can say is that the woman's relatives reported her missing this night and that we still have not heard from her.\" Local police tweeted that they were investigating and had no further comment at the time.\n\nHowever, according to a press release since released from Copenhagen police, Madsen has now been arrested and charged with \"killing\" the Swedish woman. He denies the charges and still claims he dropped the still unidentified woman off in Copenhagen on Thursday night around 11:30PM local time. Police are seeking any witnesses who may have seen the woman after 4PM on Thursday.\n\nThe police description of the missing woman reads:\n\n160 cm tall, 56 kg, 30 years, faint of building, reddish brown hair, green eyes. Wearing an orange blouse with long sleeves, black and white floral skirt, nylon stockings and white tennis shoes.\n\n\"It took about 30 seconds for Nautilus to sink, and I couldn't close any hatches or anything,\" Madsen told reporters. Co-founder of the DIY rocket ship group Copenhagen Suborbitals, Madsen is a an eccentric renaissance man who helped build the UC3 Nautilus with a group of volunteers over the course of three years. It was launched in May of 2008 and performed relatively smoothly for several years before being grounded in 2011. Repairs and maintainance were needed and following a crowdfunding campaign on Indiegogo, it relaunched in April this year.\n\nCopenhagen Suborbitals is a group of amateur rocket enthusiasts that supports itself through crowdfunding and has around 55 volunteers. The collective hopes to one day fly a volunteer on one of its rockets, but flight tests have, so far, failed. The Nautilus was another project for the group and was a bigger success. In 2014, Madsen left the group to focus on other projects, one of which being the UC3 Nautilus.\n\nThe UC3 Nautilus submarine association was formed in order to separate ownership of the sub from Copenhagen Suborbitals. But within a year, Madsen was feuding with the board of that organisation over who the proper owner of Nautilus really was. A statement on the association's website claims that board members received a text message from Madsen that read in part, \"You may think that a curse is lying on Nautilus. That curse is me.\" After several rounds of negotiation, the board decided to cede ownership of the vessel to Madsen.\n\nThe submarine's tumultuous journey is now at an end. But many questions remain unanswered. First and foremost, authorities are scrambling to find the missing journalist that was last seen with Madsen. Police divers reportedly searched the area for the UC3 Nautilus wreckage, while the Danish navy also encouraged members of the public who have the right equipment to help with the search. Police say that the submarine was found by divers but will need to be hauled to shore before they can enter. It was found on the seabed in Koge Bay, 7m below the surface.\n\n[Associated Press]\n\nWATCH MORE: Science & Health News", "time": "21:27:00"}

"http://www.thejournal.ie/homemade-submarine-denmark-3543862-Aug2017/", "body": "The turret of sunken privately built and owned submarine submarine UC3 Nautilus is seen by the side of a salvage vessel during an operation taking place in connection with a criminal investigation. Image: Jacob Ehrbahn/AP The turret of sunken privately built and owned submarine submarine UC3 Nautilus is seen by the side of a salvage vessel during an operation taking place in connection with a criminal investigation. Image: Jacob Ehrbahn/AP\n\nDANISH POLICE HUNTING for a missing journalist said they searched a huge homemade submarine that sank last week, but no body was found.\n\n\"The sub has been searched and there is nobody on board -- neither dead nor alive,\" Copenhagen police homicide chief Jens Moller told reporters.\n\nThe journalist had been aboard the submarine before it sank. The vessel's 46-year-old inventor Peter Madsen has been accused of negligent manslaughter and was remanded in custody for 24 days.\n\nHe has denied the allegations.\n\nThe vessel, the Nautilus, was refloated and towed to the Copenhagen port yesterday, then emptied of water overnight. Today police entered the sub and found it empty.\n\nPolice have identified the missing journalist as Kim Wall, a 30-year-old Swedish woman who was writing a feature about Madsen.\n\nNothing has been heard from her since Thursday evening when she boarded the sub with Madsen.\n\nHer boyfriend alerted police early on Friday that she had not returned home as planned.\n\nMadsen claims he dropped her off on the Refshaleoen island on Thursday evening after the interview.\n\nEarly on Friday, Danish authorities announced they were looking for the Nautilus in waters off Copenhagen.\n\nAround midday on Friday, the vessel was located in a bay in Koge, some 50 kilometres south of the Danish capital. Just after being located, Madsen was rescued and the submarine suddenly sank.\n\nMadsen said in media interviews after his rescue that the sub encountered a problem with the ballast tank.\n\nHowever, Moller said it appeared as though the sub was intentionally sunk, amid media speculation that Madsen may have downed the vessel to cover up a crime.\n\n\"It appears as though it was a deliberate action that caused the sub to sink,\" Moller said.\n\nWall is a freelance journalist based in China and the US. Her articles have appeared in the New York Times and the Guardian, among others.\n\n\"We're still hoping that we'll find Kim Wall alive, but we are preparing ourselves for the fact that she may not be,\" Moller said.\n\nMadsen made headlines when he launched the 18-metre Nautilus in 2008, at the time the world's biggest homemade submarine.\n\n\u00a9 - AFP 2017\n\nRead: Donald Trump's childhood home is up on Airbnb for \u20ac636-a-night", "time": "13:06:00"}

{"eng": "Kim Wall (British actor)"}, "score": 3, "type": "wiki", "id": "1438956"}], "url": "http://www.dailyrepublic.com/california-us-world/submarine-owner-detained-over-journalists-disappearance/", "body": "COPENHAGEN, Denmark -- A Danish court ordered the owner of an amateur-built submarine Saturday held in pre-trial detention for 24 days while police investigate the disappearance of a Swedish journalist who had been on the ship before it sank.\n\nPeter Madsen was arrested Friday on preliminary manslaughter charges, hours after his 40-ton, nearly 60-foot-long submarine sank off Denmark's eastern coast.\n\nThe inventor, who is from Denmark, has denied responsibility for the fate of 30-year-old Kim Wall, saying the journalist disembarked before his vessel went down.\n\nJudge Kari Soerensen announced the ruling after a two-hour custody hearing held behind closed doors.\n\nMadsen's defense lawyer, Bettina Hald Engmark, said her client maintains his innocence. He is \"willing to cooperate\" and hasn't decided whether to appeal the detention ruling, Hald Engmark said.\n\nBefore the hearing was closed, the courtroom was packed with Danish and Swedish reporters and the 46-year-old Madsen's relatives. Madsen smiled and chatted with his lawyer.\n\n\"I would very much like to express myself,\" he said after the preliminary charges were read.\n\nProsecutor Louise Pedersen said Madsen faces the preliminary manslaughter charge \"for having killed in an unknown way and in an unknown place Kim Isabell Frerika Wall of Sweden sometime after Thursday 5 p.m.\"\n\nWall's boyfriend alerted authorities early Friday that the sub, , named the UC3 Nautilus, had not returned to Copenhagen as expected. The Danish Navy launched a major search involving two helicopters, three ships and several private boats. The Navy said the sub was seen sailing, but then sank shortly afterward.\n\nKristian Isbak, who had responded to the Navy's call to help locate the ship on Friday, told The Associated Press he first spotted Madsen standing wearing his trademark military fatigues in the submarine's tower while it was still afloat.\n\n\"He then climbed down inside the submarine and there was then some kind of air flow coming up and the submarine started to sink,\" Isbak said. \"(He) came up again and stayed in the tower until water came into it\" before swimming to a nearby boat as the submarine sank, he added.\n\nMadsen told authorities he had dropped Wall off on an island in Copenhagen's harbor a few hours into their Thursday night trip.\n\n\"It is with great dismay that we received the news that Kim went missing during an assignment in Denmark,\" her family said in statement emailed to The Associated Press.\n\nThe Sweden-born freelance journalist studied at the Sorbonne university in Paris, the London School of Economics and at Columbia University in New York, where she graduated with a master's degree in journalism in 2013.\n\nShe lived in New York and Peking, her family said, and had written for The New York Times, The Guardian, the South China Morning Post and Vice Magazine, among other publications.\n\nA salvage vessel on Saturday raised the submarine, which was 23 feet under water off Copenhagen's south island of Dragoer. The submarine was brought up some 4.3 miles off the coast and is expected to be transported to land at some point.\n\nIn theory, the Nautilus can dive up to 1,550 feet but has rarely gone deeper than 132 feet, according to Madsen's business web site.\n\nIf tried and found guilty, Madsen would face between five years and life in prison.", "time": "20:32:00"}

"wiki", "id": "1438956"}], "url": "http://www.metronews.ca/news/world/2017/08/12/the-latest-sub-owner-ordered-held-in-woman-s-disappearance.html", "body": "COPENHAGEN -- The Latest on a private submarine that sank off Denmark: (all times local):\n\n5 p.m.\n\nA Danish court has ordered the owner of an amateur-built submarine to be held in pre-trial detention for 24 days while police investigate the disappearance of a Swedish journalist who had been on the ship.\n\nPeter Madsen was arrested Friday on preliminary manslaughter charges after his 40-ton, nearly 18-meter-long (60-foot-long) submarine sank off Denmark's eastern coast. He has denied responsibility for the fate of 30-year-old Kim Wall, saying she had disembarked before his vessel went down.\n\nJudge Kari Soerensen announced the ruling Saturday after a two-hour custody hearing held behind closed doors.\n\nMadsen's defence lawyer, Bettina Hald Engmark, said her client maintains he is innocent.\n\nHald Engmark says Madsen is \"willing to co-operate \" and hasn't decided whether to appeal the detention ruling.\n\n___\n\n3 p.m.\n\nThe family of a journalist who has been missing since she joined the inventor of an amateur-built submarine on a voyage in Denmark says she freelanced for prestigious publications such as the New York Times, The Guardian and Vice Magazine.\n\nKim Wall's family said in statement emailed to The Associated Press on Saturday, \"It is with great dismay that we received the news that Kim went missing during an assignment in Denmark.\"\n\nHer family says the 30-year-old Sweden-born journalist lives in New York and Peking and had studied at the Sorbonne university in Paris and the London School of Economics.\n\nShe also received a master's degree in journalism from Columbia University in New York in 2013.\n\nThe submarine's Danish inventor, Peter Madsen, is being held on suspicion of manslaughter in Wall's disappearance.\n\nThe submarine sank on Friday, but Madsen says Wall disembarked on Thursday night.\n\n___\n\n11:15 a.m.\n\nA boater who helped search a private submarine that sank off Denmark says he saw inventor Peter Madsen Kristian standing in the vessel's tower while it was still afloat.\n\nKristian Isbak tells The Associated Press he had responded to the Navy's call to help locate the submarine on Friday when he spotted Madsen.\n\nIsbak says the inventor \"then climbed down inside the submarine and there was then some kind of air flow coming up and the submarine started to sink.\"\n\nWhile the UC3 Nautilus was going down, Isbak says \"came up again, stayed in the tower until water came into it as the submarine started sinking.\"\n\nIsbak says he then saw Madsen swim over to another private boat.\n\nMadsen's actions are being scrutinized because he is being detained in the disappearance of a Swedish journalist who had been onboard his submarine Thursday night.\n\nMadsen says he dropped her off before the sinking.\n\n___\n\n10:55 a.m.\n\nA judge is set to decide if the owner of an amateur-built submarine should be held in custody during an investigation into whether he is responsible for the disappearance of a Swedish woman who had been onboard his submarine that sank off Denmark's east coast.\n\nPeter Madsen was arrested Friday on preliminary manslaughter charges after his 40-ton, nearly 18-meter-long (60-foot-long) UC3 Nautilus sank. He has denied responsibility for the 30-year-old woman's fate, saying she disembarked earlier.\n\nThe woman's boyfriend alerted authorities that the sub had not returned, prompting a major maritime search. The Navy said it was spotted sailing but then sank.\n\nMadsen told authorities he dropped the woman off on an island in Copenhagen's harbour a few hours into their Thursday night trip.\n\nThe hearing starts at 1200 GMT.", "time": "15:31:00"}

"https://in.reuters.com/article/denmark-submarine-idINKCN1AT0GG", "body": "COPENHAGEN (Reuters) - Danish police said on Sunday they had found nobody in the wreck of a submarine owned by an inventor charged with the manslaughter of a woman who had been on board - but added the vessel seemed to have been deliberately sunk.\n\nPolice have said that Swedish journalist Kim Wall, 30, is missing after taking a ride on Peter Madsen's homemade 17-metre sub, which sank on Friday morning. Madsen was rescued by the navy.\n\nMadsen, 46, has been ordered to be held in custody for 24 days, accused of Wall's manslaughter.\n\nThe vessel was recovered on Saturday from Koge Bay, south of Copenhagen, where it had been lying at a depth of seven metres, and taken into harbour. Police searched it late on Saturday and early on Sunday.\n\n\"There are no persons in the submarine, dead or alive,\" Jens Moller, head of Copenhagen Police's homicide unit, said at a news conference on Sunday.\n\nHe said it appeared to have been deliberately scuttled, and was still being treated as a possible crime scene.\n\nMadsen, an entrepreneur, artist, submarine builder and aerospace engineer, went before a judge on Saturday behind closed doors for preliminary questioning. His defence lawyer, Betina Hald Engmark, told Reuters he denied the charges.\n\nPolice said on Friday the inventor had told them he dropped Wall off from his submarine in Copenhagen on Thursday night. On Sunday they said they had since been given another explanation by Madsen, but declined to elaborate.\n\nPolice in Sweden said they had tried without success to contact Wall by phone and that her family had not heard from her.\n\nThe submarine, UC3 Nautilus, is one of three constructed by Madsen. It can carry eight people.", "time": "14:11:00"}

"url": "https://newsline.com/sunk-submarine-mystery-danish-inventor-tells-court-he-didn039t-kill-female-journalist/", "body": "Danish inventor Peter Madsen, charged in court Saturday with the death of Swedish journalist Kim Wall, who disappeared on Thursday after boarding his private submarine, has denied any guilt. He previously said he dropped her off on one of Copenhagen's harbor islands.\n\nMedia frenzy surrounding the case forced the hearing to be moved to a larger courtroom in Copenhagen on Saturday.\n\n\"I would like to have my say,\" Madsen, 46, told reporters and the public at the courtroom after the prosecutor said he faced \"preliminary charges [of manslaughter] for having killed in an unknown way and in an unknown place Kim Isabell Frerika Wall of Sweden.\"\n\nThe judge insisted, however, that initial statements should be given behind closed doors. After the hearing, Madsen, who has been a suspect since Friday, was placed in detention for 24 days.\n\nFriends, relatives and colleagues of Wall, who had been educated at Columbia University, Sorbonne and the London School of Economics, and worked as a freelance journalist, have bombarded social media with requests for information about her. Her family has also released a statement saying they still hoped that she would be found \"safe and well.\" Wall has not been reachable by phone since shortly after boarding Madsen's UC3 Nautilus submarine as part of an assignment for \"Wired\" magazine on Thursday evening.\n\nOn Saturday, the rescue vessel Vina recovered the UC3 Nautilus submarine, which is being treated as a possible crime scene, from the bottom of the sea near the island of Dragoer south of Copenhagen. The 18-meter-long, 40-ton vessel, built in 2008 with help from crowdfunding, was at the time the biggest private submarine in the world, and made its designer and captain a national celebrity.\n\nThe disappearance of Wall, whose articles have been published by the New York Times, the Guardian and other high-profile publications, was first reported by her boyfriend, who called the police after she failed to return on Thursday night.\n\nUnable to contact the Nautilus, police began a rescue operation involving two helicopters, three ships, and multiple volunteer vessels.\n\nKristian Isbak, who runs a marine company, says that he saw the moment the Nautilus sank on Friday morning.\n\nIsbak responded to the Navy's call to help locate the missing submarine, noticed the vessel on the sonar, and then spotted its sail above the water.\n\n\"We realized that it was Peter Madsen's submarine. A man sat in the tower, he climbed down and then up into the tower again,\" he told Danish daily Ekstra Bladet. \"There was a powerful pressure wave around the submarine. It began to sink. Madsen stood quite calmly in the tower. When the submarine had sunk so much that he could swim, it only took 10-15 seconds, Madsen leaped into the water and paddled to a rescue boat.\"\n\nMadsen gave a thumbs-up to gathered reporters when he came ashore, though admitted to local broadcaster TV2 that he was \"sad\" to have lost the Nautilus.\n\nWhen asked about the whereabouts of Wall, he claimed that he dropped her off near a restaurant on Refshaleon Island in Copenhagen harbor on Thursday evening, and then gave his own account of the sinking.\n\n\"I was out on a rehearsal trip, tinkering with different things in the submarine. Then a defect happened with a ballast tank which wasn't that serious, until I tried to repair it. Then it suddenly became very serious,\" Madsen told TV2. \"After that, it took 30 seconds for Nautilus to sink. I couldn't close the catch or anything. But that might be OK, as I would still be down there then.\"\n\nDanish daily Ekstra Bladet reported police sources as claiming that Madsen was suspected of intentionally sinking the vessel to cover up his tracks.", "time": "16:58:00"}

{"eng": "Kim Wall (British actor)"}, "score": 4, "type": "wiki", "id": "1438956"}], "url": "http://www.wmcactionnews5.com/story/36121505/the-latest-sub-owner-ordered-held-in-womans-disappearance", "body": "COPENHAGEN, Denmark (AP) - The Latest on a private submarine that sank off Denmark: (all times local):\n\n5 p.m.\n\nA Danish court has ordered the owner of an amateur-built submarine to be held in pre-trial detention for 24 days while police investigate the disappearance of a Swedish journalist who had been on the ship.\n\nPeter Madsen was arrested Friday on preliminary manslaughter charges after his 40-ton, nearly 18-meter-long (60-foot-long) submarine sank off Denmark's eastern coast. He has denied responsibility for the fate of 30-year-old Kim Wall, saying she had disembarked before his vessel went down.\n\nJudge Kari Soerensen announced the ruling Saturday after a two-hour custody hearing held behind closed doors.\n\nMadsen's defense lawyer, Bettina Hald Engmark, said her client maintains he is innocent.\n\nHald Engmark says Madsen is \"willing to cooperate\" and hasn't decided whether to appeal the detention ruling.\n\nThe family of a journalist who has been missing since she joined the inventor of an amateur-built submarine on a voyage in Denmark says she freelanced for prestigious publications such as the New York Times, The Guardian and Vice Magazine.\n\nKim Wall's family said in statement emailed to The Associated Press on Saturday, \"It is with great dismay that we received the news that Kim went missing during an assignment in Denmark.\"\n\nHer family says the 30-year-old Sweden-born journalist lives in New York and Peking and had studied at the Sorbonne university in Paris and the London School of Economics.\n\nShe also received a master's degree in journalism from Columbia University in New York in 2013.\n\nThe submarine's Danish inventor, Peter Madsen, is being held on suspicion of manslaughter in Wall's disappearance.\n\nThe submarine sank on Friday, but Madsen says Wall disembarked on Thursday night.\n\nA boater who helped search a private submarine that sank off Denmark says he saw inventor Peter Madsen Kristian standing in the vessel's tower while it was still afloat.\n\nKristian Isbak tells The Associated Press he had responded to the Navy's call to help locate the submarine on Friday when he spotted Madsen.\n\nIsbak says the inventor \"then climbed down inside the submarine and there was then some kind of air flow coming up and the submarine started to sink.\"\n\nWhile the UC3 Nautilus was going down, Isbak says \"came up again, stayed in the tower until water came into it as the submarine started sinking.\"\n\nIsbak says he then saw Madsen swim over to another private boat.\n\nMadsen's actions are being scrutinized because he is being detained in the disappearance of a Swedish journalist who had been onboard his submarine Thursday night.\n\nMadsen says he dropped her off before the sinking.\n\nA judge is set to decide if the owner of an amateur-built submarine should be held in custody during an investigation into whether he is responsible for the disappearance of a Swedish woman who had been onboard his submarine that sank off Denmark's east coast.\n\nPeter Madsen was arrested Friday on preliminary manslaughter charges after his 40-ton, nearly 18-meter-long (60-foot-long) UC3 Nautilus sank. He has denied responsibility for the 30-year-old woman's fate, saying she disembarked earlier.\n\nThe woman's boyfriend alerted authorities that the sub had not returned, prompting a major maritime search. The Navy said it was spotted sailing but then sank.\n\nMadsen told authorities he dropped the woman off on an island in Copenhagen's harbor a few hours into their Thursday night trip.\n\nThe hearing starts at 1200 GMT.\n\nCopyright 2017 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. This material may not be published, broadcast, rewritten or redistributed.", "time": "15:24:00"}

"https://www.reuters.com/article/us-denmark-submarine-idUSKBN1AS0V2", "body": "COPENHAGEN (Reuters) - Danish police said on Saturday they were preparing to search a sunken submarine owned by Danish inventor Peter Madsen who has been charged with the inadvertent manslaughter of a journalist.\n\nThe police said that Madsen, 46, was being held in custody for 24 days, accused of killing Swedish woman Kim Wall, 30, who they said had been on his submarine before it sank on Friday.\n\nMadsen was rescued on Friday morning in a navy operation and taken ashore after his homemade 17-metre submarine went down.\n\nThe vessel was recovered on Saturday in Koge Bay, south of Copenhagen, at a depth of seven meters, and taken into harbor.\n\nIt will be partly drained of water and searched by the police late on Saturday and early Sunday.\n\nMadsen, an entrepreneur known as an artist, submarine builder and aerospace engineer, went before a judge on Saturday behind closed doors for preliminary questioning. His defense lawyer, Betina Hald Engmark, told Reuters he denied the charges.\n\nThe police said on Friday the inventor had said he had dropped Wall off in Copenhagen on Thursday night.\n\nThe police in Sweden said they had tried without success to contact her by phone and that her family had not heard from her.\n\nThe submarine, UC3 Nautilus, is one of three constructed by Madsen. It can carry eight people.", "time": "19:40:00"}

"http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/UC3_Nautilus", "label": {"eng": "UC3 Nautilus"}, "score": 3, "type": "wiki", "id": "1438666"}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kim_Wall_(British_actor)", "label": {"eng": "Kim Wall (British actor)"}, "score": 3, "type": "wiki", "id": "1438956"}], "url": "https://www.washingtonpost.com/business/technology/submarine-owner-suspected-of-murder-faces-custody-hearing/2017/08/12/3fc9df0e-7f3c-11e7-b2b1-aeba62854dfa_story.html", "body": "COPENHAGEN, Denmark -- A Danish court ordered the owner of an amateur-built submarine Saturday held in pre-trial detention for 24 days while police investigate the disappearance of a Swedish journalist who had been on the ship before it sank.\n\nPeter Madsen was arrested Friday on preliminary manslaughter charges, hours after his 40-ton, nearly 18-meter-long (60-foot-long) submarine sank off Denmark's eastern coast.\n\nThe inventor, who is from Denmark, has denied responsibility for the fate of 30-year-old Kim Wall, saying the journalist disembarked before his vessel went down.\n\nJudge Kari Soerensen announced the ruling after a two-hour custody hearing held behind closed doors.\n\nMadsen's defense lawyer, Bettina Hald Engmark, said her client maintains his innocence. He is \"willing to cooperate\" and hasn't decided whether to appeal the detention ruling, Hald Engmark said.\n\nBefore the hearing was closed, the courtroom was packed with Danish and Swedish reporters and the 46-year-old Madsen's relatives. Madsen smiled and chatted with his lawyer.\n\n\"I would very much like to express myself,\" he said after the preliminary charges were read.\n\nProsecutor Louise Pedersen said Madsen faces the preliminary manslaughter charge \"for having killed in an unknown way and in an unknown place Kim Isabell Frerika Wall of Sweden sometime after Thursday 5 p.m.\"\n\nWall's boyfriend alerted authorities early Friday that the sub, , named the UC3 Nautilus, had not returned to Copenhagen as expected. The Danish Navy launched a major search involving two helicopters, three ships and several private boats. The Navy said the sub was seen sailing, but then sank shortly afterward.\n\nKristian Isbak, who had responded to the Navy's call to help locate the ship on Friday, told The Associated Press he first spotted Madsen standing wearing his trademark military fatigues in the submarine's tower while it was still afloat.\n\n\"He then climbed down inside the submarine and there was then some kind of air flow coming up and the submarine started to sink,\" Isbak said. \"(He) came up again and stayed in the tower until water came into it\" before swimming to a nearby boat as the submarine sank, he added.\n\nMadsen told authorities he had dropped Wall off on an island in Copenhagen's harbor a few hours into their Thursday night trip.\n\n\"It is with great dismay that we received the news that Kim went missing during an assignment in Denmark,\" her family said in statement emailed to The Associated Press.\n\nThe Sweden-born freelance journalist studied at the Sorbonne university in Paris, the London School of Economics and at Columbia University in New York, where she graduated with a master's degree in journalism in 2013.\n\nShe lived in New York and Peking, her family said, and had written for The New York Times, The Guardian, the South China Morning Post and Vice Magazine, among other publications.\n\nA salvage vessel on Saturday raised the submarine, which was seven meters (23 feet) under water off Copenhagen's south island of Dragoer. The submarine was brought up some 7 kilometers (4.3 miles) off the coast and is expected to be transported to land at some point.\n\nIn theory, the Nautilus can dive up to 470 meters (1,550 feet) but has rarely gone deeper than 40 meters (132 feet), according to Madsen's business web site.\n\nIf tried and found guilty, Madsen would face between five years and life in prison.\n\nCopyright 2017 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. This material may not be published, broadcast, rewritten or redistributed.", "time": "20:28:00"}

"body": "COPENHAGEN, Denmark (AP) -- The Latest on a private submarine that sank off Denmark: (all times local):\n\n5 p.m.\n\nA Danish court has ordered the owner of an amateur-built submarine to be held in pre-trial detention for 24 days while police investigate the disappearance of a Swedish journalist who had been on the ship.\n\nPeter Madsen was arrested Friday on preliminary manslaughter charges after his 40-ton, nearly 18-meter-long (60-foot-long) submarine sank off Denmark's eastern coast. He has denied responsibility for the fate of 30-year-old Kim Wall, saying she had disembarked before his vessel went down.\n\nSponsored Content: How is your agency managing and maximizing its data? Share your opinions in a Federal News Radio survey.\n\nJudge Kari Soerensen announced the ruling Saturday after a two-hour custody hearing held behind closed doors.\n\nMadsen's defense lawyer, Bettina Hald Engmark, said her client maintains he is innocent.\n\nHald Engmark says Madsen is \"willing to cooperate\" and hasn't decided whether to appeal the detention ruling.\n\nThe family of a journalist who has been missing since she joined the inventor of an amateur-built submarine on a voyage in Denmark says she freelanced for prestigious publications such as the New York Times, The Guardian and Vice Magazine.\n\nDefense restoration fund might be a bargaining chip in budget talks\n\nKim Wall's family said in statement emailed to The Associated Press on Saturday, \"It is with great dismay that we received the news that Kim went missing during an assignment in Denmark.\"\n\nHer family says the 30-year-old Sweden-born journalist lives in New York and Peking and had studied at the Sorbonne university in Paris and the London School of Economics.\n\nShe also received a master's degree in journalism from Columbia University in New York in 2013.\n\nThe submarine's Danish inventor, Peter Madsen, is being held on suspicion of manslaughter in Wall's disappearance.\n\nThe submarine sank on Friday, but Madsen says Wall disembarked on Thursday night.\n\nA boater who helped search a private submarine that sank off Denmark says he saw inventor Peter Madsen Kristian standing in the vessel's tower while it was still afloat.\n\nKristian Isbak tells The Associated Press he had responded to the Navy's call to help locate the submarine on Friday when he spotted Madsen.\n\nIsbak says the inventor \"then climbed down inside the submarine and there was then some kind of air flow coming up and the submarine started to sink.\"\n\nWhile the UC3 Nautilus was going down, Isbak says \"came up again, stayed in the tower until water came into it as the submarine started sinking.\"\n\nIsbak says he then saw Madsen swim over to another private boat.\n\nMadsen's actions are being scrutinized because he is being detained in the disappearance of a Swedish journalist who had been onboard his submarine Thursday night.\n\nMadsen says he dropped her off before the sinking.\n\nA judge is set to decide if the owner of an amateur-built submarine should be held in custody during an investigation into whether he is responsible for the disappearance of a Swedish woman who had been onboard his submarine that sank off Denmark's east coast.\n\nPeter Madsen was arrested Friday on preliminary manslaughter charges after his 40-ton, nearly 18-meter-long (60-foot-long) UC3 Nautilus sank. He has denied responsibility for the 30-year-old woman's fate, saying she disembarked earlier.\n\nThe woman's boyfriend alerted authorities that the sub had not returned, prompting a major maritime search. The Navy said it was spotted sailing but then sank.\n\nMadsen told authorities he dropped the woman off on an island in Copenhagen's harbor a few hours into their Thursday night trip.", "time": "15:37:00"}

"http://thegardenisland.com/news/world/submarine-owner-detained-over-journalist-s-disappearance/article_53a4595e-ba95-5d08-a787-880d0f430fa7.html", "body": "Peter Madsen was arrested Friday on preliminary manslaughter charges, hours after his 40-ton, nearly 18-meter-long (60-foot-long) submarine sank off Denmark's eastern coast.\n\nThe inventor, who is from Denmark, has denied behind closed doors.\n\nMadsen's defense lawyer, Bettina Hald Engmark, said her client maintains his innocence. Madsen smiled and chatted with his lawyer.\n\n\"I would very much like to express myself,\" he said after the preliminary charges were read.\n\nProsecutor Louise Pedersen said Madsen faces the preliminary manslaughter charge \"for having killed in an unknown way and in an unknown place Kim Isabell Frerika Wall of Sweden sometime after Thursday 5 p.m.\"\n\nWall's boyfriend alerted authorities early Friday that the sub, , named the UC3 Nautilus, had not returned to Copenhagen as expected. The Danish Navy launched a major search involving two helicopters, three ships and several private boats. The Navy said the sub was seen sailing, but then sank shortly afterward.\n\nKristian Isbak, who had responded to the Navy's call to help locate the ship on Friday, told The Associated Press he first spotted Madsen standing wearing his trademark military fatigues in the submarine's tower while it was still afloat.\n\n\"He then climbed down inside the submarine and there was then some kind of air flow coming up and the submarine started to sink,\" Isbak said. \"(He) came up again and stayed in the tower until water came into it\" before swimming to a nearby boat as the submarine sank, he added.\n\nMadsen told authorities he had dropped Wall off on an island in Copenhagen's harbor a few hours into their Thursday night trip.\n\n\"It is with great dismay that we received the news that Kim went missing during an assignment in Denmark,\" her family said in statement emailed to The Associated Press.\n\nThe Sweden-born freelance journalist studied at the Sorbonne university in Paris, the London School of Economics and at Columbia University in New York, where she graduated with a master's degree in journalism in 2013.\n\nShe lived in New York and Peking, her family said, and had written for The New York Times, The Guardian, the South China Morning Post and Vice Magazine, among other publications.\n\nA salvage vessel on Saturday raised the submarine, which was seven meters (23 feet) under water off Copenhagen's south island of Dragoer. The submarine was brought up some 7 kilometers (4.3 miles) off the coast and is expected to be transported to land at some point.\n\nIn theory, the Nautilus can dive up to 470 meters (1,550 feet) but has rarely gone deeper than 40 meters (132 feet), according to Madsen's business web site.\n\nIf tried and found guilty, Madsen would face between five years and life in prison.", "time": "03:20:00"}

{"eng": "Kim Wall (British actor)"}, "score": 3, "type": "wiki", "id": "1438956"}], "url": "http://www.detroitnews.com/story/news/world/2017/08/12/danish-submarine-owner-held-journalist-disappearance/104528690/", "body": "CONNECTTWEETLINKEDINCOMMENTEMAILMORE\n\nCopenhagen, Denmark -- A Danish court ordered the owner of an amateur-built submarine Saturday held in pre-trial detention for 24 days while police investigate the disappearance of a Swedish journalist who had been on the ship before it sank.\n\nPeter Madsen was arrested Friday on preliminary manslaughter charges, hours after his 40-ton, nearly 18-meter-long (60-foot-long) submarine sank off Denmark's eastern coast.\n\nThe inventor, who is from Denmark, has denied responsibility for the fate of 30-year-old Kim Wall, saying the journalist disembarked before his vessel went down.\n\nJudge Kari Soerensen announced the ruling after a two-hour custody hearing held behind closed doors.\n\nMadsen's defense lawyer, Bettina Hald Engmark, said her client maintains his innocence. He is \"willing to cooperate\" and hasn't decided whether to appeal the detention ruling, Hald Engmark said.\n\nBefore the hearing was closed, the courtroom was packed with Danish and Swedish reporters and the 46-year-old Madsen's relatives. Madsen smiled and chatted with his lawyer.\n\n\"I would very much like to express myself,\" he said after the preliminary charges were read.\n\nProsecutor Louise Pedersen said Madsen faces the preliminary manslaughter charge \"for having killed in an unknown way and in an unknown place Kim Isabell Frerika Wall of Sweden sometime after Thursday 5 p.m.\"\n\nWall's boyfriend alerted authorities early Friday that the sub, , named the UC3 Nautilus, had not returned to Copenhagen as expected. The Danish Navy launched a major search involving two helicopters, three ships and several private boats. The Navy said the sub was seen sailing, but then sank shortly afterward.\n\nKristian Isbak, who had responded to the Navy's call to help locate the ship on Friday, told The Associated Press he first spotted Madsen standing wearing his trademark military fatigues in the submarine's tower while it was still afloat.\n\n\"He then climbed down inside the submarine and there was then some kind of air flow coming up and the submarine started to sink,\" Isbak said. \"(He) came up again and stayed in the tower until water came into it\" before swimming to a nearby boat as the submarine sank, he added.\n\nMadsen told authorities he had dropped Wall off on an island in Copenhagen's harbor a few hours into their Thursday night trip.\n\n\"It is with great dismay that we received the news that Kim went missing during an assignment in Denmark,\" her family said in statement emailed to The Associated Press.\n\nThe Sweden-born freelance journalist studied at the Sorbonne university in Paris, the London School of Economics and at Columbia University in New York, where she graduated with a master's degree in journalism in 2013.\n\nShe lived in New York and Peking, her family said, and had written for The New York Times, The Guardian, the South China Morning Post and Vice Magazine, among other publications.\n\nA salvage vessel on Saturday raised the submarine, which was seven meters (23 feet) under water off Copenhagen's south island of Dragoer. The submarine was brought up some 7 kilometers (4.3 miles) off the coast and is expected to be transported to land at some point.\n\nIn theory, the Nautilus can dive up to 470 meters (1,550 feet) but has rarely gone deeper than 40 meters (132 feet), according to Madsen's business web site.\n\nIf tried and found guilty, Madsen would face between five years and life in prison.\n\nCONNECTTWEETLINKEDINCOMMENTEMAILMORE\n\nCopyright 2017 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. This material may not be published, broadcast, rewritten or redistributed.\n\nRead or Share this story: http://detne.ws/2w1fhbq", "time": "20:14:00"}

"body": "STOCKHOLM: Danish police hunting for a missing journalist said Sunday they searched a huge homemade submarine that sank last week, but no body was found.\n\n\"The sub has been searched and there is nobody on board -- neither dead nor alive,\" Copenhagen police homicide chief Jens Moller told reporters.\n\nThe journalist had been aboard the submarine before it sank. The vessel's 46-year-old inventor Peter Madsen has been accused of negligent manslaughter and was on Saturday remanded in custody for 24 days.\n\nThe vessel, the Nautilus, was refloated and towed to the Copenhagen port on Saturday, then emptied of water overnight. On Sunday police entered the sub and found it empty.\n\nPolice have identified the missing journalist as Kim Wall, a 30-year-old Swedish woman who was writing a feature about Madsen.\n\nNothing has been heard from her since Thursday evening when she boarded the sub with Madsen.\n\nHer boyfriend alerted police early Friday that she had not returned home as planned.\n\nMadsen claims he dropped her off on the Refshaleoen island on Thursday evening after the interview.\n\nEarly Friday, Danish authorities announced they were looking for the Nautilus in waters off Copenhagen.\n\nAround midday Friday, the vessel was located in a bay in Koge, some 50 kilometres (30 miles) south of the Danish capital. Just after being located, Madsen was rescued and the submarine suddenly sank.\n\nMadsen said in media interviews after his rescue that the sub encountered a problem with the ballast tank.\n\nHowever, Moller said Sunday it appeared as though the sub was intentionally sunk, amid media speculation that Madsen may have downed the vessel to cover up a crime.\n\n\"It appears as though it was a deliberate action that caused the sub to sink,\" Moller said.\n\nWall is a freelance journalist based in China and the US. Her articles have appeared in the New York Times and the Guardian, among others.\n\n\"We're still hoping that we'll find Kim Wall alive, but we are preparing ourselves for the fact that she may not be,\" Moller said Sunday.\n\nMadsen made headlines when he launched the 18-metre Nautilus in 2008, at the time the world's biggest homemade submarine. - AFP", "time": "11:45:00"}
