"https://www.thelocal.se/20170812/danish-submarine-owner-charged-over-swedish-journalists-death", "body": "A Danish inventor and owner of a huge private submarine is accused of manslaughter after the disappearance of a female journalist who had been on board before it sank, police said Friday.\n\nThe submarine owner denies killing the Swedish woman, saying he last saw her when he dropped her off on the tip of an island near Copenhagen late on Thursday.\n\nPolice have not yet gained access to the sunken submarine, but have decided to charge the owner for the death of the missing Swedish woman, Copenhagen Police confirmed in a statement.\n\nDanish authorities announced early Friday they were looking for the Nautilus sub, reported to have gone missing the night before in the \u00d6resund straight between Denmark and Sweden.\n\nThe submarine's owner and a Swedish journalist had been on board the vessel when it left the Refshale\u00f8en island off Copenhagen on Thursday evening.\n\nAccording to Denmark's military command centre (Forsvarets Operationscenter), the alarm that the craft was missing was raised at 2:30am on Friday by the partner of the Swedish woman.\n\nThe vessel - the biggest privately-made sub ever made when built in 2008 - was located in a bay in K\u00f8ge, some 50 kilometres from the Danish capital, at around 10:30 on Friday morning.\n\nRadio contact was then made and the owner said that he was setting course to Copenhagen, police confirmed in a statement.\n\nBut the submarine sank at around 11:00am.\n\nAfter the sub was found, the owner alone was brought to shore on board a private boat, but there was no trace of the woman.\n\nThe owner then reported that the woman had left the vessel on Thursday evening. Police immediately launched a search.\n\nREAD ALSO: Swedish woman still missing as Denmark sends divers to stricken sub\n\n\"Divers have today been at the submarine, which is in seven-metre deep water. It has not been possible to gain access to the submarine, since it must either be stabilised where it is or salvaged and towed to port for this to be possible. This will probably take place during [Saturday] morning,\" police said.\n\n\"The owner of the submarine was arrested and is accused of having killed the Swedish woman without intent,\" the police statement said.\n\n\"He denies the allegations and explains that he left the woman on the end of the Refshale\u00f8en island\" at around 10:30pm, the statement continues.\n\nThe submarine owner is due to appear before a judge on Saturday.\n\nCopenhagen Police also appealed for witnesses to come forward as they began investigation into the course of events involving the submarine.\n\n\"We would like to make contact with witnesses who have either seen the submarine with the two persons leave the harbour around 19:00 or have observed the submarine and its crew approach the tip of Refshale\u00f8en at around 22:30. We would additionally like to speak with possible witnesses that may have seen the Swedish woman after 22:30 on Thursday evening. Out of consideration to the further investigation of this case, we have nothing to add at this stage,\" deputy chief inspector Jens M\u00f8ller Jensen said.\n\nSubmarine disappearance timeline: What we know so far\n\nThursday 7pm: The submarine, crewed by its owner and a Swedish journalist, sails from the Refshale\u00f8en island harbour near Copenhagen.\n\nThursday 8:30pm: Denmark military authorities receive a message from a cruise ship that observed the submarine sail out of Copenhagen Harbour, according to a DR report.\n\nFriday 2:30am: The partner of the Swedish woman reports that the craft is missing. The Danish Defence Command (V\u00e6rnsf\u00e6lles Forsvarskommando) begins searching for the submarine.\n\nFriday 10:30am: The submarine is sighted in K\u00f8ge Bay. Radio contact is made and the owner says he is setting course to Copenhagen, and that the submarine has technical problems.\n\nFriday 11:00am: The owner is recovered by a private boat, but there is no sign of the second crew member. The owner is sailed to land at Drag\u00f8r Harbour.\n\nFriday afternoon: Police in Sweden state that a missing person alert issued during the morning pertains to the woman on board the submarine and remains in place, reports Swedish news agency TT.\n\nFriday 5:44pm: Copenhagen police announce through a press statement that the owner of the Nautilus has been charged over the woman's death. Police divers have located the sunken submarine but have not yet gained access to it.", "time": "08:00:00"}

"wiki", "id": "1438956"}], "url": "http://hosted2.ap.org/CARIE/0260ea4c3e85456b80715585ba3c7b5b/Article_2017-08-12-EU--Denmark-Missing%20Submarine/id-d0407825c3334725a6632bd7f2545794", "body": "COPENHAGEN, Denmark (AP) -- Danish prosecutors urged a judge on Saturday to hold in pre-trial detention the owner of an amateur-built submarine, suspected of being responsible for the disappearance of a Swedish woman who had been onboard the ship that later sank.\n\nPeter Madsen was arrested Friday on preliminary manslaughter charges after his 40-ton, nearly 18-meter-long (60-foot-long) ship, named the UC3 Nautilus, sank off Denmark's eastern coast. He has denied responsibility for the fate of 30-year-old Kim Wall, saying she had disembarked earlier.\n\n\"Peter Madsen faces preliminary charges (of manslaughter) for having killed in an unknown way and in an unknown place Kim Isabell Frerika Wall of Sweden sometime after Thursday 5 p.m.,\" Prosecutor Louise Pedersen told a packed courtroom, where proceedings began in a larger hall after delays due in part to overcrowding in another location.\n\nThe woman's boyfriend alerted authorities that the sub had not returned, prompting a major search involving two helicopters, three ships and several private boats. The Navy said that the sub had been spotted sailing but then sank shortly afterward.\n\nMadsen in the courtroom smiling, chatting with his defense lawyer. \"I would very much like to express myself,\" he said after the preliminary charges were read. The court was then closed for deliberation as judge Kari Soerensen deliberated her decision.\n\nKristian Isbak, who had responded to the Navy's call to help locate the ship, sailed out immediately Friday and saw Madsen standing wearing his trademark military fatigues in the submarine's tower while it was still afloat.\n\n\"He then climbed down inside the submarine and there was then some kind of air flow coming up and the submarine started to sink,\" Isbak told The Associated Press. \"(He) came up again and stayed in the tower until water came into it\" before swimming to a nearby boat as the submarine sank, he added.\n\nMadsen told authorities he had dropped the woman off on an island in Copenhagen's harbor a few hours into their Thursday night trip.\n\n\"It is with great dismay that we received the news that Kim went missing during an assignment in Denmark,\" the family said in statement emailed to The Associated Press.\n\nThe 30-year-old Sweden-born freelance journalist had studied at the Sorbonne university in Paris, the London School of Economics and at Columbia University in New York where she graduated with a master's degree in journalism in 2013.\n\nShe lives in New York and Peking, the family said, and has written for the New York Times, The Guardian, the South China Morning Post and Vice Magazine, among others.\n\nA salvage vessel, the Vina, was Saturday working on raising the submarine, which was seven meters (23 feet) under water off Copenhagen's south island of Dragoer.\n\nIn theory, the vessel can dive up to 470 meters (1,550 feet) but has rarely gone deeper than 40 meters (132 feet), according to its Web site.\n\nIf tried and found guilty, Madsen would face between five years and life in prison.", "time": "13:53:00"}

The 26-foot submarine sank just as Mr. Madsen jumped into the water and swam toward a rescue boat, a rescuer said.\n\nAs he was brought to shore, Mr. Madsen told the local television station TV2 that he had been on a test drive when he ran into problems with a valve on a ballast tank on the vessel.\n\n\"I was toying with various things on the submarine and then an error occurred,\" he said, adding he had only 30 seconds to leave the vessel before it sank.\n\nAccording to a police statement, Mr. Madsen said he dropped off Ms. Wall in a remote part of the port of Copenhagen around 10.30 p.m. and continued alone.\n\nA family statement sent by Tom Wall, Ms. Wall's brother, said that she had been with Mr. Madsen for an interview when she vanished. \"We sincerely hope that she will be found and that she is well,\" the statement said.\n\nMs. Wall is a graduate of Columbia University, and her work has appeared in a wide range of international publications including The New York Times.\n\nChristopher Harres, a Columbia graduate and an investigative journalist in Mobile, Ala., said of Ms Wall: \"She was literally loved everywhere she went. Her smile and charm could get her into events and past police cordons. Her smile filled your heart, her humor and hilarious observations could put you on the floor.\"\n\nHe added: \"Kim embodied everything that was good in journalism and storytelling. She reported from North Korea, China and all over Europe. She had wanderlust in droves and it hung off her every word.\"\n\nOn Saturday, the authorities raised the vessel from a depth of seven feet and started taking it to shore. Divers were unable to enter the submarine.\n\nFor years Mr. Madsen has led a community of amateurs in Copenhagen working to launch the world's first manned amateur space rocket. Other members of the community successfully launched an unmanned rocket 1.7 miles into the air in 2011.\n\nMr. Madsen had planned three launches this summer in preparation for a possible space mission in 2019 with only himself onboard.\n\nHe's been described in the local media as a maverick and a \"Gyro Gearloose\" with high ambitions and low social skills.\n\n\"He argues with every Tom, Dick and Harry. I've argued with him as well. But that's what it's like with people driven by deep passion,\" Thomas Djursing, an editor who wrote a book about Mr. Madsen, told the daily newspaper BT.\n\nIn 2015, the inventor had a severe argument over ownership of the UC3 Nautilus with an association formed to support his plans to build the submarine. In the end, his supporters pulled out.\n\nIn a message published on the association's website two years ago, his associates quoted a text message from Mr. Madsen that rings ominously today: \"A curse lies over Nautilus. That curse is me. There will not be calm around Nautilus as long as I exist.\"", "time": "15:39:00"}

before it sank.\n\nMs Wall had been writing about Madsen for a story and is believed to have set sail with him from Refshale Island at 7pm on Thursday.\n\nHer boyfriend reported her missing in the early hours of Friday morning saying she had failed to return from her trip.\n\nBut Madsen says he returned Ms Wall to land at 10.30pm on Thursday and has denied any involvement in her disappearance.\n\nA search for the missing submarine was launched after Ms Wall's boyfriend raised the alarm.\n\nThe Navy said the US3 Nautilus was initially seen sailing normally but sank shortly afterwards in Koge Bay, south of Copenhagen.\n\nMadsen escaped from the submarine as it sank and was rescued by a private boat.\n\nHe told Denmark's TV2 channel there had been a problem with a ballast tank and that it only took 30 seconds for the sub to sink.\n\nA salvage vessel has raised the sub to the surface where it is expected to be transported back to land at some point.\n\nThe decision to rescind Madsen in custody for a further 24 days was made by a judge after a two-hour custody hearing.\n\nMadsen's defence lawyer said her client maintains he is innocent but is \"willing to cooperate\" and has not decided whether to appeal the ruling.\n\nCopenhagen police have appealed for anyone who may have seen Ms Wall to contact them.\n\nThey described her as \"160cm tall, 56kg, 30 years old, with reddish-brown hair and green eyes\".\n\nShe was wearing an orange blouse with long sleeves, a black and white floral skirt, nylon stockings and white tennis shoes when she disappeared.\n\nAccording to her family Ms Wall lived in New York and Beijing, and had written for The New York Times, The Guardian, the South China Morning Post and Vice Magazine, among others.", "http://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-40911387", "body": "Police in Copenhagen say they are charging submarine enthusiast and rocket builder Peter Madsen in connection with the death of a missing Swedish journalist.\n\nThe Dane is the skipper and designer of the UC3 Nautilus, a privately-owned submarine which sank off the Danish coast on Friday.\n\nSome reports describe Mr Madsen as a \"hobby engineer\", and it is not clear what his background and training is.\n\nWhile building his own crowd-funded submarine might seem challenging enough, after completing the Nautilus - which he claims is the world's biggest privately-built submarine - in 2008, he moved on to a more lofty ambition - space exploration.\n\nHe now runs an organisation called Rocket-Madsens Space Laboratory, which is funded by donations, and aims to launch a rocket from a floating platform in the Baltic, near the island Bornholm.\n\nA crowd-funding page was set up for the Nautilus prior to 2014 to attempt to raise $50,000 (\u00a339,000) to cover refurbishment costs - just $6,170 was raised. At that time the Nautilus had logged more than 1,000 dives and had a team of 10 volunteers working on her refurbishment.\n\nIn 2015, after a dispute with the group of volunteers maintaining it, ownership of the Nautilus was transferred to Mr Madsen, says a statement on the website (in Danish).\n\n\"You may think that a curse is lying on Nautilus. That curse is me,\" he had messaged members of the board, according to the statement. \"There will not be peace on Nautilus for as long as I exist.\"\n\nThe craft finally re-launched earlier this year. It has a diesel and an electric motor and is 17.8m in length.\n\nAccording to the crowd-funding page, Danish law prohibited the Nautilus's operators from taking on passengers, but the team offered tours of the craft while docked \"to give you the full experience of being aboard a real submarine\".\n\nBoth Rocket-Madsens Space Laboratory and Copenhagen Suborbitals - which Mr Madsen co-founded but has since left - are trying to become the first non-government, all-volunteer organisation to launch a human being into space.\n\nThe two organisations are in conflict over their launch area, and seem to communicate via blog warfare.", "time": "13:13:00"}

"https://www.thelocal.dk/20170811/missing-submarine-found-none-hurt-denmark", "body": "The private submarine UCS Nautilus and its crew have been found in good condition after a search lasting several hours.\n\nPress spokesperson with the Danish Defence Command (V\u00e6rnsf\u00e6lles Forsvarskommando) Christer Haven confirmed to broadcaster DR that the search for the vessel, lasting several hours, was now over.\n\nAfter half a day's search, the Nautilus, the world's largest private submarine, was found sailing in K\u00f8ge Bay.\n\nThe vessel went missing due to \"technical difficulties\" and it lost contact due to a bad radio connection, Peter Madsen, who built the submarine in 2008 and was on board, told DR.\n\nMadsen was accompanied by a Swedish journalist on the submarine, which was found after it eventually contacted Lyngby Radio, the Defence Command's centre for remote operation of 24 coastal radio stations in Denmark, reports Politiken.\n\nThe submarine left Copenhagen Harbour at 8:30pm on Thursday. It then failed to return to its dock at the Refshale\u00f8en harbour at the scheduled time, prompting the Swedish journalist's partner to alert the Armed Forces at 2:30am, reports DR.\n\nAfter around eight hours, the Danish military was able to announce the safety of vessel and the crew via Twitter.\n\nPrivat ub\u00e5d Nautilus fundet sejlende ved K\u00f8ge Bugt. @forsvaretdk indstiller efters\u00f8gning.#dkforsvar #v\u00e6rdatk\u00e6mpefor -- Forsvaret (@forsvaretdk)\n\nAugust 11, 2017\n\nThe Armed Forces despatched boats and helicopters to search for the submarine, with the help of the Marine Home Guard.\n\nThe search team initially scoured K\u00f8ge Bay, along with areas around southwest and east of the Amager and Saltholmen islands.\n\nA file photo of the Nautilus. Photo: Bardur Eklund/Scanpix\n\nThe Forces then intensified their search in the Middelgrunden area off Nordhavn, having been informed that Madsen had planned to sail there, according to Politiken's report.\n\n\"We are incredibly happy to have found them safe and sound,\" Haven told Politiken.", "time": "11:26:00"}

coast.\n\nPeter Madsen was arrested Friday on preliminary manslaughter charges after his 40-ton, nearly 18-meter-long (60-foot-long) UC3 Nautilus sank. He has denied responsibility for the 30-year-old woman's fate, saying she disembarked earlier.\n\nThe woman's boyfriend alerted authorities that the sub had not returned, prompting a major maritime search. The Navy said it was spotted sailing but then sank.\n\nMadsen told authorities he dropped the woman off on an island in Copenhagen's harbor a few hours into their Thursday night trip.\n\nThe hearing starts at 1200 GMT.\n\nCopyright 2017 The Associated Press. "https://www.theregister.co.uk/2017/08/11/uc3_nautilus_submarine_sunk_passenger_missing/", "body": "Captain rescued but questions remain over passenger's whereabouts\n\nOne of the world's only privately built submarines has reportedly sunk under mysterious circumstances on the Danish coast.\n\nThe 33-ton diesel-electric boat, UC3 Nautilus, is said to have foundered after getting into difficulty in K\u00f8ge Bay, around 25 miles southwest of Copenhagen.\n\nProminent Swedish newspaper Aftonbladet wrote that the boat was reported missing by its captain's girlfriend after he failed to return to Copenhagen harbour as scheduled. This prompted a search by the Danish Navy.\n\nWhile the navy apparently found the Nautilus and her captain, Peter Madsen, on the sea's surface, it appears that the boat foundered shortly afterwards as a result of \"technical problems\", judging by other accounts.\n\nOne Swedish journalist aboard the submarine who was reportedly put ashore before the boat ran into trouble has not yet been accounted for, according to Danish newspaper Berlingske. Bloomberg News reported that Madsen told a local TV station about the sinking, revealing that a problem with a ballast tank caused the crowdfunded vessel to sink.\n\nBallast tanks are used to dive and surface a submarine by changing its buoyancy. When the tanks are filled with water, the submarine sinks; when they are pumped out with compressed air, the sub rises.\n\n\"It took about 30 seconds for Nautilus to sink, and I couldn't close any hatches or anything,\" Madsen was reported as saying. \"But I guess that was pretty good because I otherwise still would have been down there.\"\n\nThe Nautilus itself was launched in 2008, having been built by Madsen and a group of friends. The Wikipedia entry for the boat appears to have been written by someone familiar with the Nautilus's design and systems, judging by the level of detail. While her theoretical crush depth is given as \"400m-500m\", this seems a tad optimistic. Proper naval submarines tend to operate at these levels, and the 18-metre Nautilus is far smaller than those.\n\nThe boat was reportedly equipped with a fully functional snorkel system as well, allowing her to use her diesel engines for propulsion while submerged just below the surface. Her maximum speed was given as a stately 9 knots. A few years ago a crowdfunding project to raise $50,000 for a refit fell well short of its target.\n\nThe Nautilus was unarmed, though was reportedly well equipped with video cameras and portholes for observation. She was relaunched in April this year after a six-year refit, if Wikipedia is to be believed.\n\nPrivate submarines, as distinct from submersibles used for scientific research and the like, are vanishingly rare. The traditional size and hull form of submarines is driven by their need to carry armaments, sensors and a crew to operate them; the size is simply not necessary when you don't need half a dozen torpedo tubes in the bows and stern of your boat, or a ballistic missile compartment in the middle of it. Scientific and private submersibles, as a result, tend to resemble crabs with bulbous heads rather than missiles.\n\nNonetheless, the submarine hull form is now iconic, in the same way as Concorde will forever represent supersonic passenger aircraft. \u00ae", "time": "14:58:00"}

Peter Madsen, de 46 a\u00f1os, ha quedado en prisi\u00f3n preventiva durante 24 d\u00edas tras prestar declaraci\u00f3n ante el juez instructor y despu\u00e9s de que la fiscal\u00eda le acusase de la muerte de la reportera de 30 a\u00f1os Kim Wall, informan medios locales.\n\nLa fiscal Louise Pedersen asegur\u00f3 que se han presentado cargos por homicidio contra Madsen \"por haber matado de forma desconocida y en un lugar desconocido\" a la periodista sueca, un delito con una condena de entre cinco a\u00f1os de c\u00e1rcel y cadena perpetua. No obstante, la polic\u00eda reconoci\u00f3 que la reportera sigue desaparecida y avanz\u00f3 adem\u00e1s que parece que el sospechoso hundi\u00f3 \"de forma deliberada\" el submarino. \"Seguimos esperando encontrar a Kim Wall con vida, pero nos preparamos para la eventualidad de que no sea as\u00ed\", asegur\u00f3 el jefe de Homicidios de Copenhague, Jens Moller, en rueda de prensa.\n\nEl detenido, por su parte, se ha declarado inocente, asegura que la periodista sueca desembarc\u00f3 antes de que su submarino -de casi 18 metros de largo y 40 toneladas- se hundiese en la costa oriental danesa y quedase a unos 7 metros de profundidad. Ambos se embarcaron a continuaci\u00f3n en la nave y partieron para un peque\u00f1o viaje, punto a partir del cual la historia se complica.\n\nMadsen asegura que, tras un paseo de un par de horas, dej\u00f3 a Wall en Refshaleoen, una isla de Copenhague, a petici\u00f3n suya, pero la periodista no regres\u00f3 a su domicilio. El novio de la mujer denunci\u00f3 en la ma\u00f1ana del viernes la desaparici\u00f3n de Wall ante las autoridades danesas, que lanzaron una operaci\u00f3n de salvamento con dos helic\u00f3pteros, tres barcos y algunas embarcaciones privadas.\n\nEl submarino fue entonces detectado en la bah\u00eda de Koge, cerca la isla de Dragoer, con Madsen ya fuera, sobre la torre del aparato, pero se hundi\u00f3 poco despu\u00e9s. El inventor fue rescatado por una embarcaci\u00f3n privada. \"Estaba en un viaje de prueba y prob\u00e9 unas cuantas cosas en el submarino. Entonces pas\u00f3 algo con el tanque de lastre\", explic\u00f3 el propio Madsen en declaraciones a medios daneses tras su rescate.\n\nTras ser localizado a unos siete metros de profundidad, el \"UC3 Nautilus\" fue arrastrado por un barco de salvamento unos siete kil\u00f3metros y depositado en la costa para que sea transportado a tierra firme. En una primera inspecci\u00f3n, las fuerzas de seguridad no encontraron ning\u00fan cuerpo a bordo, indic\u00f3 Moller. Seg\u00fan la p\u00e1gina web de Madsen, el submarino pod\u00eda sumergirse hasta 470 metros de profundidad, aunque habitualmente no desciende m\u00e1s all\u00e1 de los 40.", "time": "17:38:00"}], "count": 1, "page": 1}}}
